chunks.question: Do you think I will find the happiness I have been looking for if I convert to Islam?
chunks.answer:
I am sure100 % that Islam will give you the happiness which can never be bought by millions of dollars. It will grant you the happiness which is not to be found in travelling to different countries, driving luxurious cars, living in affluent villas or enjoying pleasures on fascinating beaches.
If you believe in Allah and follow his messenger in all his instructions, you will find a happiness that is only recognized by people who experienced it. It is the happiness of self-satisfaction and trust in your creator.	I am sorry. I think it
cannot be expressed by language. Lucky people can experience it, but it is very hard to explain it.
Is it not enough that you will not be scared from anything that happen to you in this world? Is it not enough that you will never be afraid of death? You will believe that death is the way to meet your creator and live in Paradise eternally in an unimaginable and eternal happiness.
Realistically speaking, I can see you have tried everything to get happiness and have travelled everywhere and have made everything expensive to get it. It is also obvious that you haven't found it yet.
So, why don't you try this way also? You will lose nothing. It is not an expensive one. I will not charge you any fees for my advice and you will not pay any money to be a Muslim. Just try it as you have tried every other way. I assure you, if you do this with a pure heart and true search of the right way, you will never regret it.

chunks.answer:
Allah forgive all sins whatever they were provided that you believe in Him as the one and only creator and believe in his messengers and his angels and his books and the Last Day and your fate whether good or bad.
The following verses and Hadeeth are evidence:
( 53 ) Say, "O My servants who have transgressed against themselves [by sinning], do not despair of the mercy of Allah. Indeed, Allah forgives all sins. Indeed, it is He who is the Forgiving, the Merciful."

We visited 'Amr bin Al-'as (May Allah be pleased with him) when he was in his deathbed	Then he ('Amr) turned his
face towards us and said:
“	When Allah instilled the love for Islam in my heart, I
went to Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and said, 'Extend your right hand, so that I pledge allegiance to you.' He (ﷺ) stretched out his right hand, but I withdrew my hand. He said, 'What is the matter, 'Amr?' I said, 'I wish to lay down some conditions.' He asked, 'What conditions do you wish to put forward?' I replied, 'To be granted forgiveness.' He said, 'Do you not know that (embracing) Islam wipes out all that has gone before it (previous misdeeds). Verily, emigration wipes out all the previous sins, and the Hajj (pilgrimage) wipes out all the previous sins.'

chunks.question: But if I convert to Islam, this will, definitely, put me in struggles and disputes with many people and many social systems that embrace ideologies in contrast to the teachings of Islam?
chunks.answer:
The struggles and disputes among individuals and nations are one of the universal laws preordained by Allah in this life. Struggles started as Man started living on Earth and will continue to the Last Day of this world.
Comprehensive peace and thorough happiness are impossible in this life. So, whether you are a believer or an unbeliever, you will face struggles and disputes. But, when you are a believer, you will be rewarded for patience and wise reactions. However, no rewards are offered to unbelievers.
The following verses show the inevitability of struggles on Earth among individuals and nations. They also show some of the wisdom behind these struggles and conflicts:
“	And We said, "Go down, [all of you], as enemies to one
another, and you will have upon the earth a place of settlement and provision for a time."
Al-Baqara – no. 2– verse 36
( 251 ) So they defeated them by permission of Allah, and David killed Goliath, and Allah gave him the kingship and prophethood and taught him from that which He willed. And if it were not for Allah checking [some] people by means of others, the earth would have been corrupted, but Allah is full of bounty to the worlds.
Al-Baqara – no. 2– verse 251

chunks.question: And If problems, sickness, poverty and calamities overwhelm me while I am a Muslim, does it mean that Allah do not like me or I am not a good Muslim? What does it mean in Islam if a Muslim is involved in sickness, poverty and calamities?
chunks.answer:
We were primarily created in this life to be tested as you learnt before. So, it is not logical or reasonable that anyone in this life will lead a happy and peaceful life until his death.
Calamities and problems are a must. Or how the test would be performed. Some people think that the more misfortunes they have in this life, the less loved and preferred they are by their creator. And the more happiness and fortunes they have, the more loved and preferred they are.
Actually, this is totally wrong. The fact is completely different. Allah usually test the true Muslims with more calamities and misfortunes either to test their true belief or to raise them in degrees.
Many verses in Quran shed light on this fact:
( 155 ) And We will surely test you with something of fear and hunger and a loss of wealth and lives and fruits, but give good tidings to the patient,
( 156 ) Who, when disaster strikes them, say, "Indeed we belong to Allah, and indeed to Him we will return."
( 157 ) Those are the ones upon whom are blessings from their Lord and mercy. And it is those who are the [rightly] guided.
Al Baqarah – no. 2 – verse 155 – 157
(23) Chapter: Patience at the time of calamity
It was narrated from Mus’ab bin Sa’d that his father, Sa’d bin Abu
Waqqas, said:
“I said: ‘O Messenger of Allah, which people are most severely tested?’ He said: ‘The Prophets, then the next best and the next best. A person is tested according to his religious commitment. If he is steadfast in his religious commitment, he will be tested more severely,
and if he is frail in his religious commitment, his test will be according to his commitment. Trials will continue to afflict a person until they leave him walking on the earth with no sin on him.’”
Reference: Sunan Ibn Majah 4023 :	 Book 36, Hadith 98 :	In-book reference
English translation	: Vol. 5, Book 36, Hadith 4023

chunks.question: And if I have a lot of money and fortunes while I am a Muslim, what should I do with this wealth according to Islam?
chunks.answer:
Firstly, you are free to do in your wealth what you like provided that you do not do an impermissible act. Do the right and get away from the forbidden and do not spend too much. This is stated in Qur'an:
( 31 ) O children of Adam, take your adornment at every masjid, and eat and drink, but be not excessive. Indeed, He likes not those who commit excess.
Al A'raf – no.7 – verse 31
In the coming verse, Allah instruct us to be moderate in spending. Not too much and not too little.
( 29 ) And do not make your hand [as] chained to your neck or extend it completely and [thereby] become blamed and insolvent. ( 30 ) Indeed, your Lord extends provision for whom He wills and restricts [it]. Indeed He is ever, concerning His servants, Acquainted and Seeing.
Al Isra" – no. 17 – verse 29 – 30
In this verse, Allah compare those who spend wastefully to the devils.
( 26 ) And give the relative his right, and [also] the poor and the traveler, and do not spend wastefully.
( 27 ) Indeed, the wasteful are brothers of the devils, and ever has Satan been to his Lord ungrateful.
Al Isra" – no.17 – verse 26 – 27
But take care:
One of the pillars of Islam is to pay a small amount of your money to the poor if your wealth reaches a specific amount. (Refer to Islamic Legislation to know more details). This is called "Zakat" or "paying alms to the poor”. This is a must for any Muslim to do. Many verses in Qur'an talk about this pillar. And it is always paired with prayer to show its importance:
( 110 ) And establish prayer and give zakah, and whatever good you put forward for yourselves - you will find it with Allah. Indeed, Allah of what you do, is Seeing.
Al Baqarah – no. 2 – verse 110
And after paying "Zakah", Allah urge true Muslims who want to reach higher degrees and compete to satisfy their Lord to pay more money from their wealth as "sadakat". This is not a must. But it is too much recommended for whoever seeks the highest degrees. Many verses talk about this in Qur'an. Allah compare those who pay this extra money to the poor as if they were giving a loan to their creator and He will multiply it for them as many times as He wish in the Hereafter.
Many verses in Qur’an tell us this fact and encourage us in a very attractive way to pay “sadakat” to the poor:
( 11 )	Who is it that would loan Allah a goodly loan so He will multiply it for him and he will have a noble reward?
Al Hadid – no. 57 – verse 11
( 245 ) Who is it that would loan Allah a goodly loan so He may multiply it for him many times over? And it is Allah who withholds and grants abundance, and to Him you will be returned.
Al Baqarah – no.2 – verse 245
Explanation: Do you think that Allah, the creator who own everything need a loan from you? Definitely, not. He is only making a metaphor to show you how he will reward you for this in the Hereafter. And to show you how He like this act from you so much. Again, it is the test. Allah could make everyone very rich. It is so easy for Him, but He is testing some people with fortunes and wealth and testing others with poverty and deprivation.
Also, these sayings by the prophet warn wealthy people in this life that they will be the lowest and the poorest in the Hereafter unless they abide by his advice:
Abu Dharr reported:
I went to the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) and he was sitting under the shade of the Ka'ba. As he saw me he said: By the Lord of the Ka'ba, they are the losers. I came there till I sat and I could not stay (longer) and (then) stood up. I said: Messenger of Allah, let my father, be ransom for you, who are they (the losers)? He said: They are those having a huge amount of wealth except so and so and (those who spend their wealth generously on them whom they find in front of them, behind them and on their right side and on their left side) and they are a few. And no owner of camels, or cattle or goat and sheep, who does not pay Zakat (would be spared punishment) but these (camels, cattle, goats and sheep) would come on the Day of Resurrection wearing more flesh and would gore him with their horns and trample them with their hooves. And when the last one would pass away, the first one would return (to trample him) till judgment would be pronounced among people.
Sahih Muslim 990 a
In-book reference
Book 12, Hadith 37
It was narrated from Abu Dharr that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: “The wealthiest will be the lowest on the Day of Resurrection, except those who do such and such with their money, and earn it from good sources.”
Sunan Ibn Majah 4130
Book 37, Hadith 31 :	In-book reference
English translation	: Vol. 5, Book 37, Hadith 4130
Abu Dharr reported:
I walked with the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) on the stony ground of Medina in the afternoon and we were looking at Uhud. The Messenger of Allah (way peace by upon him) said: Abu Dharr! I said: Messenger of Allah, I am here at thy beck and call. He said: What I desire is that Uhud be gold with me and three nights should pass and there is left with me any dinar but one coin which I would keep to pay debt. (I love) to spend it among the servants of Allah like this and he pointed in front of him, and on his right side and on his left side. We then proceeded on and he said: Abu Dharr. I said: At thy beck and call, Messenger of Allah. He (the Holy Prophet) said: The rich would be poor on the Day of Resurrection, but he who spent like this and like this and like this, and he pointed as at the first time.
Sahih Muslim 94 c
In-book reference	: Book 12, Hadith 41

chunks.question: What if I get a senior important job? What if I have authority, to be a manager, a minister, a political party leader …. etc.? What is Islam's stance on this? Does Islam encourage or discourage Muslims if they get jobs with authority?
chunks.answer:
Prophet Muhammad instructed us in "Sunnah" to get away from authority and positions as far as we can, especially if we are not up to the responsibility and cannot perform it fully and honestly.
Authority may look nice and tempting in this life but it becomes a huge burden and a heavy responsibility when you die and in the Hereafter. The only exception to this, is when it is offered to you and you did not ask for it. And you feel that you can perform its duties honestly. Otherwise, do not seek it in any way.
Many "hadeeths" in Sunnah talk about this advice:
(5)Chapter: Prohibition of Asking for Governorship It was narrated from Abu Hurairah that :
The Prophet [SAW] said: "You will be keen for governorship but it will be regret and loss on the Day of Resurrection. What a good position it is when they are alive, but how miserable their state when they die (and leave it behind)."
Sunan an-Nasa'i 5385 : Reference
Book 49, Hadith 7 :	In-book reference
English translation	: Vol. 6, Book 49, Hadith 5387
(3) Chapter: The prohibition of seeking or desiring a position of authority
It has been reported on the authority of 'Abd al-Rahman b. Samura who said:
The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said to me: 'Abd al-Rahman, do not ask for a position of authority, for if you are granted this position as a result of your asking for it, you will be left alone (without God's help to discharge the responsibilities attendant thereon), and if you are granted it without making any request for it, you will be helped (by God in the discharge of your duties).
Sahih Muslim 1652c :
Book 33, Hadith 15 :	In-book reference
USC-MSA web (English) reference	: Book 20, Hadith 4487
Chapter: It is disliked to be appointed to a position of authority unnecessarily
It has been narrated on the authority of Abu Dharr who said:
I said to the Prophet (ﷺ): Messenger of Allah, will you not appoint me to a public office? He stroked my shoulder with his hand and said: Abu Dharr, thou art weak and authority is a trust. and on the Day of judgment, it is a cause of humiliation and repentance except for one who fulfils its obligations and (properly) discharges the duties attendant thereon.
Sahih Muslim 1825 : Reference
Book 33, Hadith 19 :	In-book reference
USC-MSA web (English) reference	: Book 20, Hadith 4491

chunks.question: But I heard that Muslims have to pray 5 times every single day. They also must pay some money to the poor. In addition, they have to fast for one month every year. I think it is hard to abide by all these duties and be away from all the impermissible things in Islam. I feel I will be like a prisoner. What do you think?
chunks.answer:
To be honest with you, the Muslim duties need patience and true believing especially at the beginning. But if you are a true believer, after some time, you will find your pleasure in these duties. And you will never feel they are hard. But first be patient and honest and a true believer. Then, Allah will help you.
And you have to know that reaching Eternal Paradise is not that easy. It requires paying a high price. It needs piety, hard work, honesty and patience.
Some "Hadeeths" show this fact clearly:
The Paradise is surrounded by hardships and the Hell-Fire is surrounded by temptations.
Sahih Muslim - Book 53, Hadith 1
It was narrated from Abu Hurairah that the Messenger of Allah said: "When Allah created Paradise and Hell, He sent Jibril, peace be upon him, to Paradise and said: 'Look at it and at what I have prepared for its people in it.' He looked at it, then he came back
and said: 'By Your Glory, no one will hear of it but he will enter it.' So He commanded that it be surrounded by hardships and said: 'Go and look at it and at what I have prepared for its people in it.' He looked at it and saw that it had been surrounded with hardships. He (Jibril) said: 'By Your Glory, I fear that no one will enter it.' He (Allah) said: 'Go and look at the Fire and at what I have prepared for its people in it.' So he looked at it and parts of it were piled upon other parts. He came back and said: 'By Your Glory, no one will enter it.' So He commanded that it be surrounded with pleasures and said: 'Go and look at it.' So he looked at it and saw that it was surrounded with pleasures. He came back and said: 'By Your Glory, I fear that no one will be saved from it and all will enter it.'"
Sunan an-Nasa'i 3763 - Book 35, Hadith 3

chunks.question: Maybe I am partially convinced but I am still worried and uncertain, what should I do to feel quite certain and satisfied about Islam?
chunks.answer:
Raise your hands and supplicate honestly and faithfully to the creator of this universe before you go to bed or any suitable time when you are alone, you may tell Him: " Oh my creator and the creator of everything, guide me to the right belief. Guide me to the right religion that saves me. Guide me to the religion that you love" And he will definitely guide you sooner or later if you are truthful and honest in your search of the right religion.
( 69 ) And those who strive for Us - We will surely guide them to Our ways. And indeed, Allah is with the doers of good.
Al 'Ankabut – no.29 – verse 69

metadata.category: Section G – Wrap-up of the previous sections and Questions about how to be a Muslim, how to prepare for this decisive change, how to face potential challenges, how to prepare for post-Islam life and final essential pieces of advice

chunks.question: What else can I do, other than supplication, to feel certain and satisfied about Islam?
chunks.answer:
You can try three ways:
First, try to find answers to some of the questions you asked me in other religions and beliefs. Compare my answers to theirs. Be objective. Unbiased comparison will show you the difference and make truisms and facts clearer to you.
Second, I advise you to read the whole Qur'an once. Read it with a short explanation from beginning to end. Or you could listen to some surahs. You will surely feel it is a divine revelation not a human language. I am not exaggerating if I say that whatever you like, you will find it in Qur’an. Long books could be written to describe the beauty of Qur’an and still these books will never give Qur’an its due respect. Briefly, I can tell you that Qur’an is a book of everything beautiful and everything infallible. No wonder since it is the true word of Allah.
Third, try to read one of the short Sunnah books like “Riyad Al- Saliheen”. Read it with a short explanation. You will find an ocean of wisdom, a treasure of mercy and good behavior and a simple gate to happiness. It will benefit you in your life even if you do not embrace Islam.

chunks.type: Section G – Wrap-up of the previous sections and Questions about how to be a Muslim, how to prepare for this decisive change, how to face potential challenges, how to prepare for post-Islam life and final essential pieces of advice
chunks.question: Tell me one more concrete thing that I can do to feel satisfied about Islam.
chunks.answer:
Look inside yourself and look around you on Earth and in the sky and look at the tiny and the huge creatures in this world. Look at the billions of people who speak different languages and have different colors and shapes and they are given food, water and livelihood at the same time everywhere. Consider, think over and ask yourself honestly. Is it possible that all this huge universe has no creator? Is it possible that all this came out of nothing or by accident? Be honest with yourself and give up arrogance and you will find the right way easily.
The following verses in Quran ask and challenge all humans about some basic questions. Read and think:
( 35 ) Or were they created by nothing, or were they the creators [of themselves]?
( 36 ) Or did they create the heavens and the earth? Rather, they are not certain.
( 37 ) Or have they the depositories [containing the provision] of your Lord? Or are they the controllers [of them]?
At Tur – no.52 – verse 35 – 37
( 17 ) Then do they not look at the camels - how they are created? ( 18 ) And at the sky - how it is raised?
( 19 ) And at the mountains - how they are erected? ( 20 ) And at the earth - how it is spread out?
( 21 ) So remind, [O Muhammad]; you are only a reminder. ( 22 ) You are not over them a controller.
Al Ghashiyah – no.88 – verse 17 - 22

chunks.question: And does Islam provide clear answers and guidance for every minor detail in one's life? Or is it a religion of prayers and worshipping only?
chunks.answer:
Islam has guidance and clear answers for every and each minor detail in a Muslim's life. In some cases, you will find that scholars have different opinions and different verdicts. In this case, look for the verdict of the majority. It is safer for you. And you have to know that this is a sign of the flexibility of Islam. Also, you have to bear in
mind that Islamic scholars disagreed only in marginal affairs not in major principles.

chunks.type: Section G – Wrap-up of the previous sections and Questions about how to be a Muslim, how to prepare for this decisive change, how to face potential challenges, how to prepare for post-Islam life and final essential pieces of advice
chunks.question: And what should I do, if I want to convert to Islam?
chunks.answer:
-	You should first testify that "There is no god but Allah and that prophet Muhammad is his last messenger". You should believe in this from all your heart.
-	Then, you should wash yourself.
-	After that, you should start to learn the basics of Islam and how to pray and how to fast and how to pay "Zakat" or "alms" to the poor.
-	You should start to learn the most important, then, step by step, learn all the small details.
-	During learning, you should practice and apply step by step.
-	You should start with the basics like the 5 daily prayers and paying " the alms" to the poor.
-	You will need time to get used to the daily chores of a Muslim.
So, be patient.
-	You will surely make mistakes and sins, but Allah is forgiving if you repent faithfully. Every time you make a sin, Allah will forgive it, if you repent with a good intention.

chunks.type: Section G – Wrap-up of the previous sections and Questions about how to be a Muslim, how to prepare for this decisive change, how to face potential challenges, how to prepare for post-Islam life and final essential pieces of advice
chunks.question: And how do I distinguish between the permissible and the impermissible in Islam? What are the main sources for legislation in Islam?
chunks.answer:
The main sources for legislation in Islam by order of importance are:
1.	The Qur'an: and its explanations by prophet Muhammad, his companions and their followers. The explanations which were accepted by most of the great Islam scholars. But not the explanations done by some ignorant people or deviant scholars.
2.	Sunnah: which means all the sayings and the actions of prophet Muhammad. Also, these "hadeeths" or "sayings" should be understood as explained by the companions of the prophet and the great scholars of Islam.
3.	Consensus: which means the agreement among most of the great scholars of Islam on a specific "verdict". Since most of them agreed on this "verdict”, it becomes an Islamic legislation, even if a minority of scholars had a different point of view.
4.	The Islamic legislation tool of "measurement": This is an Islamic legislative tool used by scholars and Islamic legislators to deduce "Islamic verdicts" for the new incidents not mentioned in Qur'an or Sunnah. But it can be used only by great scholars not by ordinary people because you should master a lot of Islamic sciences in order to be able to use this tool.
For ordinary Muslims who are not scholars, they should accept ready-made verdicts made by great, honest and truthful scholars.

chunks.question: And What are the most important books that I should read to understand Islam in a good way? There are Thousands of books about Islam. In your opinion, what are the most significant ones for a new convert or a common Muslim?
chunks.answer:
The most indispensable books for any Muslim are as follows:
1.	The Holly Qur'an: with a short and authenticated explanation.
2.	"Riyad Al-Saliheen Book" : The most famous and authenticated short book for the ordinary Muslim about "Sunnah". This book includes (1905) hadeeths or sayings of prophet Muhammad. This book is recommended because it includes the most important sayings and actions of prophet Muhammad which are vital for any Muslim to know.
Then, there are some important books that any Muslim should read and understand like:
3.	An explanation for the the Islamic belief called "Tahawiyya Islamic Doctrine": This book is one of the most famous books which gives more details about the Islamic belief and gives citations from Qur'an and Sunnah.
4.	"The facilitated Islamic Jurisprudence in the light of Qur'an and Sunnah" : This is a simplified book in basic items of Islamic " Fiqh" or jurisprudence for the ordinary non- specialized Muslims.
5.		"The biographies of the noblest men and women in Islam" which is called in Arabic "Nozhat Al-Fudala'a in siyarAa'lam Al-Nubala'a": This book was written by "Al-Zahaby" and was simplified by " Muhammad Hasan Akeel Mussa". This book lets you know about the noblest and the greatest men and women in Islam and how they lived. This book gives any Muslim unforgettable and unimaginable real examples of very noble men and women. I think any Muslim needs this at a time when the examples for us have become "actors, actresses, singers and football players".
6.	Finally, you should read any simplified and authenticated book in the history of Islam to see how this religion started and how the early Muslims suffered unimaginable kinds of persecution and torture in order for this religion to come to us. You should know about the glorious days of Islam and how it controlled most of the world in less than 50 years from its outset. You should also know how it became weak again and how Muslims lost all power when they abandoned their religion.
Actually, reading history is a great benefit for anyone. It is full of lessons and morals and insight for the future. The future is no more than a repetition of the past incidents but with some difference in details. I think whoever studies the past and understands the present will definitely have some insight about the future.
Certainly, there are many other books for whoever wants to specialize and become a scholar. Actually, Muslims have a treasure of books written by ancient and recent scholars. But the books I mentioned are only for
the ordinary non-specialized Muslim who wants to know the basics of his religion in a relatively short time.
This hadeeth is also relevant to your question:
Yahya related to me from Malik that he heard that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said, "I have left two matters with you. As long as you hold to them, you will not go the wrong way. They are the Book of Allah and the Sunna of His Prophet."
Muwatta Malik
Arabic reference	: Book 46, Hadith 1628
USC-MSA web (English) reference: Book 46, Hadith 3

chunks.question: And what are the misleading books about Islam which include false or inaccurate information. Can you tell me a list of these books so that a new convert or an ordinary Muslim can avoid reading them?
chunks.answer:
I am not specialized in this matter, but I can advise you to read the books written by the scholars of “Sunnah and Unanimity” and never read any books written by any of the misguided sects and groups.
You can also ask for advice about this matter from honest Sunnah scholars.

chunks.question: Can you give me an example list of some honest and pious religious scholars whom a normal Muslim can trust?
chunks.answer:
Actually, honest and pious religious scholars are so many. You can find them in every age and in every country. If I give you a list, it will be a local one according to my limited knowledge. I am sure, you will come to know a lot of them bit by bit if you convert.
And when you go into any Islamic library or bookshop, you will find many of their books. And when you read old and recent books about Islam, you will also come across many of them. However, I tried to make a list for you from my humble knowledge. It is on p.
320. Surely, there are many other good scholars whom I do not know. So, my list is only a local and limited guide that depends on my limited knowledge.

chunks.question: Is it important to learn the Arabic language to be a good Muslim?
chunks.answer:
There are things you must learn in Arabic like how we pray and what we say in our prayers and some verses of Qur'an in Arabic so that you recite them in praying and in other occasions. But it is not a must to learn Arabic professionally as much as I know, it is only a desirable advantage for a Muslim to learn Arabic professionally.
I said it is a desirable advantage because learning Arabic will open for you the gates of reading the most important books about Islam in its original language especially Qur’an and Sunnah.
Don't forget that Arabic will be the language of paradise dwellers. Also, don't forget that Allah chose to send His final revelation to humans in Arabic. In addition, He selected an Arab messenger from the Arab people who speak Arabic.
Aren't all these Divine selections and facts any motivations for you to learn Arabic?

chunks.question: And if I convert to Islam and abide by its regulations, what is the most honorable task that I may do during my life after converting?
chunks.answer:
The most honorable thing to do in life is "Da'waa" or inviting people to Islam and trying to explain to them the right belief and its details because this is why we were created and this is why the earth and the heavens were created.
Read the following verses to remember why humans, the earth and the heavens were created primarily:
( 56 ) And I did not create the jinn and mankind except to worship Me.
( 57 ) I do not want from them any provision, nor do I want them to feed Me.
( 58 ) Indeed, it is Allah who is the [continual] Provider, the firm possessor of strength.
Adh Dhariyat– no.51 – verse 56 – 58
( 2 ) [He] who created death and life to test you [as to] which of you is best in deed - and He is the Exalted in Might, the Forgiving – Al Mulk– no. 67 – verse 2
( 33 ) And who is better in speech than one who invites to Allah and does righteousness and says, "Indeed, I am of the Muslims." Fussilat – no. 41 – verse 33
The Prophet said, "Convey from me even an Ayah of the
Qur'an……"

chunks.question: Some people are adventurous by nature. They love to be champions in sports or perform untraditional and courageous tasks or go on thrilling trips and tours or become famous actors or exceptional artists to enjoy their lives. I think there are thousands of these people around the world. How does Islam view these people?
chunks.answer:
Islam is a very practical religion. Allah want you to use your time efficiently in something useful and fruitful for you, for your family, for your community and for Islam. Islam is not against fun and playing provided that it has the following conditions: it benefits you in your practical life or in your religion; It is not a waste of time; It is not against the general ethics and principles of Islam; It doesn't take you from your basic daily chores. If any activity or travelling or fun is congruous with the previous conditions. I think it is not forbidden in Islam.
In the following verses Allah allude to the fact that everything was created for a purpose. It was not made for fun or playing:
( 38 ) And We did not create the heavens and earth and that between them in play.
( 39 ) We did not create them except in truth, but most of them do not know.
Ad Dukhan – No. 44 – verse 38, 39
In the following hadeeth, Prophet Muhammad (MPBUH) warns us that any human being will be asked about how he spent his time, how he spent his money; What he did with his wealth and his knowledge.
Abu Barzah (May Allah be pleased with him) reported:
Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said, "Man's feet will not move on the Day of Resurrection before he is asked about his life, how did he consume it, his knowledge, what did he do with it, his wealth, how did he earn it and how did he dispose of it, and about his body, how did he wear it out."
[At-Tirmidhi, who classified it as Hadith Hasan Sahih]. Riyad as-Salihin 407 : Reference
In-book reference	: Introduction, Hadith 407
In the following hadeeths, the prophet (PBUH) tells us about the sports and activities Allah like for you and will reward you for doing them:
It was narrated from ‘Uqbah bin ‘Amir Al-Juhani that the Prophet (ﷺ) said:
“Allah will admit three people to Paradise by virtue of one arrow: The one who makes it, seeking reward by making it well; the one who shoots it; and the one who hands it to him.” And the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: “Shoot and ride, and if you shoot that is dearer to me than if you ride. All things that a Muslim man does for entertainment are in vain except for shooting arrows, training his horse and playing with his wife, for these are things that bring reward.”
Sunan Ibn Majah 2811 : Reference
Book 24, Hadith 59 :	In-book reference
English translation	: Vol. 4, Book 24, Hadith 2811
Narrated Salama:
Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) passed by some people from the tribe of Aslam practicing archery. He said, "O children of Ishmael! Throw (arrows), for your father was an archer. I am on the side of Bani so-and so," meaning one of the two teams. The other team stopped throwing, whereupon the Prophet (ﷺ) said, "What has happened to them?" They replied, "How shall we throw while you are with Bani so-and so?" He said, "Throw for I am with all of you."
Al-Bukhary - Book 61, Hadith 17

chunks.question: And if I believe in Allah and abide by all the Islamic regulations, can you guarantee for me a happy and a peaceful life?
chunks.answer:
The pleasures and satisfaction of believing in Allah, recognizing the true way, accepting your fate and hoping for paradise are incomparable and unimaginable, but still, you will be subject to the universal law 'Testing". So, calamities and suffering are inevitable.
The good news is that you will be rewarded for these calamities and misfortunes if you show patience, perseverance and acceptance.
However, unbelievers are not rewarded for suffering in this life.
The evidence is in this Hadeeth:
Abu Sa'id and Abu Hurairah (May Allah be pleased with him) reported that the Prophet (ﷺ) said:
"Never a believer is stricken with a discomfort, an illness, an anxiety, a grief or mental worry or even the pricking of a thorn but Allah will expiate his sins on account of his patience".
[Al-Bukhari and Muslim].
Riyad as-Salihin 37 : Reference
In-book reference	: Introduction, Hadith 37

chunks.question: But some people encounter big calamities and misfortunes in this life. These misfortunes are too hard for them to bear. So, they feel desperate and may commit suicide. Does Islam offer any help for this kind of desperate people?
chunks.answer:
The true belief in Allah and his fate enables people to bear and adapt with misfortunes and calamities in this life. A Muslim's belief that this life is only a short one that is followed by a thorough accounting is satisfying. A Muslim’s belief that everything that happens to him in this life was destined by Allah 50 thousand years before the Earth and heavens were created render all its calamities and misfortunes acceptable.
Allah explain this concept in the following verses:
( 22 ) No disaster strikes upon the earth or among yourselves except that it is in a register before We bring it into being - indeed that, for Allah, is easy -
( 23 ) In order that you not despair over what has eluded you and not exult [in pride] over what He has given you. And Allah does not like everyone self-deluded and boastful -
Al Hadid – No. 57 – verses 22 – 23
In the following hadeeth prophet Muhammad (PBUH) promises Muslims with big rewards for their patience on the most minor troubles
Abu Sa'id and Abu Hurairah (May Allah be pleased with him) reported that the Prophet (ﷺ) said:
"Never a believer is stricken with a discomfort, an illness, an anxiety, a grief or mental worry or even the pricking of a thorn but Allah will expiate his sins on account of his patience".
[Al-Bukhari and Muslim]
Riyad as-Salihin – Book 1 – no. 37
Introduction, Hadith 37
In the following hadeeth prophet Muhammad PBUH instructs Muslims never to hope for death whatever was the troubles in which they are involved. Instead, he teaches Muslims a supplication to say in this case
Anas (b. Malik) reported Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) as saying. None of you should make a request for death because of the trouble in which he is involved, but if there is no other help to it, then say:
O Allah, keep me alive as long as there is goodness in life for me and bring death to me when there is goodness in death for me. Sahih Muslim - Book 48, Hadith 10

Al Hadid – No. 57 – verses 22 – 23

chunks.question: Why are some people in this world trying to find the true religion but they are not guided to Islam?
chunks.answer:
In order to be truly guided, one needs to get rid of his arrogance and to read and understand without pride or prejudice. If you do this, Allah will open your heart to righteousness. All hearts are controlled by Allah, the creator.
The following verse sheds light on this idea:
"( 125 ) So whoever Allah wants to guide - He expands his breast to [contain] Islam; and whoever He wants to misguide - He makes his breast tight and constricted as though he were climbing into the sky. Thus does Allah place defilement upon those who do not believe."
Al An'am– no. 6 – verse 125
Arrogance and sins and injustice are thick barriers against accepting Islam. Allah punishes arrogant, tyrant and unfair people by closing their hearts so that they will never accept the light of Islam. They will always be in darkness as a result of their behavior.
The following verse shows this meaning:
( 25 ) And among them are those who listen to you, but We have placed over their hearts coverings, lest they understand it, and in their ears deafness. And if they should see every sign, they will not believe in it. Even when they come to you arguing with you, those who disbelieve say, "This is not but legends of the former peoples." Al An'am– no. 6 – verse 25

chunks.question: Well, so a man should take care of himself only. No matter what other people believe or do?

No, it is our duty as Muslims to try to guide people to the right way. But, in the end, it is up to their discretion to believe or not.
The following verses explain this idea:
"( 17 ) O my son, establish prayer, enjoin what is right, forbid what is wrong, and be patient over what befalls you. Indeed, [all] that is of the matters [requiring] determination."
Luqman – no. 31 – verse 17
"( 110 ) You are the best nation produced [as an example] for mankind. You enjoin what is right and forbid what is wrong and believe in Allah. If only the People of the Scripture had believed, it would have been better for them. Among them are believers, but most of them are defiantly disobedient."

"( 164 ) And when a community among them said, "Why do you advise [or warn] a people whom Allah is [about] to destroy or to punish with a severe punishment?" they [the advisors] said, "To be absolved before your Lord and perhaps they may fear Him."

chunks.question: Some people in our age are very proud of the human mind, science and technology. These people assume that the human mind, Science and technology have the potential to control everything and overcome even death itself and make life much happier. What do you think?
chunks.answer:
Look around you. Do you think technology and advanced science have controlled anything or made life happier? Pandemics are still killing millions of people. Hurricanes of different kinds are still destroying whole cities and villages. Many diseases are still without a medicine. Doctors have managed to develop only painkillers not medicines.
Even the vaccines that were prepared to face dangerous diseases depend on the Immune System inside the human body to create and activate natural antibiotics for the disease.
Let them bring back the dead people. Let them save their beloved from old age or from death. Even, let them create “a fly” if they could. Allah challenged those we invoke beside Allah whether humans or idols to use all their powers and science altogether to create “a fly”, one of the beings we despise but they will never be able to
Listen to the verse that has the challenge:
( 73 ) O people, an example is presented, so listen to it. Indeed, those you invoke besides Allah will never create [as much as] a fly, even if they gathered together for that purpose. And if the fly
should steal away from them a [tiny] thing, they could not recover it from him. Weak are the pursuer and pursued.
( 74 ) They have not appraised Allah with true appraisal. Indeed, Allah is Powerful and Exalted in Might.
Al-Hajj- no. 22 – verse 73,74
To cut it short for you, ask yourself who created the human mind they are bragging about? And who created for them the elements inside the Earth that they are using to develop and invent. It is very obvious for any mindful man that everything is coming from Allah and everything is going to Him and everything is controlled by Him. And humanity is very vulnerable and helpless.

chunks.question: Which factors or circumstances -do you think- are most dangerous on my future as a Muslim if I convert?
chunks.answer:
Arrogance and vain are the most dangerous enemies to man. When he feels he is strong, intelligent or rich, he wants to understand everything with his mind. Here comes the fatal mistake. When he tries to explain everything using his mind, his mind fails him and he loses trust in his creator and becomes an atheist. This fatal mistake was done by millions before you. Try to avoid it. Keep your mind away from five areas. These are red lines for any human mind:
1.	Thinking about the Divine-self of the creator. This is beyond our limited mind. And it will surely lead to atheism. When Satan urges you to think about Allah's Divine self or what He look like or such questions remember this verse in Qur'an:
"There is nothing like unto Him, and He is the Hearing, the Seeing."
Ash-Shura– no. 42 – verse11
Also put this warning from prophet Muhammad into your consideration:
Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) said, "Satan comes to one of you and says, 'Who created so-and-so? 'Till he says, 'Who has created your Lord?' So, when he inspires such a question, one should seek refuge with Allah and give up such thoughts."
Sahih al-Bukhari - Book 59, Hadith 85
Always remember that Allah started everything and created everything. And nothing was there before Him. Always remember that you can know Allah from his creatures in this universe and from his innumerable blessings but not from thinking about his Divine Self which is beyond our minds. It is a very dangerous red-line. It will lead you to nothing. So, beware.
2.	Thinking about Allah's destiny: Why he did this? And why he made this in such a way? And why he ordered this…. etc. You will never understand Allah's wisdom. So, submit and trust to avoid atheism and be sure Allah will never be unjust with you or anyone else as he said in this verse:
"( 40 ) Indeed, Allah does not do injustice, [even] as much as an atom's weight; while if there is a good deed, He multiplies it and gives from Himself a great reward."
An Nisa – no. 4 – verse 40
3.	Thinking about the "unspecific" verses of Qur'an and insisting on understanding their explanations before you embrace Islam.
For example:
( 1 ) Alif, Lam, Meem"
Al Baqarah- no.2 – verse 1
And such separated letters at the beginning of some suras. And some other verses. This is very dangerous. Most probably, you will never understand their meanings. Only Allah know their real meanings. And maybe a minority of great scholars understand them. Allah has intended them to be a test for those who have little trust in their creator as Allah said in this verse:
"( 7 ) It is He who has sent down to you, [O Muhammad], the Book; in it are verses [that are] precise - they are the foundation of the Book - and others unspecific. As for those in whose hearts is deviation [from truth], they will follow that of it which is unspecific, seeking discord and seeking an interpretation [suitable to them].
And no one knows its [true] interpretation except Allah. But those firm in knowledge say, "We believe in it. All [of it] is from our Lord." And no one will be reminded except those of understanding."
Al 'Imran– no. 3 – verse 7
4.	Thinking about Allah's legislation: Why he wanted us to pray this number of prayers at these specific times? Why he wanted us to make Hajj in such a way and kiss a stone in Ka'baa? And why he wanted us to fast in Ramadan and stop eating and drinking for a specific time every day? Why he made this permissible? And why he made this impermissible? And hundreds of similar questions that arise to our minds. If you believe in Allah and that he is all-knowing and all-wise. Do not keep asking such questions. Only follow his orders. This is what we call "Iman" or "true belief" as we said before.
It is not bad to think about the wisdom behind a specific legislation. If you understand the wisdom behind some legislations, it is good. But, if you cannot understand and this will happen for sure, submit to your creator and say "We heard and we obeyed".
Definitely, your limited mind will never be able to understand the wisdom behind every legislation.
5.	Do not listen to hypocrites or false scholars: If you convert to Islam, you will always find Muslim hypocrites or ignorant thinkers who come on TV channels and speak against Islam and bring some Hadeeths or verses and try to show you that they are contradicted and that Islam is unfair for one reason or another. Do not listen to such ignorant hypocrites. And when you find something confusing in your religion, go to a true scholar and ask him. Do this either face to face or online. But never take your religion from ignorant hypocrites who sold their belief and religion in return for a few dollars on some TV channels.

chunks.question: If I remain unbeliever and never convert to Islam, how should a true Muslim deal with me as I am?
chunks.answer:
A true Muslim must not fight you or hurt you or kill you as long as you are peaceful and you don't hurt him or try to stop him from practicing his belief.
Everyone considers those who follow a different religion from his own "unbelievers”. So, yes, a true Muslim will call you “unbeliever” in
his religion as you call him “unbeliever” in your religion. But all your rights and safety will be guaranteed with all true Muslims.
The following verses explain my point of view:
( 1 ) Say, "O disbelievers,
( 2 ) I do not worship what you worship.
( 3 ) Nor are you worshippers of what I worship.
( 4 ) Nor will I be a worshipper of what you worship. ( 5 ) Nor will you be worshippers of what I worship.
( 6 ) For you is your religion, and for me is my religion."
Al Kafirun – No. 109 – verses 1 – 6
Prophet Muhammad (MPBUH) warned us and prohibited us from hurting or killing any one from “the protected people” from other religions as long as he is peaceful. If this is done, the perpetrator will never enter Paradise or even smell its fragrance.
Narrated `Abdullah bin `Amr:
The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "Whoever killed a Mu'ahid (a person who is granted the pledge of protection by the Muslims) shall not smell the fragrance of Paradise though its fragrance can be smelt at a distance of forty years (of traveling).
Sahih al-Bukhari 6914
Book 87, Hadith 52
USC-MSA web (English) reference	: Vol. 9, Book 83, Hadith 49
166 – But I saw some people who are considered by some media channels as public Muslim figures and thinkers. These people attack some famous Islamic books like Al-Bukhari fiercely and even disgust the pious and dedicated Muslims. How do you explain these practices?
As I told you before. If you find someone attacking Al-Bukhari or Muslim or such mother books in Sunnah, be sure he is a hypocrite who sold his religion with a bunch of dollars. And never listen to him.
Those people are probably hired by organizations or countries to attack Islam strongly and make the young generations skeptical about their belief.

chunks.question: But I saw some people who are presented by certain media channels as public Muslim figures or thinkers. These people fiercely attack famous Islamic books such as Sahih al-Bukhari and even show contempt toward pious and devoted Muslims. How can these practices be explained?
chunks.answer:
As mentioned previously, if a person openly attacks foundational books of the Sunnah such as Sahih al-Bukhari or Sahih Muslim, then this is a serious indication that he has deviated from the authentic teachings of Islam. Such individuals should not be trusted or followed.

Many of these figures are promoted by certain media outlets to create confusion and skepticism among Muslims, especially the younger generations, regarding their faith and its authentic sources. In many cases, these attacks are driven by personal interests, ideological agendas, or external influences rather than sincere scholarly concern.

Throughout Islamic history, the Sunnah and its major compilations have been preserved through rigorous scientific methodologies, including chains of narration, critical evaluation of narrators, and scholarly consensus. Attempts to discredit these sources are not new; rather, they are part of recurring efforts to weaken Islamic belief by undermining its primary references.

Therefore, Muslims are advised to rely on the Qur’an and the authentic Sunnah as understood and preserved by trustworthy scholars, and not to be misled by voices that attack Islam’s foundational texts under the guise of intellectual reform or free thinking.

chunks.type: Section G – Wrap-up of the previous sections and Questions about how to be a Muslim, how to prepare for this decisive change, how to face potential challenges, how to prepare for post-Islam life and final essential pieces of advice
chunks.question: Can you tell me a short piece of advice that you consider essential whether I convert or not?
chunks.answer:
One thing I want you to remember always:
-		You will be the only winner or the only loser by your belief or disbelief
-		Allah will never be harmed by your disbelief because He is the owner, the creator and the lord of everything. He is the one who give life and death and He is the one who give and deny everything in-between. Every tiny blessing with you is from Allah. You actually own nothing. And you can create nothing. So how can He be harmed by your disbelief?
-		Likewise, all the other people in this world will not be harmed by your disbelief. And they will not benefit anything from your belief because every one of them will be evaluated according to his own deeds.
The following verses manifest this concept plainly:
"( 7 )	If you disbelieve - indeed, Allah is Free from need of you. And He does not approve for His servants disbelief. And if you are grateful, He approves it for you; and no bearer of burdens will bear the burden of another. Then to your Lord is your return, and He will inform you about what you used to do. Indeed, He is Knowing of that within the breasts."
Az Zumar– no. 39 – verse 7
"( 170 ) O Mankind, the Messenger has come to you with the truth from your Lord, so believe; it is better for you. But if you disbelieve - then indeed, to Allah belongs whatever is in the heavens and earth. And ever is Allah Knowing and Wise."
An Nisa – no. 4 – verse 170
The following hadeeth is very important and relevant to your question. Note the part written in bold type carefully:
Abu Dharr reported Allah's Messenger (ﷺ) as saying that Allah, the Exalted and Glorious, said:
My servants, I have made oppression unlawful for Me and unlawful for you, so do not commit oppression against one another. My servants, all of you are liable to err except one whom I guide on the right path, so seek right guidance from Me so that I should direct you to the right path. O My servants, all of you are hungry (needy) except one whom I feed, so beg food from Me, so that I may give that to you. O My servants, all of you are naked (need clothes) except one whom I provide garments, so beg clothes from Me, so that I should clothe you. O My servants, you commit error night and day and I am there to pardon your sins, so beg pardon from Me so that I should grant you pardon. O My servants, you can neither do Me any harm nor can you do Me any good. O My servants, even if the first amongst you and the last amongst you and even the whole of human race of yours, and that of jinns even, become (equal in) God-conscious like the heart of a single person amongst you, nothing would add to My Power. O My servants, even if the first amongst you and the last amongst you and the whole human race of yours and that of the Jinns too in unison become the most wicked (all beating) like the heart of a single person, it would cause no loss to My Power. O My servants, even if the first amongst you and the last amongst you and the whole human race of yours and that of jinns also all stand in one plain ground and you ask Me and I confer upon every person what he asks for, it would not. in any way, cause any loss to Me (even less) than that which is caused to the ocean by dipping the needle in it. My servants, these for you I shall reward you for thern, so he who deeds of yours which I am recording finds good should praise Allah and he who does not find that should not blame anyone but his ownself. Sa'id said that when Abu Idris Khaulini narrated this hadith he knelt upon his knees.
Sahih Muslim 2577 a - Book 45, Hadith 70 - Book 32, Hadith 6246

chunks.question: Are you an Islamic scholar or a researcher? How did you know all this information about Islam? Anyway, I am thankful to your kindness. You have provided me with new information and new insight. I need to have some time to think over about what you said.
chunks.answer:
I am not a scholar or a researcher. I am an ordinary Muslim. But I have asked myself almost the same questions in the past and tried to find the answers in order to be convinced with my religion and to have a strong faith. I didn't want to be like millions of adherents of different religions who inherited their faith from their families, but they lack a lot of knowledge and a lot of true faith in this or that faith. I am not a scholar, but I learnt and read about my religion as every ordinary Muslim should do.
And you are most welcome. I also feel happy that I could answer your questions. I hope my answers can be helpful to you. I think it is the time for my flight. I wish you the best!

chunks.question: What if I come across other questions in the future? How can I obtain correct and accurate answers?
chunks.answer:
If you encounter additional questions in the future, there are several reliable ways to seek correct and accurate answers:

First, the primary and most authentic sources of guidance are the Qur’an and the Sunnah, as well as the explanations of these sources provided by the great and trustworthy Islamic scholars.

Second, you may benefit from the list of recommended books and websites that have been provided, which are known for their reliability and adherence to authentic Islamic teachings.

Third, you can learn from the scholars of Sunnah and consensus (Ahl al-Sunnah wa al-Jama‘ah). Although meeting them in person may not always be possible, their lectures, lessons, books, and recorded audio or video materials are widely available through the internet and various educational platforms.

Above all, you should continuously supplicate sincerely to your Creator, asking Him for guidance and steadfastness upon the truth, for Allah alone is the One who guides hearts to the right path.

chunks.question: What is Islam?
chunks.answer: The word "Islam" means peace and submission. Peace means to be at peace with yourself and your surroundings and submission means submission to the will of God. A broader meaning of the word "Islam" is to achieve peace by submitting to the will of God. This is a unique religion with a name which signifies a moral attitude and a way of life. Judaism takes its name from the tribe of Juda, Christianity from Jesus Christ, Buddhism from Goutam Buddha and Hinduism from Indus River. However, Muslims derive their identity from the message of Islam, rather than the person of Muhammed (Peace be upon him), thus should not be called "Muhammadans".

chunks.question: Who is Allah?
chunks.answer: Allah is the Arabic word for "one God". Allah is not God of Muslims only. He is God of all creations, because He is their Creator and Sustainer.

chunks.question: Does Allah look like us?
chunks.answer: No, Allah is perfect. He is not like any of His creations. A Muslim does not say a single thing about Allah other than what Allah says about Himself. Allah is Perfect and Unique.

chunks.question: What is the Kabah?
chunks.answer: The Kabah is the place of worship, which God commanded Abraham and Ishmael to build over four thousand years ago. The building was constructed of stone on what many believe was the original site of a sanctuary established by Adam. God commanded Abraham to summon all mankind to visit this place, and when pilgrims go there today they say 'At Thy service, O Lord', in response to Abraham's summons.

chunks.question: Who is a Muslim?
chunks.answer: The word "Muslim" means one who submits to the will of God. This is done by declaring that "there is no god except one God and Muhammad is the messenger of God." In a broader sense, anyone who willingly submits to the will of God is a Muslim. Thus, all the prophets preceding the prophet Muhammad are considered Muslims. The Quran specifically mentions Abraham who lived long before Moses and Christ that, "he was not a Jew or a Christian but a Muslim," because, he had submitted to the will of God. Thus there are Muslims who are not submitting at all to the will of God and there are Muslims who are doing their best to live an Islamic life. One cannot judge Islam by looking at those individuals who have a Muslim name but in their actions, they are not living or behaving as Muslims. The extent of being a Muslim can be according to the degree to which one is submitting to the will of God, in his beliefs and his actions.

chunks.question: Who was Muhammad?
chunks.answer: (Peace be upon him) In brief, Muhammad (Peace be upon him) was born in a noble tribe of Mecca in Arabia in the year 570 AD. His ancestry goes back to Prophet Ishmael (Peace be upon him), son of Prophet Abraham (Peace be upon him). His father died before his birth and his mother died when he was six. He did not attend a formal school since he was raised first by a nurse as it was the custom those days, and then by his grandfather and uncle. As a young man, he was known as a righteous person who used to meditate in a cave. At age 40, he was given the prophethood when the angel, Gabriel, appeared in the cave. Subsequently, the revelations came over 23 years and were compiled in the form of a book called the Quran which Muslims consider as the final and the last word of God. The Quran has been preserved, unchanged, in its original form and confirms the truth in the Torah, the psalms and the Gospel. (1)

chunks.question: How did Muhammad (peace be upon him) become a prophet and a messenger of God?
chunks.answer: At the age of 40, while engaged in a meditative retreat, Muhammad (peace be upon him) received his first revelation from God through the Angel Gabriel. This revelation, which continued for twenty- three years, is known as the Quran. As soon as he began to recite the words he heard from Gabriel, and to preach the truth that God had revealed to him, he and his small group of followers suffered bitter persecution, which grew so fierce that in the year 622 God gave them the command to emigrate. This event, the Hijrah, 'migration', in which they left Makkah for the city of Madinah some 260 miles to the north, marks the beginning of the Muslim calendar. After several years, the Prophet (peace be upon him) and his followers were able to return to Makkah, where they forgave their enemies and established Islam definitively. Before the Prophet (peace be upon him) died at the age of 63, the greater part of Arabia was Muslim, and within a century of his death Islam had spread to Spain in the West and as Far East as China.

chunks.question: Do Muslims worship Muhammad?
chunks.answer: (Peace be upon him) No. Muslims do not worship Muhammad (Peace be upon him) or any other prophets. Muslims believe in all prophets including Adam, Noah, Abraham, David, Solomon, Moses and Jesus. Muslims believe that Muhammad (Peace be upon him) was the last of the prophets. They believe that God alone is to be worshiped, not any human being. 1-Khan,The personality of Allah s last messenger , p (17- 34)

chunks.question: What is the Quran?
chunks.answer: The Quran is a record of the exact words revealed by God through the Angel Gabriel to the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). It was memorized by Muhammad (peace be upon him) and then dictated to his companions, and written down by scribes, who crosschecked it during his lifetime. Not one word of its 114 Surahs, has been changed over the centuries, so that the Quran is in every detail the unique and miraculous text which was revealed to Muhammad (peace be upon him) fourteen centuries ago.

chunks.question: What is the Quran about?
chunks.answer: The Quran, the last revealed Word of God, is the prime source of every Muslim's faith and practice. It deals with all the subjects which concern us as human beings: wisdom, doctrine, worship, and law, but its basic theme is the relationship between God and His creatures. At the same time, it provides guidelines for a just society, proper human conduct and an equitable economic system .

chunks.question: Are there any other sacred sources?
chunks.answer: Yes, the Sunnah, the practice and example of the Prophet (peace be upon him), is the second authority for Muslims. A Hadith is a reliably transmitted report of what the Prophet (peace be upon him) said, did, or approved. Belief in the Sunnah is part of the Islamic faith. Examples of the Prophet's sayings The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'God has no mercy on one who has no mercy for others.' 'None of you truly believes until he wishes for his brother what he wishes for himself.' 'Powerful is not he who knocks the other down, indeed powerful is he who controls himself in a fit of anger.' (From the Hadith collections of Bukhari, Muslim, Tirmidhi and Baihaqi.)

chunks.question: How do we know Islam is the truth?
chunks.answer: 1- It is the only religion that holds Allah as One, Unique, and Perfect. 2- It is the only religion that believes in the sole worship of Allah, not Jesus, not an idol, and not an angel, only Allah. 3- The Quran does not contain contradictions. 4- The Quran contains scientific facts, which are 1300 years ahead of their time. The Quran, while revealed 1400 years ago contains scientific facts, which are only now being discovered. It is not in contradiction to science. 5- Allah has challenged the world to produce the like of the Quran. And He says they won't be able to. 6- Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was the most influential man in history. In the book "The 100 most influential men in History", written by non- Muslim, the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was #1. Prophet Jesus (peace be upon him) was #3. It should be noted that even the Prophet Jesus (peace be upon him) was a prophet sent by Allah.

chunks.question: Does Islam tolerate other beliefs?
chunks.answer: The Qur an says: Allah does not forbid you with regards to those who do not fight you for [your] faith nor drive you out of your homes, from dealing kindly and justly with them; for Allah loves those who are just. (Qur an, 60:8) There is no compulsion in religion. (2:214) It is one of the functions of Islamic law to protect the privileged status of minorities, and this is why non- Muslim places of worship have flourished all over the Islamic world. History provides many examples of Muslim tolerance towards other faiths. For example, when the caliph Omar entered Jerusalem in the year 634, he granted amnesty to all and sanctioned freedom of worship to all religious communities in the city. Another example is Muslims who ruled the Spain had such tolerance of other beliefs that the Golden Age of Jewish Civilization flourished under the Muslim rule. Not only that, Islamic law permits non-Muslim minorities to set up their own courts thus allowing them the autonomy to be judged according to their family law.

chunks.question: Do Islam and Christianity have different origins?
chunks.answer: Together with Judaism, they go back to the prophet and patriarch Abraham, and their three prophets are directly descended from his sons-Muhammad (peace be upon him) from the eldest, Ishmael, and Moses and Jesus, from Isaac. Abraham established the settlement, which today is the city of Makkah, and built the Kabah towards which all Muslims turn when they pray.

chunks.question: What do Muslims think of Jesus?
chunks.answer: (Peace be upon him) Muslims think highly of Jesus (peace be upon him) and his worthy mother, Mary. The Quran tells us that Jesus was born of a miraculous birth without a father. "Lo! The likeness of Jesus with Allah is the likeness of Adam. He created him of dust, and then He said unto him: Be and he is" (Quran 3.59). He was given many miracles as a prophet. These include speaking soon after his birth in defense of his mother's piety. God's other gifts to him included healing the blind and the sick, reviving the dead, making a bird out of clay and most importantly, the message he was carrying. These miracles were given to him by God to establish him as a prophet. According to the Quran, he was not crucified but was raised into Heaven. (Quran, Chapter Maryam)

chunks.question: "How can you believe in God, when you can't see, hear, touch, smell, taste or even imagine what He is?
chunks.answer: " We know from the teachings of Muhammad, peace be upon him, that no one has ever actually seen God - at least not in this lifetime. Nor are we able to use our senses to make some kind of contact with Him. However, we are encouraged in Islam to use our senses and our common sense to recognize that all of this universe could not possibly come into existence on its own. Something had to design it all and then put it into motion. That is beyond our ability to do, yet it is something that we can understand. We don't have to see an artist to recognize a painting, correct? So, if we see paintings without seeing artists painting them, in the same way, we can believe that Allah created everything without having to see Him (or touch, or hear, etc.).(1)

chunks.question: What are the pillars of Islam?
chunks.answer: There are five major pillars of Islam which are the articles of faith. These pillars are 1) the belief (Iman) in one God and that Muhammad (P) is His messenger, 2) prayer (Salat) which are prescribed five times a day, 3) fasting (Siyam) which is required in the month of Ramadan, 4) charity (Zakat) which is the poor-due on the wealth of the rich and 5) hajj which is the pilgrimage to Mecca once in a lifetime if one can afford it physically and financially. All the pillars should be of equal height and strength in a building in order to give the building its due shape and proportions. It is not possible that one would do hajj without observing fasting or without practicing regular prayers. Now think of a building which has pillars only. It would not be called a building. In order to make it a building, it has to have a roof, it has to have walls, it has to have doors and windows. These things in Islam are the moral codes of Islam such as honesty, truthfulness, steadfastness and many other human moral qualities. Thus in order to be a Muslim, one should not only be practicing the pillars of Islam but should also have the highest possible attribute for being a good human being. Only then the building is completed and looks beautiful.

chunks.question: What is the purpose of worship in Islam?
chunks.answer: The purpose of worship in Islam is to be God conscious. Thus the worship, whether it is prayer, fasting, or charity, is a means to achieve God consciousness so that when one becomes conscious of God, in thought and in action, he is in a better position to receive His bounties both in this world and the hereafter.

chunks.question: Do Muslims believe in the hereafter?
chunks.answer: God is Just and manifest His justice, He established the system of accountability. Those who do good will be rewarded and those who do wrong will be punished accordingly. Thus, He created Heaven and Hell and there are admission criteria for both. Muslims believe that the present life is a temporary one. It is a test and if we pass the test, we will be given a life of permanent pleasure in the company of good people in Heaven.

chunks.question: Will the good actions of the non-believers be wasted?
chunks.answer: No. The Quran clearly says that, "anyone who has an atom's worth of goodness will see it and anyone who has done an atom's worth of evil will also see it" (Quran 99:7- 8). By that it is meant that those who are non- believers but have done good will be rewarded in this world for their good deed. On the other hand, those who do good if they are Muslims, they will be rewarded not only in this world but also in the world hereafter. However, the final Judgment is up to God himself. (Quran 2:62) 1-www:knowingallah.com

chunks.question: What is the dress code for Muslims?
chunks.answer: Islam emphasizes modesty. No person should be perceived as a sex object. There are certain guidelines both for men and women that their dress should neither be too thin nor too tight to reveal body forms. For men, they must at least cover the area from the knee to navel and for women, their dress should cover all areas except the hands and face.

chunks.question: What are the dietary prohibitions in Islam?
chunks.answer: Muslims are told in the Quran not to eat pork or pork products, meat of the animals who died before being slaughtered or the carnivorous animals (as they eat dead animals), nor drink blood or intoxicants such as wine or use any illicit drugs.

chunks.question: What is Jihad?
chunks.answer: The word "Jihad" means struggle, or to be specific, striving in the cause of God. Any struggle done in day-to-day life to please God can be considered Jihad. One of the highest levels of Jihad is to stand up to a tyrant and speak a word of truth. Control of the self from wrong doings is also a great Jihad. One of the forms of Jihad is to take up arms in defense of Islam or a Muslim country when Islam is attacked. This kind of Jihad has to be declared by the religious leadership or by a Muslim head of state who is following the Quran and Sunnah.

chunks.question: What is the Islamic Year?
chunks.answer: The Islamic year started from the migration (Hijra) of Prophet Muhammad (P) from Mecca to Medina in 622 AD. It is a lunar year of 354 days. The first month is called Muharram. 1996 AD is in Islamic year 1416 AH.

chunks.question: What are the major Islamic festivals?
chunks.answer: Idul Fitre, marks the end of fasting in the month of Ramadan and is celebrated with public prayers, feasts and exchange of gifts. Idul Adha marks the end of the Hajj or the annual pilgrimage to Mecca. After the public prayers, those who can afford, sacrifice a lamb or a goat to signify Prophet Abraham's obedience to God, shown by his readiness to sacrifice his son Ishmael.

chunks.question: What is Sharia?
chunks.answer: Sharia is the comprehensive Muslim law derived from two sources, a) the Quran b) the Sunnah or traditions of Prophet Muhammad (Peace be upon him). It covers every aspect of daily individual and collective living. The purpose of Islamic laws are protection of individuals' basic human rights to include right to life, property, political and religious freedom and safeguarding the rights of women and minorities. The low crime rate in Muslim societies is due to the application of the Islamic laws. (1) 1-www:Islamichotline.com

chunks.question: Was Islam spread by the sword?
chunks.answer: According to the Quran, "There is no compulsion in religion" (2:256), thus, no one can be forced to become a Muslim. While it is true that in many places where Muslim armies went to liberate people or the land, they did carry the sword as that was the weapon used at that time. However, Islam did not spread by the sword because in many places where there are Muslims now, in the Far East like Indonesia, in China, and many parts of Africa, there are no records of any Muslim armies going there. To say that Islam was spread by the sword would be to say that Christianity was spread by guns, F-16's and atomic bombs, etc., which is not true. Christianity spread by the missionary works of Christians. Ten- percent of all Arabs are Christians. The "Sword of Islam" could not convert all the non-Muslim minorities in Muslim countries. In India, where Muslims ruled for 700 years, they are still a minority. In the U.S.A., Islam is the fastest growing religion and has 6 million followers without any sword around.

chunks.question: Does Islam promote violence and terrorism?
chunks.answer: No. Islam is religion of peace and submission and stresses on the sanctity of human life. A verse in the Quran says, [Chapter 5, verse 32], that "anyone who saves one life, it is as if he has saved the whole of mankind and anyone who has killed another person (except in lieu of murder or mischief on earth) it is as if he has killed the whole of mankind." Islam condemns all the violence which happened in the Crusades, in Spain, in WW II, or by acts of people like the Rev. Jim Jones, David Koresh, Dr. Baruch Goldstein, or the atrocities committed in Bosnia by the Christian Serbs. Anyone who is doing violence is not practicing his religion at that time. However, sometimes violence is a human response of oppressed people as it happens in Palestine. Although this is wrong, they think of this as a way to get attention. There is a lot of terrorism and violence in areas where there is no Muslim presence. For example, in Ireland, South Africa, Latin America, and Sri Lanka. Sometimes the violence is due to a struggle between those who have with those who do not have, or between those who are oppressed with those who are oppressors. We need to find out why people become terrorists. Unfortunately, the Palestinians who are doing violence are called terrorists, but not the armed Israeli settlers when they do the same sometimes even against their own people. As it turned out to be in the Oklahoma City bombing, sometime Muslims are prematurely blamed even if the terrorism is committed by non-Muslims. Sometimes those who want Peace and those who oppose Peace can be of the same religion.

chunks.question: What is "Islamic Fundamentalism"?
chunks.answer: There is no concept of "Fundamentalism" in Islam. The western media has coined this term to brand those Muslims who wish to return to the basic fundamental principles of Islam and mould their lives accordingly. Islam is a religion of moderation and a practicing God fearing Muslim can neither be a fanatic nor an extremist.

chunks.question: Is Islamic marriage like Christian marriage?
chunks.answer: In Islam, marriage is one of the most sacred bonds that two humans can forge. In addition, a marriage in Islam is also practical involving legal agreement and contractual obligations which spouses mutually agreed upon. According to Islam, no Muslim girl or boy can be forced to marry against their will. Parents are to play a proactive and active role in suggesting potential spouses, but not to impose a decision upon their children.

chunks.question: Does Islam promote polygamy?
chunks.answer: No, polygamy in Islam is a permission not an injunction. Historically, all the prophets except Jesus, who was not married, had more than one wife. For Muslim men to have more than one wife is a permission which is given to them in the Quran, not to satisfy lust, but for the welfare of the widows and the orphans of the wars. In the pre-Islamic period, men used to have many wives. One person had 11 wives and when he became Muslim, he asked the Prophet Muhammad (Peace be upon him), "What should I do with so many wives?" and he said, "Divorce all except the four." The Quran says, "you can marry 2 or 3 and up to 4 women if you can be equally just with each of them" (4:3). Since it is very difficult to be equally just with all wives, in practice, most of the Muslim men do not have more than one wife. Prophet Muhammad (Peace be upon him) himself from age 24 to 50 was married to only one woman, Khadija. In the western society, some men who have one wife have many extramarital affairs. Thus, a survey was published in "U.S.A. Today" (April 4, 1988 Section D) which asked 4,700 mistresses what they would like their status to be. They said that "they preferred being a second wife rather than the 'other woman' because they did not have the legal rights, nor did they have the financial equality of the legally married wives, and it appeared that they were being used by these men."

chunks.question: Does Islam oppress women?
chunks.answer: No. On the contrary, Islam elevated the status of women 1,400 years ago by giving them the right to divorce, the right to have financial independence and support and the right to be identified as dignified women (Hijab) when in the rest of the world, including Europe, women had no such rights. Women are equal to men in all acts of piety (Quran 33:32). Islam allows women to keep their maiden name after marriage, their earned money and spend it as they wish, and ask men to be their protector as women on the street can be molested. Prophet Muhammad (Peace be upon him) told Muslim men, "the best among you is the one who is best to his family." Not Islam, but some Muslim men, do oppress women today. This is because of their cultural habits or their ignorance about their religion.

chunks.question: Is Islam intolerant of other religious minorities?
chunks.answer: Islam recognizes the rights of the minority. To ensure their welfare and safety, Muslim rulers initiated a tax (Jazia) on them. Prophet Muhammad (Peace be upon him) forbade Muslim armies to destroy churches and synagogues. Caliph Umer did not even allow them to pray inside a church. Jews were welcomed and flourished in Muslim Spain even when they were persecuted in the rest of Europe. They consider that part of their history as the Golden Era. In Muslim countries, Christians live in prosperity, hold government positions and attend their church. However, the same religious tolerance is not always available to Muslim minorities as seen in the past during Spanish inquisition and the crusades, or as seen now by the events in Bosnia, Israel and India. Muslims do recognize that sometimes the actions of a ruler does not reflect the teachings of his religion.

chunks.question: What is the Islamic view on- a. Dating and Premari...
chunks.answer: tal sex: Islam does not approve of intimate mixing of the sexes, and forbids premarital or extramarital sex.
