Islam encourages marriage as a shield to such temptations and as a means of having mutual love, mercy and peace. b. Abortion: Islam considers abortion as murder and does not permit it except to save the mother's life (Quran 17:23-31, 6:15 1). c. Homosexuality and AIDS: Islam categorically opposes homosexuality and considers it a sin. However, Muslim physicians are advised to care for AIDS patients with compassion just as they would for other patients. d. Euthanasia and Suicide: Islam is opposed to both suicide and euthanasia. Muslims do not believe in heroic measures to prolong the misery in a terminally ill patient. e. Organ transplantation: Islam stresses upon saving lives (Quran 5:32); thus, transplantation in general would be considered permissible in necessity provided a donor consent is available. The sale of the organ is not allowed.

chunks.question: How should Muslims treat Jews and Christians?
chunks.answer: The Quran calls them "People of the Book", i.e., those who received Divine scriptures before Muhammad (Peace be upon him) . Muslims are told to treat them with respect and justice and do not fight with them unless they initiate hostilities or ridicule their faith. The Muslims ultimate hope is that they all will join them in worshipping one God and submit to His will. "Say (O Muhammad): O people of the Book (Jews and Christians) come to an agreement between us and you, that we shall worship none but Allah, and that we shall take no partners with Him, and none of us shall take others for Lords beside Allah. And if they turn away, then say: Bear witness that we are those who have surrendered (unto Him)." (Quran 3:64) What about Hindus, Bahai, Buddhists and members of other religions? They should also be treated with love, respect, and understanding to make them recipients of Invitations to Islam.

chunks.question: How does Islam guarantee human rights?
chunks.answer: Freedom of conscience is laid down by the Qur an itself: There is no compulsion in religion . (2:256) The life and property of all citizens in an Islamic state are considered sacred whether a person is Muslim or not. O mankind! We created you from a single soul, male and female, and made you into nations and tribes, so that you may come to know one another. Truly, the most honored of you in Allah s sight is the greatest of you in piety. Allah is All-Knowing, All- Aware. (49:13)

chunks.question: Why is the family so important to Muslims?
chunks.answer: The family is the foundation of Islamic society. The peace and security offered by a stable family unit is greatly valued, and seen as essential for the spiritual growth of its members. A harmonious social order is created by the existence of extended families; children are treasured, and rarely leave home until the time they marry.

chunks.question: How do Muslims treat the elderly?
chunks.answer: In the Islamic world there are no old people s homes. The strain of caring for one s parents in this most difficult time of their lives is considered an honor and blessing, and an opportunity for great spiritual growth.

chunks.question: Who is your Rubb? (the Lord,the Creator etc).
chunks.answer: My Rubb is Allah Who has created me and all that exists. He nourishes me and all creatures by His Bounties.

chunks.question: What is your religion?
chunks.answer: My religion is Islam, which is submission and obedience to the Order oF Allah and His Messenger with love, hope and fear.

chunks.question: How did you know Allah?
chunks.answer: I know Him by His signs and creation like the day and night; the sun and the moon; the heaven and the earth, and all that is there in and between them.

chunks.question: Where is Allah?
chunks.answer: Allah is above the heavens raised over the Throne and separated from His creatures.

chunks.question: Is Allah with us (in person)?
chunks.answer: Allah is settled over His Mighty Throne, but He is with us by His Knowledge, hearing ,seeing and other attributes. As He said: "Fear not verily! I am with you both hearing and seeing (V,20. :46)

chunks.question: Who are the friends of Allah?
chunks.answer: Those people are the friends of Allah who are pious and righteous, fear Him much abstain from all kinds of sins and perform all kinds of goods, and holdfast to the Qur`an and Sunnah.

chunks.question: How do you worship Allah?
chunks.answer: I worship Allah in a manner in which all my ibadah is dedicated to Him Alone. I do not ascribe anyone with Him in worship.

chunks.question: Why did Allah send Messengers?
chunks.answer: Allah has sent Messengers so that they call the people to worship Him Alone, not ascribing any partner with Him, and in order that mankind should have no plea against Allah.

chunks.question: What is the meaning of Islam ?
chunks.answer: Islam means i.e. submission to Allah with Tawhid .

chunks.question: What are the pillars of Istam?
chunks.answer: 1. Testimony of Faith (There is no true God except Allah and Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah ) 2. To establish Salat (prayers). 3. To pay Zakat. 4. To observe Saum (fasting) in Ramadan. 5. Hajj (pilgrimage to the Sacred House) if one can afford the journey.

chunks.question: What is Iman?
chunks.answer: Iman (Faith) means to believe in the heart, to confess by the tongue and to act with the parts of the body.

chunks.question: Can there be any variation in Iman?
chunks.answer: By some words and deeds it may increase and by some words and deeds it may decrease.

chunks.question: What do you mean by increase and decrease in Iman?
chunks.answer: A- Iman (Faith) increases by obedience to Allah and good deeds while it decreases by sins and evil acts.

chunks.question: What are the pillars of Iman (Faith)
chunks.answer: The pillars of Iman are six i.e. to believe in: 1. Allah. 2. His Angels. 3. His Messengers. 4. His Books. 5. The Last Day. 6. Divine Preordainments good or bad.

chunks.question: What is Belief in Allah?
chunks.answer: The Belief in Allahi is that you should believe that Allah is the Sole Creator Sustainer Provider and the One in Whose Hand is the disposal of all affairs. Everything stands in need of Him, but He stands in need of none. He is the Only One Who is worthy of being worshipped. He has the Best Names and Perfect Attributes.

chunks.question: Who are the angels?
chunks.answer: The angels are creatures of light. They are Allah's obedient slaves, they do that which they are commanded and are incapable of disobedience.

chunks.question: What do you mean by Belief in the Book and the Messengers?
chunks.answer: It means that Allah sent the Messengers like Moses, Jesus,Abraham. Noah etc. and sent down the books like the Torah, Injeel, Zaboor (Psalms) etc. to call the people to worship Allah Alone, associating nothing with Him. He sealed (finalized) the Messengers with Prophet Muhammed and abrogated all previous books with the Qur'an. Therefore the worship should be done according to the Qur'an and the Sunnah of the Prophet .

chunks.question: What is meant by Belief in the Last Day?
chunks.answer: The Belief in the Last Day means to believe that Allah has ordained a fixed term for everything, and a term for this world. He will assuredly raise the dead from their graves and will account for everyone their deeds in this world. On that Day of Resurrection, rewards and punishments will be assigned. Every one will be justly rewarded or punished.

chunks.question: What is meant by Belief Preordainment (Qadar)?
chunks.answer: The Belief in Preordainment (Qadar) means to believe that everything — good or bad — happens or takes place according to what Allah has ordained for it. He has created everything in due proportion.

chunks.question: What is the cleaning of "There is no God but Allah"?
chunks.answer: It means there is no true deity except Allah Alone, Negating all false gods and affirming that Allah is the only true God.

chunks.question: What is the meaning of ^Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah"?
chunks.answer: It means total submission to him in whatever he ordered, and avoiding what he forbade and believing in all those matters he informed us about.

chunks.question: What are the conditions of the testimony of Faith?
chunks.answer: There are seven conditions of the testimony of Faith: 1- Knowledge whick negates ignorance. 2- Certainty which negates doubt. 3- Sincerity and purity of intent which negates Shirk. 4- Truthfulness which negates hypocrisy. 5- Love and devotion which negates disdain of Allah`s religion. 6- Submission which negates disobedince. 7- Acceptance which negates rejection or denial.

chunks.question: What is the greatest thing that Allah has enjoined?
chunks.answer: The greatest thing Allah has enjoined is Tauhid (Monotheism).

chunks.question: What is Tauhid (Islamic Monotheism)?
chunks.answer: Tauhid means declaring Allah to be the only God who deserves to be worshipped in truth and confirming all attributes with which He has qualified Himself or that are attributed to Him by His Messenger .

chunks.question: What are the aspects of Tauhid?
chunks.answer: There are three aspects of Tauhid: 1- Tauhid-ar-Rububiyah. 2- Tauhid-al-Uluhiyah. 3-Tauhid-al-Asma was-Sifat.

chunks.question: What isTauhid-ar-Rububiyah?
chunks.answer: It is declaring Allah to be One and Unique in His work, Iike creation, sustenance, bringing to life and causing death etc.

chunks.question: What is Tauhid-al-Uluhiyah?
chunks.answer: It is declaring Allah as the Only God to whom all acts worship must be dedicated such salat (prayers), Zakat, Sawm(fasting), supplications vowing etc.

chunks.question: What isTauhid-al-Asma was-Sifat?
chunks.answer: It is an affirmation of all the Divien Names and Attributes of Allah in a manner that suits His Majesty, as mentioned in the Qur'an and the Sunnah.

chunks.question: How would you describe Ibadah?
chunks.answer: It is a comprehensive word comprising deeds and words that Allah loves and is pleased with whether manifested or hidden,

chunks.question: What are the conditions of Ibadah?
chunks.answer: There are two conditions of Ibadah: 1. Sincerity to Allah. 2. Submission to Allah's Messenger i.e. to act according to his Sunnah.

chunks.question: Write some types of Ibadah.
chunks.answer: Some types of Ibadah are the prayers, the obligatory charity, fasting, the pilgrimage, fear of Allah, hope in His Mercy, Seeking His aid. and other acts of worship which Allah has commanded and enjoined.

chunks.question: What is the greatest thing Allah has forbidden?
chunks.answer: The greatest thing Allah has forbidden is Shirk (polytheism).

chunks.question: What is polytheism?
chunks.answer: It means to believe that there is one who shares Allah in His acts i.e. ascribing partners or setting up rivals to Allah in His rights.

chunks.question: What are the types of polytheism?
chunks.answer: There are three types of polytheism: 1. The greater polytheism (Shirk Akbar). 2. The lesser polytheism (Shirk Asghar). 3. The inconspicuous polytheism (Shirk Khafi).

chunks.question: What is greater polytheism?
chunks.answer: The greater polytheism is to devote any form of worship to other than Allah Allah will never forgive one who dies upon Shirk,nor accept his good deeds, and he would be cast out from the folds of Islam.

chunks.question: What are the types of greater polytheism?
chunks.answer: There are four types of greater polytheism: 1- The polytheism in invocation i.e. involving supplications to other than Allah. 2. The polytheism in intentions i.e. purpose and intentions not for the sake of Allah but directed towards other deities. 3, The polytheism in obedience i.e. rendering obedience to any authority against the Order of Allah. 4. The potytheism in love i.e showing love to others which is due to Allah Alone.

chunks.question: What is lesser polytheism?
chunks.answer: The lesser polytheism is Ar-Riya, that means the acts of worship done to gain praise or fame rather than to please Allah, this type of polytheism, however, does not cast the person committing it out of the fold of Islam.

chunks.question: What is inconspicuous polytheism?
chunks.answer: The inconspicuous polytheism implies being dissatisfied with the conditions ordained by Allah.

chunks.question: What is the proof of the inconspicuous polytheism?
chunks.answer: The proof of the above Shirk is the saying of the Prophet "The inconspicuous polytheism is more hidden among this nation than the track of a black ant over a black stone on a dark night" (Musnad Ahmad)

chunks.question: What are the types of Kufr (disbelief)?
chunks.answer: There are two types of Kufr : 1. The majorKufr which cast its people out of Islam, 2. The lessor cr minor Kufr which does not cast the one who commits it out of Islam. It is Kufr of ungratefulness.

chunks.question: What are the types of major Kufr?
chunks.answer: There are five types of major Kufr : 1. The Kufr of denial. 2. The Kufr of arrogance associated with recognition of the truth. 3. The Kufr of doubt. 4-. The Kufr of disregard, 5. The Kufr of hypocrisy.

chunks.question: What are the categories of hypocrisy ?
chunks.answer: There are two categories of hypocrisy: 1. Hypocrisy in Belief. 2. Hypocrisy in deeds and actions.

chunks.question: What is the hypocrisy in Belief?
chunks.answer: Hypocrisy in Belief is of six types: 1. Denial of the Messenger . 2. Denial of the thing with which the Messenger is sent. 3. Hating the Messenger 4.Hating the thing with which the Messenger is sent. 5. Rejoicing at the disgrace of Islam. 6. Disliking the prevalence of Islam.

chunks.question: What is the hypocrisy in deeds and actions?
chunks.answer: The hypocrisy in deeds and actions is of five types: 1- When he speaks, he lies. 2- When he promises., he breaks it. 3. When he is entrusted, he betrays. 4. When he disputes, he acts immorally. 5. When he makes a pact, he makes acts treacherously.

chunks.question: Are good deeds accepted (by Allah) with the polytheism?
chunks.answer: Never! None of the deeds are accepted when mixed with polytheism. Allah says: " If they had joined in worship others with Allah all that they used to do would have been of no benefit to them" (V.6: 88) "Verily! Allah forgives not setting up partners in worship with Him, but He forgives whom He pleases sins other than that" '(V.4:116)

chunks.question: What are the nullifiers of Islam?
chunks.answer: The nullifiers of Islam are ten: 1. Polytheism of worship. 2. He who does not believe that the polytheists are disbelievers, or doubts their infidelity or holds their belief to be valid. 3. He who sets up intermediaries between one's self and Allah, supplicating them, trusting them and asking them to intercede on his behalf. 4. He who believes that the guidance of others is more perfect than the Prophet . 5. He who hates anything that the Prophet was sent with. 6. He who denies the religion of the Prophet or ridicules its reward or punishment. 7. Sorcery. 8. Supporting the polytheists against the Muslims. 9. He who believes that some people are exempted from abiding by the Shari`ah as Khidr was exempted by the laws of Musa. 10. Turning away from the religion of Allah by neither learning nor applying it.

chunks.question: What are the three fundamentals that every Muslim must learn?
chunks.answer: The three fundamentals are: I, Knowing Your Rubb (the Lord, the Creator, the Sustainer, and the One in Whose Hand is the disposal of all affairs). 2. Knowing your religion (Islam). 3. Knowing your Prophet Muhammad

chunks.question: What is Taghut?
chunks.answer: Everything that is worshipped. or followed or obeyed other than Allah is Taghut.

chunks.question: How many Taghut are there and who are their leaders?
chunks.answer: They are many but their leaders are Five:

chunks.question: Who are the leaders of Taghut ?
chunks.answer: They are: 1. Satan, may Allah curse him, 2. Anyone who is worshipped with his consent. 3. A person who calls the people to be worshipped instead of Allah. 4. A person who claims the knowledge of Ghaib (unseen, hidden, invisible, absent etc). 5.The ruler who rules by laws other than the law sent down by Allah.

chunks.question: How can we prove the existence of the Creator?
chunks.answer: The innate mental principle (Indication of the Creator by the creation) was approved by the Quran and cognitive and faith meanings, have been based upon it, necessitating the Oneness of Allah Blessed and exalted. God Almighty said: (O humanity! Be mindful of your Lord Who created you from a single soul, and from it He created its mate,1 and through both He spread countless men and women. And be mindful of Allah—in Whose Name you appeal to one another—and ˹honor˺ family ties. Surely Allah is ever Watchful over you.) [An-Nisa: 1] He says: ((Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and the earth and the alternation of the day and night there are signs for people of reason.(190) ˹They are˺ those who remember Allah while standing, sitting, and lying on their sides, and reflect on the creation of the heavens and the earth ˹and pray˺, “Our Lord! You have not created ˹all of˺ this without purpose. Glory be to You! Protect us from the torment of the Fire. (191)) [Al-Imran: 190-191] You find great emphasis that in contemplating Allah's creation leads to the knowledge of God and the truth of what the prophets brought of a promising punishment to the unbelievers. And because creation is the clearest indication of God and the most prominent proof of His lordship, the prophets (peace be upon them) taught the people about their Lord through the (evidence) of the creation. For example, here is Abraham, peace be upon him, teaching his people of God, he said: ((He replied, “In fact, your Lord is the Lord of the heavens and the earth, Who created them ˹both˺. And to that I bear witness.”)) [Surah Al-Anbiya: 56] And this is Moses, peace be upon him, answering the question of Pharaoh (He answered, “Our Lord is the One Who has given everything its ˹distinctive˺ form, then guided ˹it˺.”) [Surah Taha: 50] It appears from all of the above: that creatures indicate their Creator, and call for faith in Him and His oneness, lordship, divinity and perfection of His attributes, and that the Quran determines this issue best and confirms it with the clearest confirmation. Inference of creation about the Creator is a legal and valid method and also a correct mentality: 1) It is legitimately correct; because the Quran has shown it, directed and guided people to it. 2) It is intellectually correct; because of the fact that a person was brought into (after he was nothing), and created from sperm and then from a leech. People didn’t know this from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), but they found this out with their minds, whether the Prophet told them or not. So, what is meant here: is to show that knowledge is a way to lead to faith in God the Creator.

chunks.question: Can you prove the existence of God with other evidence?
chunks.answer: The evidence is abundant, and we mention some of them: First evidence: The evidence of origination (bringing into existence), and its meaning: That everything that is Muhdath (brought into being after it did not exist) must have a producer, a Moojid (originator), so everything that is brought into existence is direct evidence of the originator. For example: Let's look at Google. There must be an internet to use Google, in order for there to be internet we need our computer, phones or tablets, and for the computer, well, someone had to build it, and there are things that depend on electricity. The next question is Google depends on the Internet, the Internet depends on the computer, the computer depends on us and electricity. The process goes on and on. We can't have infinite dependent things. There's a place where it must stop so it can be logical, and that is the necessary and self-sufficient independent being who is God. Second evidence: The evidence of tendency (and attention), which is that everything in existence carries a degree of functional complexity, i.e. performs a specialized function and a specific task, and functional complexity is a guide to making and bringing into existence. So there must be an originator. For example: A light bulb consists of: a lamp filament, a lead wire that conducts electricity to the filament, inert gas which protects the wick and doesn’t interact with the electricity, and glass which prevents air entering or inert gas from exiting, otherwise the wick would have burned. And the lamp base that connects the bulb to the rotary and forms a path of electric current. Here the light bulb is a system of complexity that cannot be simplified, and therefore has a primary mental (logical) significance which gives meaning to a mastered manufacture (production) which denies the elaborate workmanship of the lamp or assumes its appearance by chance is the one who demands evidence of this.

chunks.question: Why isn't the necessary being the universe?
chunks.answer: Well it's good that you said that, because it first shows that you acknowledge that we need to have a necessary. This applies to the universe and we say that this contradicts our saying that it is a necessary being because it has to be an independent, self-sufficient and necessary being, the universe is not self-sufficient and not self-reliant, on the contrary, it means it cannot be, because it contradicts what we said.

chunks.question: Can't there be more than one Creator?
chunks.answer: No, because then we return to the question of the necessary object. If there is more than one Creator, the question is how can you have one necessary self-sufficient and independent being if there is another God, then he is a follower and not necessary. So the question is: If there were two Creators first, God, the Almighty, says in the Quran: (Had there been other gods besides Allah in the heavens or the earth, both ˹realms˺ would have surely been corrupted. So Glorified is Allah, Lord of the Throne, far above what they claim.) [Al-Anbiya: 22] That is, they will fight each other for power, that is, the two forces will fight each other because they are subordinate and not independent, because it needs more power to kill the other, which is why we believe that there must be one necessary being who is self-sufficient, independent and necessary.

chunks.question: God created everything, so who created God?
chunks.answer: This question is wrong, it is a question that should not be asked, because now I have made God a creature, and a creator in the same sentence. If there is a God who created him, the god will become a follower who is no longer self-sufficient. What we are saying is that this creator as long as necessary everything else stops.

chunks.question: Can God create a rock that He cannot lift?
chunks.answer: This is a wrong question that cannot originally be asked as a correct one. Can I ask a question? Can God cease to exist? Absolutely not, this is a contradiction, it is like asking how many days are in a week? Yes or no? It is not a yes or no question, how many days are in a week? Seven. So your question is wrong in itself, so to ask can God create a rock of this size and not lift it? This means that the moment he created this rock he became weak (unstrong) because he could not carry it and there is no such thing, as this is a question that does not make sense. These questions that pertain to God's creation, such as: Can God create a rock that He cannot lift? Can God cease to exist? These questions cannot be asked because they are corrupt questions.

chunks.question: God doesn't need us, so why did He create us?
chunks.answer: The idea that needfulness (necessity) means frivolity is absurd! Needfulness is matched with wisdom, not absurdity. For example: A wealthy doctor with a good reputation may treat people without needing anything from them, but he treats them for their own benefit and here we do not describe his act as absurd! The wisdom and the great purpose behind the action do not revolve in the cycle of need nor in vain! A swimmer may save a child with mercy and then leave him and go without waiting for the praise of the child's parents. And here his act is not classified as a need or in vain, but is a generous act and a noble purpose and a good creation, so there is no correlation between needfulness and absurdity! And the patient's ignorance of the doctor's wisdom does not mean that the doctor's decisions are absurd. Knowledge of divine wisdom does not require an understanding of all dimensions of wisdom, but it is sufficient to understand some of them! It is enough to know that we are entrusted, the requirements of this entrustment, and to know the existence of this Divine wisdom, so this is enough for us, otherwise we are like the one who disbelieves in what he does not understand. The Almighty said: (In fact, they ˹hastily˺ rejected the Book without comprehending it and before the fulfillment of its warnings. Similarly, those before them were in denial. See then what was the end of the wrongdoers!) [Yunus: 39] So God is wise and created us for a wise reason - Glory be to Him - God is in no need of anyone. Our endeavor, effort and work are only for ourselves. The Almighty said: (And whoever strives ˹in Allah’s cause˺, only does so for their own good. Surely Allah is not in need of ˹any of˺ His creation) [ Al-Ankabut: 6] As submission to God is the opposite of submission (slavery) in our concept. Slavery (submission) in our concept is that the master takes the good from the slave, but slavery to God is the exact opposite, which is that the master gives the slave a lot of bliss. When God says, (I have not created the Jinn and mankind except to worship me) it means that I did not create the jinn and mankind except to give them love, goodness, dignity and pride. God does not need our worship, rather we are the ones who need this worship, honor, talents and goods that have no limits. God the Generous allowed us to enter (knock at his door) anytime without an appointment.

chunks.question: Why does God need to test us?
chunks.answer: God is not in need of anything - He does not need to create anything and does not need to test anyone. He does not benefit from our belief and is not affected by our disbelief. Rather, it is part of His infinite wisdom that He created us and gave us the opportunity to know Him. God knows the future - the point is, for us to live through and experience our lives and make our own choices.

chunks.question: Why is it that we are not brought about by evolution?
chunks.answer: For many reasons, including: 1) There is not a single evidence of evolution. 2) Where did the unicellular organism from which other life forms evolved according to Darwin's theory came from? 3) Why hasn’t any form of development been observed? We haven't seen a monkey turn into a human. And why didn't man evolve into a stronger being? 4) The discovery of DNA (amino acids) completely eliminated this theory. 5- The theory of evolution is just a hypothetical theory that has no laboratory experiments, observations or scientific facts.

chunks.question: Why is the source of the universe not by chance?
chunks.answer: Who says that this universe was created by chance amongst the tail-tellers who have completely or almost lost their minds. If I told you that six monkeys sat on typewriters, and kept hitting the letters, and accidentally brought us a beautiful poem or an interesting novel, would you believe?? If you don't believe that, why do you believe that this universe that God created came as a result of chance?? الصدفة العظيمة An amazing coincidence

chunks.question: So is the Big Bang theory correct?
chunks.answer: If the universe arose from a great explosion (Big Bang) - if proven - it still does not preclude in any way the existence of a masterminded creator who ordered this explosion (assuming the validity of the theory), for the explicit mind assures that there is nothing made, except that it has a maker, and there is no trace (like the Big Bang) without there being an effector in it that created it.

chunks.question: Why can’t we see Allah so we may believe in Him?
chunks.answer: We use our logic, and our minds. Science deals with the five senses of what you can see through experimentation so what we say is very simple. There are scientists who believe in things also. If you say, for example, I don't see God and so I don't believe in Him, you know, this is not something scientific. Science does not talk about the supernatural, science depends on experiment. But we know, for example, scientists recently discovered dark matter, which is something they cannot see, touch, feel, smell, or hear, and the same applies to God, can you see God? No. Can you touch God? No. Can you smell God? No. Do you hear God? No. Can you see God? No, but you reject its existence. But the same thing with dark matter and yet you believe in its existence, what kind of contradiction is this? God does not exist because I cannot touch or feel Him but dark matter exists, this is a contradiction. You know, there were people who believed in God, and these were scientists, you know, like Einstein, you know, he believed in a higher power. So this matter of science or scientists with (the belief of) God, contains no contradiction. There can be Muslim or Christian scientists, yes, this is not a discovery. We know from the teachings of Muhammad, peace be upon him, that no one has ever actually seen God- at least not in this lifetime. Nor are we able to use our senses to make some kind of contact with Him. However, we are encouraged in Islam to use our senses and our common sense to recognize that all of this universe could not possibly come into existence on its own. Someone had to design it all. and then put it into motion. That is beyond our ability to do, yet it is something that we can understand. We don't have to see an artist to recognize a painting, correct? So, if we see paintings without seeing artists painting them, in the same way, we can believe that Allah created everything without having to see Him (or touch, or hear, etc.).(1)

chunks.question: Why did God create evil?
chunks.answer: Looking at the ocean will reveal that good in the universe is the rule and evil is the exception, health is the rule, disease is the exception, and we spend most of our lives in health and get sick for only a few days. Similarly, earthquakes are mostly a few minutes in life on earth, which is counted in millions of years, as well as volcanoes, as well as wars which are short disturbances in the life of nations between long periods of peace, and then we see some good in all of that, the disease gives the body immunity and pain educates man on hardness and endurance, and earthquakes are an alternative to pressure inside the globe and protect the earth's crust from explosion and return mountains to their places and volcanoes take out minerals and riches from the belly of earth and make the soil of the earth fertile, and wars make nations come together in the form of alliances and the greatest inventions came out during atomic wars. Missiles and jets all was a result of wars, and from the venom of the snake comes medicine, and from the microbe we make the vaccine. Evil is the test by which we know ourselves, which is the affliction that determines our grades with God, and the whole world is one chapter of a novel that will abound in chapters. Death is not the end of the story, but its beginning, and it is not permissible to judge a play from one chapter nor to reject a book because the first page wasn’t to our liking. The judgment here is incomplete and complete wisdom can only be known in the end. Then what alternative does the questioner who mocks us imagine? Does he want to live a life without death, without disease, without old age, without deficiency, without helplessness, without limitations, without sorrows and without pain, does he ask for absolute perfection, he asks as he pleases, perfection belongs to God alone. And evil is something that is normal within divine obligation! It is surprising that the existence of evil is the greatest proof of the validity of the religious cause, and of the error of atheism. For if we were children of the material world, we would not grasp neither good nor evil, because according to the vision of atheism, we walk in strict material imperatives. Understanding evil means that we are not children of this world, and that we derive our understanding of the existence of evil. From an introduction other than the Darwinian materialistic introduction to existence! And not realizing some of the subtleties of the divine wisdom in the matter of affliction – not evil because there isn't pure evil in existence.

chunks.question: Do People Need Revelation (Religion)?
chunks.answer: Humanity needs revelation as it announces the existence of God and His Oneness. It also clarifies His nature (who He is) and provides us with a guide on how to live our lives. Take this simple example: Every time you buy an electronic or electrical device, what do you find in the box? A user manual! This manual shows you how to use the device correctly, includes warnings, dos and don'ts, recommendations, and more. Religion is the answer to the most important questions that concern humans. It answers every existential question (such as: Why am I here? What happens after death?). Religion is a correction of human beliefs. It is a return to the monotheism that all prophets called for. Today, Muslims are the only ones on earth who adhere to this monotheism. Moreover, even the fiercest atheist believes that truth is better than lies, right? The fiercest atheist believes that honesty is better than betrayal, right? These are concepts that do not originate from this material world, and nothing in the material world justifies their meaning. What is the meaning of honesty? What is the meaning of lying? If we analyze the depths of the atom, will we find meanings such as honesty or lying? These are terms that do not belong to this material world, but they are real concepts. In fact, they are the most important things in existence. The value of a human lies in their morals, not in their physical size, the number of their atoms, or the energy levels of their cells. The value of a human is in the divine obligation within them. There is a good person and a corrupt person. But there is no good mountain or corrupt mountain. We do not observe an honest planet or a traitorous planet. Humans alone embody value, purpose, and the meaning of existence. Humans alone are capable of comprehending existence. The Quran, which is the final revelation from God, is an instructional guide for humanity. It contains life lessons, such as saving lives, being kind to neighbors, giving to charity, avoiding intoxicants, refraining from gambling, not lying, and much more. It also includes wisdom, morals, lessons, history, stories, and so much more.

chunks.question: What is wrong with morals being a product of the brain or a society?
chunks.answer: The brain is made up of exactly the same physical components! No matter how complex the brain is or the complexity of the physical structures, the sum of zeros will only produce zero. No matter how many zeros are inflated or superimposed on top of each other. If matter knows neither good nor evil, so does the brain! Here's the question: How did the concept of good and evil get to the brain? What is the cerebral objection from exterminating all the people of the earth? What is the cerebral objection from introducing lower human races into animal cages? These questions are not answered by the physical brain by error or correction. The brain is completely morally neutral. Because it is composed of the same atoms as the earth. The brain has nothing to do with morality. Whereas the idea that society is the origin of morality is strange, because morality is subjective, and because it means man as a human being and not society as a society. If this were true, and we consider morality to be the product of society, the Nazis would be right in exterminating others because society sees that. It is therefore true that morality is independent of society. Right is right no matter if it’s a good or bad society. And wrong in wrong no it it’s a good or bad society. So morality has a meaning that goes beyond the brain and society.

chunks.question: Why is Muhammad not the inventor of Islam?
chunks.answer: How can you prove the truth of Muhammad? Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) is true and means that he is truly the Prophet of Allah, the Quran is the word of Allah, resurrection is true, the angels are true, Paradise and Hell are true. As for a liar and not just an ordinary liar, but one who is used to lying, he has slandered Allah. (God forbid) We will know this from his conducts and actions, as these actions provide us with an explanation of why he claimed prophecy, if he was called to Islam? For example: 1) Standing alone when his followers were defeated in (the battle of) Hunayn, facing the enemies, saying: “I am the Prophet, not lying! I am the son of Abdul Muttalib!” This is an act that can never be issued by a liar! It is only the honest who has reached the highest levels of certainty or a madman who has reached the highest level of madness and irrationality! Muhammad, as we know from his biography and history, cannot be described as insane, reckless or light-minded at all. 2) Also, when his son Abraham died and the sun was eclipsed and people thought that it was eclipsed in sorrow over the death of Abraham, it was better for the liar claiming prophecy to seize the opportunity or at least to be silent until he confirms with his silence what people thought of the solar eclipse for the death of his son, but contrary to all this, he came out to them saying: “The sun and the moon are two of the signs of God that are not eclipsed for anyone's death or life!” What is the explanation for this strange behavior? 3) Also in the prediction of the unseen that you find in the near prophecy which mentions the time, as in the predominance of the Romans over the Persians (in a few years), but in the distant prophecy it does not mention the date as in the rise of the hour, while the liar will do the opposite. He wouldn’t involve himself in giving a date for the occurrence of the near prophecy, but rather escape from it when necessary. Whereas he can easily give an accurate date for the distant prophecy that will occur after his death because it will not harm him at the time. Why did Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allaah be upon him) behave in this way? 4) These things and others like them in the biography of Muhammad must come out with a coherent interpretation, i.e. there is no contradiction! It is not correct to adopt a theory where all the facts, events, actions and words are unexplainable. But it must have the full and undiminished explanatory ability. If you say that he is a liar, for example, you must be able to interpret all his words and actions in the light of this interpretation. 5) It means, for example, in the hadith: The Messenger of Allah (may Allah's peace and blessings be upon him) never ate at a low table or from a small bowl, and that thin bread was not baked for him. Does this seem like a person who seeks the world and its goods or vice versa? 6) He slept on mats until it affected his side, and when the companions offered him another mattress, he refused, and when a woman from the Ansar sent him a mattress stuffed with wool, he ordered Aisha to return it to her. 7) And he used to stand at night until his feet were swollen from the length of the standing. How do these behaviors come from a person who seeks the world or has worldly goals? 8) They offered him money, prestige, women and power so that he would let the prophecy and the message while he was in Mecca weak and with few followers, but he declined and refused until it was reported that he said “If they put the sun on my right and the moon on my left, to leave this matter, I would not leave it!” 9) He endured insults for the sake of his cause and his message that many people cannot bear. Like when they threw the abdominal parts of a slaughtered she-camel on his back while praying at the Kaaba, and he was even chased by children with stones until blood flowed from his feet in Ta’if. And he is honorable among his people and has an impeccable reputation and has merchandise which enriches him for life, so what threw him in these difficulties? And what makes him accept these insults? He gave me a coherent explanatory theory cognitively, this is what is needed. A theory, capable of explaining all these words, deeds and facts. In experimental science, when observing a set of observations, scientists compete to explain them and develop appropriate theories that explain them and explain why they occurred in this way. Here in this regard, we hope to follow the same scientific path, collect all words, deeds and events and then present the correct theory capable of interpreting and explaining them without cost or intransigence. 10) What is the interpretation of what happened from the contemporary Arabs to the Prophet (peace be upon him) when he challenged them with the Quran, so they were unable to meet the challenge and resorted to fighting and fighting it, and for that they endured the destruction of livers, the captivity of women and the orphanage of children. If these people were able to meet the challenge and refute the Quran, they would not have moved from the easiest solution to the most difficult solution, and they would not have had to war, fight and fight with the sword and endure for this what they cannot bear. What is the explanation for this inability of them and their failure to meet the challenge? If the Quran was a book written by Muhammad and the Arabs could oppose it, why did it not do it, meet the challenge and destroy the myth of Muhammad instead of war, fighting, the destruction of souls and the loss of money? It's really amazing!!

chunks.question: What is the problem if I just believe in God and don’t follow the Apostles?
chunks.answer: How can you believe in Him and not believe His Apostles? You’re dismissing Allah’s commands, and you do not know his power, so what is the difference between you and the disbeliever? This is a crime and a great sin explained by the Holy Quran. Almighty said: (Surely those who deny Allah and His messengers and wish to make a distinction between Allah and His messengers, saying, “We believe in some and disbelieve in others,” desiring to forge a compromise,(150) they are indeed the true disbelievers. And We have prepared for the disbelievers a humiliating punishment(151) As for those who believe in Allah and His messengers—accepting all; rejecting none—He will surely give them their rewards. And Allah is All- Forgiving, Most Merciful(152)) ﴾ [An-Nisa’: 150-152] God Almighty sent us messengers to show us the way of good, the way of evil, what is the purpose of life and what is the purpose of our creation. Where did we come from and where we will end up. How we worship Allah, that you believe in his existence, and how we thank Him for His blessings. If you truly believe in Him, you must believe in the Apostles.

chunks.question: How do you respond to agnosticism and indifference?
chunks.answer: The response is very simple. Ask him a question. When you pass the road in the morning, do you look to your right and left to see the movement of cars, or are you passing unconsciously, you do not know what you are experiencing is real or not? And you don't care what happens? He'll say, of course, I do look at the movement of cars. Tell him.. So you care. The evidence for the existence of God is not equal to the evidence for his non- existence as the agnostic claims. The atheist has no evidence to give us, he claims without evidence.

chunks.question: What questions will an atheist not answer?
chunks.answer: How did existence emerge from the unnecessary and the nowhere? How did lifelessness come into life? How did dead matter move into living cells? Whereas today, at the top of our technology and giant universities, we cannot create simpler images of life, how do we attribute the emergence of life to the blind dead matter? How can an atheist, through his atheism, defend the extermination of all the people of the earth? The material world knows neither right nor wrong? Atheism assumes that humans are mere animals that came in a chain of evolution of inferior beings! What if a finer object appears? Does he have the right to bring humans into animal cages and use them in his drug trials? The explicit answer from the reality of matter and Darwinism is: Yes What if evolution proves that one human race is superior to another, does the finest have the right to turn the inferior into a used substance, as we deal with evolutionarily inferior insects and animals? The answer to materialistic Darwinism is: Yes The atheist assumes that morality is relative – that is, it bears more than one aspect; for example, honesty may be better than betrayal and betrayal may be better than honesty - and then when he comes up with his suspicions - predetermining that it is absolute -. It can only bear one possibility. Honesty is better than betrayal. Because if morality were relative, suspicion has no meaning, because then he would not be able to decide that there is a violation of an ethical standard. This is an apparent contradiction: is morality relative or absolute? If it were absolute, his atheism would end because this means that morality carries a major existential teleology. The will of Allah and the divine commission, even if it is relative, it means that it is not right for an atheist to come up with suspicion or to understand the existence of suspicion in the first place. How did these amazing physical constants that created the universe appear?

chunks.question: What is the Quran's approach to responding to atheists?
chunks.answer: Almighty said: (Or were they created from nothing, or are they the Creators) [Surah At-Tur: 35] The verse confined it to three choices 1) Were they created out of nowhere? And this is impossible. 2) Did they create themselves? This is impossible too. 3) That their creation be a Creator? And this is correct. We find as Shaykh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah (may Allah have mercy on him) said: "He, exalted be he, mentioned the evidence in the interrogative form of denial, to show that this issue that he inferred is intuitive and stable in the souls, and no one can deny it. He can't say, 'This brought about himself.'

chunks.question: If God knew my actions before they happened and predestined them on me, why would He hold me accountable? Do we really have a choice?
chunks.answer: Atheists always follow the cause of destiny and repeat that you say that God does everthing in his kingdom with decree and destiny and that God has predestined our actions and if this is my situation and that all my actions are written to him in advance, why does he hold me accountable for them? And don't tell me we are chosen, there is no bigger lie than this lie, did you choose my birth, sex, height, width, color and homeland? Does the sun rise and the moon set by my choice? Do I die by choice? Do I fall into misfortunes by choice and find no solution but crime? Why does God force me to do something and then hold me accountable for it? And if you tell me that I am free and that I have a will next to God's will, would this not be polytheism, and falling into the multiplicity of wills? Then what do you say about the judgment of the environment and the conditions in changing this fate and in the inevitability that historical materialists say? The answer is that the questioner is caught in several fallacies, your actions are known to God in his book, he knows that you will choose this choice, so he wrote it, but it is not written on you under duress, it is estimated in his knowledge only as you estimate with your knowledge that your son will do such and such a mistake and then he actually does it, did you force him or was this an appreciation in knowledge from you and your knowledge was right? As for your statement saying freedom is a lie, saying that you did not choose your birth, color, sex, height and color, and that you cannot move the sun from its place, is another mistake, and this time the reason is that you will imagine freedom in a way other than the way we believers imagine it. You will talk about absolute freedom. Freedom to act in the universe and this belongs to God alone. We do not support this freedom and your Lord creates what He wants and chooses what is good for them because God is the one who creates what He wants and chooses. And God will not hold you accountable for your tallness, or reproach you for your height. And He will not punish you because you did not stop the sun in its orbit. The things that God ordered you to do are the ones that He will hold you accountable for. You are free to do as you wish in these matters, and these are the limits in which we speak about. You are free to prevent your lust, resist yourself, kill your evil intentions and encourage your tendencies to good. You can be generous or be stingy, and you can be honest or lie. And you can prevent your hand from forbidden money and your sight from the unlawful figures of others. And you can hold your tongue from backbiting and gossiping. In these matters we are free and this is only what God holds us accountable for.

chunks.question: Do we really have a choice?
chunks.answer: The fact that God knows our choices does not make it any less voluntary. Although God wants people to believe in Him, He does not force anyone. If God willed, He could guide all of humankind, as He has power over everything. But in His Wisdom, He has created us with the ability to choose and made us accountable for our choices. God is not necessarily pleased with everything that He allows to occur.

chunks.question: Why doesn't God just reveal Himself?
chunks.answer: In God's wisdom, He has chosen to make Himself known through His signs. This is part of the test of this life. He has made it our responsibility to use the abilities He has given us to acknowledge Him. This means that only those who are sincere, humble and reflect deeply will recognise and believe in Him. We (God) will show them Our signs in the horizons and within themselves until it becomes clear to them that it is the truth." Quran 41:53 God provides signs of His existence – both through His natural creation and through revelation. God calls on us to acknowledge Him through His signs and has made it our responsibility to ponder and reflect in order to recognise Him. Some people are receptive to these signs and see God's work all around them, while others dismiss everything as random and meaningless. God has placed in every person, a natural inclination to believe, but this innate predisposition to believe can either be nurtured or suppressed. Importantly, God guides people who are sincere and willing to receive guidance. In other words, those who do not want to believe in God will not be guided. God says, "God guides Himself whoever turns to Him." Quran 13:27 This requires objectivity and an unbiased attitude to the possibility of God's existence, which can be quite confronting and humbling for some people, but without this genuine openness and willingness, no amount of information can make someone believe. In fact, God warns us that those who approach His signs from a position of pride and arrogance will only find justification for their disbelief.

chunks.question: What is the purpose of life?
chunks.answer: Where did I come from? Why am I here? Where am I going? - One of the first questions that comes to mind when considering our purpose of life is, “where did we come from?” Are we here based on random natural coincidences or is there a higher intelligent being, a creator? - The All Wise did not create us to simply wander aimlessly or to only fulfil our basic instincts and desires. Rather, we have a higher purpose – to acknowledge and worship God alone, so that we live upon the guidance of our Creator. - This guidance enables us to live a contented and successful life in all aspects. It is part of God’s infinite wisdom that He created us and gave us the opportunity to know Him and to experience our lives and make our own choices. - Islam is a complete and practical way of life that teaches Muslims to be balanced, decent and contributing members of society. - The concept of worship in Islam does not only include praying and supplicating to God. It is a broad definition that includes any action that God is pleased with. Some examples include: Earning an honest living Opposing oppression Taking care of orphans Looking after the environment Having patience & humility Benefiting the community Respecting parents Standing up for justice Kindness to neighbors Having mindfulness of God Providing for one’s family Speaking the truth Acts of worship require the sincere intention to please God and must be performed correctly according to Islamic guidelines. Acknowledging the existence of a creator is the first step in understanding our true purpose in life. There are many logical and rational reasons for believing in a creator. Three reasons are briefly mentioned below.

chunks.question: What is Islam?
chunks.answer: A Brief Guide To #Islam Definition of Islam Islam is the name of the religion which God (Allah) has revealed to his last Prophet, Muhammad (peace be upon him). The word Islam means total submission and obedience to God. a single God who has neither partners nor sons. That is why Islam is not a new religion. It is, in essence, the same message and guidance that Allah revealed to all prophets in its comprehensive, complete, and final form. The religion of Islam is based on principles of justice, peace, tolerance, and mercy towards all our brothers in humanity. Muslims have a *direct connection* with their Creator. There is no intermediary, such as praying to or through others, in worshiping God. And this is what makes Islam so special and unique. And * true happiness * is in only found in *worshiping our creator*. as it is the right of the Creator to be worshipped alone and the right of the human being to have direct connection with His Creator. You will find out that most of the teachings of Islam are moral teachings and ethical instructions that will make our world a better place, like don't kill, don't steal, be good to others, respect your parents, speak the truth, don't cheat, be honest, respect your husband or wife, etc.

chunks.question: Is Islam a new religion?
chunks.answer: The Religion of Adam and Eve Islam is not a new religion; rather, it is a continuation of the divine message sent by Allah through prophets across the ages. All prophets came with one unified message: to worship Allah alone, without any partners or intermediaries. Islam, at its core, is the same monotheistic faith preached by prophets from Adam to Noah, Abraham, Moses, Jesus, and Muhammad (peace be upon them all). Prophet Abraham (peace be upon him) was neither Jewish nor Christian but a true Muslim who submitted entirely to Allah, as the Quran states: "Abraham was neither a Jew nor a Christian, but he was one inclining toward truth, a Muslim [submitting to Allāh]. And he was not of the polytheists." (Quran 3:67). Prophet Jesus (peace be upon him) and his disciples were also Muslims. The disciples said, as mentioned in the Quran: "The disciples said, 'We are supporters for Allah. We have believed in Allah and testify that we are Muslims [submitting to Him]." (Quran 3:52). Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) did not bring a new religion but came to complete the message carried by previous prophets and to guide humanity back to the pure path after distortions had entered previous scriptures. Islam is the final, complete, and preserved version of God’s religion, emphasizing justice, mercy, and absolute monotheism.

chunks.question: How do we know Islam is the truth?
chunks.answer: 1. Islam is based on the belief that Allah is One, with no partners or equals. He is perfect in His attributes and incomparable to anything. This pure monotheism distinguishes Islam from other religions.

chunks.question: Why is there multiplicity in religions?
chunks.answer: Humanity began as one nation following one religion, with Allah sending messengers with a single unified message: the call to monotheism and the worship of Allah alone, without partners. This message remained consistent across all times and places, emphasizing belief in Allah and adherence to His commands. However, the laws (Shari’ah) brought by the prophets varied according to the needs and circumstances of each era and community. These differences in laws were a mercy from Allah, ensuring they suited the nature and context of each nation, but they never altered the core message of monotheism and submission to Allah. Over time, distortions crept into these divine laws and scriptures. Some people rejected the truth and insisted on denial even after clear evidence was presented to them. Others tampered with the scriptures, adding or removing content or interpreting them in ways that served their personal interests. Some even went as far as mistreating or killing the prophets. Allah says: "And indeed, there is among them a party who alter the Scripture with their tongues so you may think it is from the Scripture, but it is not from the Scripture. And they say, "This is from Allāh," but it is not from Allāh. And they speak untruth about Allāh while they know." (Quran 3:78). As a result of these distortions and deviations, sects and differing ideologies emerged. However, the religion that Allah has always chosen for humanity has remained one: Islam, which means complete submission to Allah. Allah says: "And whoever desires other than Islām as religion - never will it be accepted from him, and he, in the Hereafter, will be among the losers" (Quran 3:85).

chunks.question: Who is God?
chunks.answer: Who is Allah? 3- Who is Allah? Understanding God in Islam Allah in Islam is the One, the Absolute, the Perfect in His attributes, and eternal in His existence, unlike anything else. In Arabic, we call God "Allah," a term used by Arabic speakers of all faiths, including Christians and Jews, to refer to the Almighty. All agree that Allah is not a trinity. Allah is the Greatest Creator, who brought you into existence from nothing, cared for you in your mother's womb, and granted you intellect, hearing, and sight. He created the heavens and the earth, the moon and the sun, and everything in the universe. Islam calls for the worship of Allah alone, without any intermediary. The relationship with Allah is direct; anyone can communicate with their Creator without needing any other party. Allah says: “And when My servants ask you, [O Muḥammad], concerning Me - indeed I am near. I respond to the invocation of the supplicant when he calls upon Me.” (Quran 2:186) Allah is the Most Merciful and Forgiving. He forgives the sins of those who sincerely repent and always offers a chance for people to return to Him, no matter their mistakes. Allah says: "Say, "O My servants who have transgressed against themselves [by sinning], do not despair of the mercy of Allāh.'” (Quran 39:53) Allah is perfect in all His attributes. He does not eat, drink, or sleep. He has no children, parents, or partners. He alone deserves worship and submission. Allah knows what is hidden in hearts, manages all matters with wisdom, and everything He decrees for His servants is ultimately good, even if they do not comprehend it. Allah says: " ِAnd they encompass not a thing of His knowledge except for what He wills." (Quran 2:255). Belief in Allah brings peace and tranquility to the heart, strengthens trust in His wisdom, and ensures confidence in His absolute justice.

chunks.question: Why does God punish people?
chunks.answer: To answer this question, we need to look at the concept of punishment from a rational and realistic perspective. Punishment is an essential part of establishing justice, whether in our daily lives or on a divine level. Human logic dictates that every fair system must include rewards for those who do good and penalties for those who do wrong. In our daily lives, criminal laws punish individuals who commit crimes like theft or murder to protect society and deter others. Similarly, educational institutions reward hard working students with high grades while negligent ones face failure, creating an environment that encourages better performance. If we accept the necessity of punishment and reward to establish justice in our lives, it is even more reasonable that God, as the Creator, holds His creation accountable for their actions. God has granted humans the freedom to choose, and with that freedom comes individual responsibility. If a person decides to deny God’s existence or disobey His commands despite the clarity of evidence and guidance, they bear the consequences of their choices. For instance, if you work for years to save money to secure your future and your family’s, only for someone to steal it in an instant, you would demand justice and punishment for the thief. Here, punishment is not just about revenge but about restoring balance, achieving justice, and preventing others from facing a similar situation. In our daily lives, parents discipline their children when they misbehave, not out of revenge, but to teach them right from wrong. For example, if a child plays with an electrical outlet, a parent might punish them harshly to prevent future harm. Similarly, traffic signals are set up to protect everyone, and if someone runs a red light and causes an accident, they are held accountable for their actions. Punishment here aims to correct the individual and protect others. God is the Most Just and Most Merciful. He sent prophets and revealed scriptures to guide humanity towards the path of righteousness and did not leave people without direction. Divine punishment serves to establish absolute justice and to give every individual what they deserve based on their choices in life. God does not punish until He makes the message and guidance clear to people. Islam emphasizes balancing hope in God’s mercy with fear of His punishment. God grants people time to repent and reform and does not hasten punishment. Divine punishment is not a sign of cruelty but of God’s justice and mercy, helping individuals recognize their responsibilities and giving them a chance to correct their path before it is too late.

chunks.question: What is the Quran?
chunks.answer: Do you know what is the #Quran? The Quran is the last and eternal word of God to all of mankind, revealed to the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, through the Angel Gabriel. The Quran addresses a wide range of topics, including belief in Allah, the prophets, and the Day of Judgment; morality and ethics; social and political issues; and family and personal affairs. It provides guidance on every aspect of human life. It contains the answers to the mysteries of life and beyond, Where I come from, what happens after death, the purpose of life. Give life to those who are spiritually dead. It emphasizes justice, compassion, and solidarity, and it encourages Muslims to be kind and fair to their fellow human beings.

chunks.question: What is the proof that the Quran is the Word of God?
chunks.answer: The Quran is the Word of God revealed to the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). It is miraculous in its characteristics and features, proving that it is not the work of humans. The evidence includes:

chunks.question: Who Wrote the Quran and How Was It Compiled?
chunks.answer: Firstly: Allah Himself guaranteed the preservation of the Quran, as He says in His holy book: "Indeed, it is We who sent down the Reminder [i.e., the Quran], and indeed, We will be its guardian" (Quran 15:9). Secondly: Literacy was not widespread among the Arabs during the time of the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him). Allah described them as follows: "It is He who has sent among the unlettered [Arabs] a Messenger from themselves" (Quran 62:2). The Arabs relied on memorizing the Quran in their hearts, and some of them wrote down verses and chapters on animal skins, thin white stones, and other materials. Thirdly: At the beginning, the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) forbade writing anything other than the Quran for a period of time. This was to ensure that the companions focused solely on memorizing and writing the Quran and to prevent any mixing of the Prophet’s words with the words of Allah. This contributed to protecting the Quran from any addition or omission. Fourthly: The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) appointed a group of trustworthy and knowledgeable companions to write down the revelation. Among them were Abdullah ibn Amr ibn al-As, Muawiyah ibn Abi Sufyan, Zayd ibn Thabit, and others– may Allah be pleased with them all. Fifthly: The Quran was revealed in seven dialects, as mentioned in an authentic hadith narrated by Umar ibn al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him). These dialects represented the eloquent linguistic styles of the Arabs at the time. Sixthly: The Quran remained preserved in the hearts of the companions who memorized it, as well as on the materials on which it was written, until the time of Caliph Abu Bakr As-Siddiq (may Allah be pleased with him). After consulting the senior companions, Abu Bakr decided to compile the Quran into a single book to ensure its preservation, especially after many memorizers were martyred in battles. He entrusted this task to Zayd ibn Thabit, who was known for his excellent memorization and meticulousness. Zayd only agreed to write down a verse after two witnesses testified that they had heard it directly from the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him). This compiled Quran remained with Abu Bakr until his death, then with Umar ibn al- Khattab during his lifetime, and later with Hafsah, the daughter of Umar (may Allah be pleased with them). Seventhly: During the caliphate of Uthman ibn Affan (may Allah be pleased with him), the companions had dispersed across different regions, and variations in recitation arose due to differences in dialects. To prevent disputes, Uthman united the Muslims on a single recitation in the Quraysh dialect, the language in which the Quran was first revealed. He requested Hafsah to send him the copy of the Quran she had, and he tasked Zayd ibn Thabit, Abdullah ibn al-Zubayr, Saeed ibn al-As, and Abdur Rahman ibn Harith ibn Hisham with copying it. He instructed them: "If you disagree with Zayd ibn Thabit on any point in the Quran, write it in the dialect of Quraysh, for it was revealed in their tongue." Once the copies were completed, Uthman returned the original manuscript to Hafsah and sent the new copies to different Islamic provinces. The Quran has remained preserved and transmitted faithfully from generation to generation, both in written form and in the hearts of Muslims, as Allah promised: "Indeed, it is We who sent down the Reminder [i.e., the Quran], and indeed, We will be its guardian" (Quran 15:9). And Allah knows best.

chunks.question: Why did Caliph Uthman ibn Affan burn some copies of the Quran?
chunks.answer: The issue of burning the Quranic copies during the caliphate of Uthman ibn Affan, may Allah be pleased with him, has been misunderstood by some, either out of ignorance or deliberate intent. To understand this matter accurately, it is essential to consider the historical context and the reasons behind this decision. The Quran was compiled during the lifetime of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and was recited to Muslims in various readings that suited the different dialects of the Arab tribes. As Islam expanded and people from non-Arab backgrounds or different dialects embraced the faith, variations in Quranic recitation began to appear. These variations were not due to alterations in the text but resulted from differences in dialects and the inability of some people to comprehend the multiple recitations. These differences started causing disputes, raising concerns that they might lead to doubts about the Quranic text. To preserve the unity of Muslims and safeguard the Quran from any suspicion, Uthman ibn Affan, may Allah be pleased with him, decided to unite the community on one standardized recitation in the Quraysh dialect, the dialect in which the Quran was revealed. Standardized copies of the Quran were produced and distributed to different regions, and any other copies that were written in non-standardized forms were ordered to be burned to prevent confusion. This action was not an alteration or modification of the Quranic text; rather, it was a measure to protect and ensure its uniformity. Allah Almighty has guaranteed the preservation of the Quran, as stated in the verse: "Indeed, upon Us is its collection [in your heart] and [to make possible] its recitation." (Surah Al-Qiyamah: 17). What Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, did was a wise measure, carried out with the consensus of the companions, to ensure the Quran remained unchanged and free of discrepancies. Throughout Islamic history, the Quran has never been altered, thanks to divine preservation and the diligence of the noble companions.

chunks.question: Why did Allah preserve the Quran and allow His earlier books of divine revelation to be changed or lost?
chunks.answer: The answer to this question lies in several key points related to the purpose of divine revelations and the nature of sacred texts. The scriptures revealed before the Quran, such as the Torah and the Gospel, were sent to specific nations and for limited periods of time. Once the mission of the prophet delivering the message was completed or the targeted community ceased to exist, God sent another prophet with a new scripture suited to the new era and circumstances. Therefore, it was not necessary to preserve these scriptures permanently, as their preservation was left as a test for humanity. Unfortunately, people deviated from the truth, altered the content of these scriptures, and added or removed elements to suit their desires, leading to the distortion or loss of the original revelations. In contrast, the Quran was revealed to the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), the final messenger. He was not sent to a specific people or for a limited time but to all of humanity until the end of time. Allah states: "And We have not sent you except comprehensively to mankind as a bringer of good tidings and a warner. But most of the people do not know" (Quran 34:28). Therefore, it was essential for the Quran to be preserved from any distortion or loss so that it could remain a proof for all generations of humanity until the Day of Judgment. The Quran is also the greatest miracle of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and the definitive evidence of his prophethood. Preserving the Quran was necessary to ensure the continuation of this miracle and to affirm that Muhammad (peace be upon him) is indeed the final messenger. Over time, false claimants to prophethood have presented their own so-called scriptures, but none of them were preserved in the miraculous way that the Quran has been, nor did they embody its profound message. The Quran is the primary source of Islam and its principles. Through its preservation, the teachings of Islam have been safeguarded in their original purity. Even if people deviate or attempt to make changes, the Quran remains a timeless witness to the truth, allowing humanity to return to it for guidance and correction. Allah says: "Indeed, the religion in the sight of Allah is Islam" (Quran 3:19). The loss of the original texts of previous scriptures, such as the Gospel, which disappeared during the persecution of early Christians, or the Torah, which was destroyed during the Babylonian conquest, means that returning to the pure teachings of earlier prophets is impossible except through Islam. Islam is the only religion where the teachings of the prophets have been meticulously preserved through the Quran, which serves as the final and universal message to all of mankind.

chunks.question: Are there any other sacred sources besides the Quran?
chunks.answer: Yes, the Sunnah of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), which includes his practices, sayings, and teachings, is the second source of legislation in Islam after the Quran. A Hadith is a reliable report of what the Prophet (peace be upon him) said, did, or approved. Belief in the Sunnah is an essential part of Islamic faith. The Quran clarifies the authority of the Sunnah:

chunks.question: Why is abrogation in Quran verses?
chunks.answer: Abrogation in the Quran is part of divine wisdom that aims to achieve human benefit and ease their lives. It is not a contradiction or change in God's knowledge. Human laws themselves change over time to suit the development of societies and their needs; how much more so for God's rulings, which consider the conditions of people across ages? Abrogation in rulings demonstrates God's mercy by gradually guiding His servants according to their capacity for understanding and compliance. Gradual legislation is an effective way to bring about positive change. For example, the prohibition of alcohol was not immediate but occurred in stages, which helped people accept the ruling without societal shock. Abrogation also shows how divine rulings can adapt to changing temporal and social circumstances, ensuring that the new ruling aligns better with the current reality while maintaining fundamental principles. It is also a test of believers' faith and trust in God's wisdom. When Muslims accept abrogation, they demonstrate their devotion to God and readiness to submit to His commands, regardless of changes. Allah says: "We do not abrogate a verse or cause it to be forgotten except that We bring forth [one] better than it or similar to it. Do you not know that Allah is over all things competent?" (Al-Baqarah: 106). This verse clarifies that abrogation always brings something better or equivalent, indicating that it does not diminish the perfection of legislation but rather enhances its alignment with human benefit. The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) explained new rulings to Muslims and clarified their wisdom, as he did in the case of changing the direction of prayer (Qiblah) from Jerusalem to the Kaaba. This change carried both spiritual and political significance, asserting the independence of Muslims from other religions. An example of abrogation in legislation is the change in Qiblah. Muslims initially prayed facing Jerusalem but were later commanded to face the Kaaba. This change highlighted their trust in God's wisdom and established their religious identity. The prohibition of alcohol came in successive stages until it was fully prohibited, reflecting God's mercy in gradually guiding His servants. Similarly, rulings on prisoners of war evolved from killing them to pardoning or ransoming them, demonstrating a moral and humane progression in dealing with enemies. Abrogation often came to ease burdens on Muslims or simplify their obligations. Changes in rulings encouraged greater effort from believers, leading to increased rewards. It also allowed societies to adapt gradually to new laws. Abrogation is not a contradiction or alteration in God's knowledge; rather, it reflects divine wisdom that considers human benefit. It highlights the perfection of divine legislation, its ability to adapt to changing circumstances, and affirms that Islam is a religion of mercy and ease.

chunks.question: Who is Muhammad (peace be upon him)?
chunks.answer: Who is Muhammad, the Messenger of Allah, the Prophet of Islam? Muhammad (peace be upon him) is the Seal of the Prophets, sent by Allah as a mercy to all mankind. He was tasked with calling people to the oneness of Allah, teaching humanity, bringing good news, and warning against evil. His message was a continuation of the divine messages sent before him, calling people to worship Allah alone and follow the path of truth. Allah says: "And We have not sent you, [O Muḥammad], except as a mercy to the worlds." (Quran 21:107) Revelation descended upon him at the age of forty, and he spent the remainder of his life calling people to Islam, explaining its teachings, and applying them in practice. Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was sent with the Quran, the final divine book, and Allah made his life a complete model for humanity in faith, morality, and behavior. Allah says: "There has certainly been for you in the Messenger of Allāh an excellent pattern for anyone whose hope is in Allāh and the Last Day and [who] remembers Allāh often." (Quran 33:21) Islam is the final divine message, abrogating previous laws and calling for the worship of Allah alone without intermediaries. Allah says, "And whoever desires other than Islām as religion-never will it be accepted from him, and he, in the Hereafter, will be among the losers." (Quran 3:85) Worshiping Allah in the manner He has ordained can only be achieved by following the guidance of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was a paragon of good character, urging others to embody the best morals. He said, "The best among you are those with the best character." He emphasized kindness in interactions, saying: "Whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day should not harm his neighbor; whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day should honor his guest; and whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day should say what is good or remain silent." Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was distinguished by his mercy in all situations. He said: "Whoever does not show mercy will not be shown mercy." When some companions asked him to pray against the disbelievers, he responded, "I was not sent as one who curses but as a mercy." The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was a great leader, a loyal husband, a compassionate father, and a truthful friend. His teachings have left a profound impact on humanity, and they continue to guide millions in their daily lives. Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was not just a prophet but a practical example embodying all the noble values that Islam calls for, making him a role model for all people across time and place.

chunks.question: How did Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) teach Muslims the importance of tolerance in their daily lives?
chunks.answer: 1– Self-accountability: The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said: 'The wise one is the one who holds himself accountable and works for what is after death, and the incapable one is the one who follows his desires and places false hopes on Allah.' (Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi and authenticated by Al-Albani). This highlights the importance of self-accountability and working for the Hereafter as a part of practicing tolerance with oneself and others. 2– Concealing others' faults: The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said: 'Whoever conceals the faults of a Muslim, Allah will conceal his faults in this world and the Hereafter.' (Narrated by Muslim). This encourages people to cover others' shortcomings rather than exposing them, fostering an environment of tolerance and mutual respect. 3– Controlling anger: Allah says: 'And who restrain anger and who pardon the people - and Allāh loves the doers of good' (Quran 3:134). The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said: 'The strong person is not the one who can overpower others in wrestling. Rather, the strong one is the one who controls himself when he is angry.'
