(Narrated by Al-Bukhari and Muslim). Tolerance requires the ability to control anger and forgive others. 4– Forgiving others: Allah says: 'And indeed, the Hour is coming; so forgive with gracious forgiveness.' (Quran 15:85). The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) urged forgiveness by saying: 'Pardon those who wrong you.' (Narrated by Ahmad with a good chain of narration). 5– Avoiding cursing: The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said: 'I was not sent as a curser but as a mercy.' (Narrated by Muslim). This encourages avoiding cursing and instead promoting mercy, even towards those who may cause harm. 6– Avoiding suspicion: Allah says: 'O you who have believed, avoid much [negative] assumption. Indeed, some assumption is sin.' (Quran 49:12). Tolerance requires refraining from harboring negative assumptions, which can damage relationships and increase hostility. 7– Avoiding arrogance and pride: Allah says: 'And do not turn your cheek [in contempt] toward people and do not walk through the earth exultantly. Indeed, Allāh does not like everyone self-deluded and boastful.' (Quran 31:18). The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said: 'It is enough evil for a man to belittle his Muslim brother.' (Narrated by Muslim). Humility is a key characteristic of a tolerant person. 8– Avoiding mocking others: Allah says: 'O you who have believed, let not a people ridicule [another] people; perhaps they may be better than them.' (Quran 49:11). Mockery weakens bonds between people and stirs up discord. 9– Exercising patience: Patience is mentioned in over seventy verses in the Quran. The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said: 'No one is given a gift better and more expansive than patience.' (Narrated by Al-Bukhari and Muslim). Patience helps in overcoming conflicts and nurturing a spirit of tolerance. Tolerance is not merely a noble virtue but also a means to build a cohesive society filled with love and understanding. The sayings of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and the verses of the Quran present a clear model for the virtue of tolerance.

chunks.question: Why should Muhammad be the final Prophet?
chunks.answer: Haven't there been others after him? In John 16:12-13, Jesus says: "I still have many things to say to you, but you cannot bear them now. However, when He, the Spirit of truth, has come, He will guide you into all truth." This passage indicates that Jesus promised the coming of a messenger who would complete the message and guide people to the full truth. Muslims believe this refers to Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), who brought a comprehensive and final message. In Deuteronomy 18:18, God says to Moses: "I will raise up for them a prophet like you from among their brothers, and I will put My words in his mouth, and he shall speak to them all that I command him." The text refers to a prophet coming from the "brothers" of the Israelites, which means the descendants of Ishmael. This aligns with Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), who descended from Ishmael. If Jesus were the last prophet or God Himself, why did He promise the coming of another (John 16:13)? Jesus explicitly stated that his mission was directed only to the Israelites: "I was not sent except to the lost sheep of the house of Israel." (Matthew 15:24). This demonstrates that his message was not universal, unlike Islam, which came with a message for all of humanity. John Hick, a Christian theologian, argued that the concept of salvation through Christ alone contradicts God's justice and mercy. If God is loving and just, why would salvation be limited to belief in Christ alone, while ignoring millions of people who lived before Christ or in regions where Christianity never reached? This highlights the need for a universal message, such as Islam, which asserts that every individual is held accountable for their actions rather than adherence to a specific creed. Scholars like Bart Ehrman have pointed out that the Bible has undergone alterations over time. This makes it difficult to rely on Biblical texts as evidence that Jesus was the last prophet or that prophethood ended with him. Christian sects such as the Arians and some Eastern Orthodox groups rejected the doctrine of the Trinity and salvation exclusively through Christ. This suggests that the concept of prophethood and finality in Christianity is not universally agreed upon among all denominations. Islam emphasizes that Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) is the final prophet through whom God completed the religion: "Muḥammad is not the father of [any] one of your men, but [he is] the Messenger of Allāh and seal [i.e., last] of the prophets." (Surah Al-Ahzab: 40) "This day I have perfected for you your religion and completed My favor upon you and have approved for you Islām as religion." (Surah Al-Ma'idah: 3) This confirms that Islam came to complete previous messages, not to nullify or replicate them. Unlike previous prophets who were sent to specific communities, Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was sent as a messenger for all of humanity: "And We have not sent you except comprehensively to mankind as a bringer of good tidings and a warner." (Surah Saba: 28) God has preserved the Quran from any alteration. "Indeed, it is We who sent down the Qur'an, and indeed, We will be its guardian." (Surah Al-Hijr: 9) This is in contrast to previous scriptures, which underwent alterations, making the need for a final, preserved message essential.

chunks.question: Is the Quran authored by Muhammad (peace be upon him) or derived from the Bible?
chunks.answer: We can rely on several logical points supported by evidence from both the Quran and the Bible: 1. Illiteracy of Prophet Muhammad: The Quran affirms the illiteracy of Prophet Muhammad, negating the possibility that he could have written the Quran, as stated in the verse: 'And you did not recite before it any scripture, nor did you inscribe one with your right hand. Then [i.e., otherwise] the falsifiers would have had [cause for] doubt.' (Al-Ankabut 29:48). 2. The Quranic Challenge to Produce Similar Work: The Quran challenges people to produce a surah like it if they doubt its divine origin, as mentioned in the verse: 'And if you are in doubt about what We have sent down [i.e., the Qur’ān] upon Our Servant [i.e., Prophet Muḥammad (ﷺ)], then produce a sūrah the like thereof and call upon your witnesses [i.e., supporters] other than Allāh, if you should be truthful.' (Al-Baqarah 2:23). 3. Scientific and Historical Content of the Quran: The Quran contains accurate scientific and historical information unknown at that time, such as details of embryonic development and cosmic realities, indicating that it could not have been authored by someone from the 7th century. 4. Biblical Prophecies About Muhammad: Some scholars refer to prophecies in the Bible they consider to be indications of Prophet Muhammad, such as the Paraclete prophecy in the Gospel of John, which some interpreters believe refers to Muhammad. 5. Doctrinal and Ethical Differences: The Quran corrects and completes the doctrines and teachings of the Bible on topics such as the oneness of God and the stories of the prophets, demonstrating that it is not merely a human composition but divine guidance. 6. Linguistic and Rhetorical Consistency: The Quran is distinguished by its unique rhetorical style and linguistic coherence, surpassing human capabilities, which has challenged the Arabs, known for their language and eloquence. Finally, if the Quran were derived from the Bible, how could the branch surpass the root in every aspect? The Quran offers corrections and additions in doctrinal, ethical, scientific, and linguistic areas, suggesting that it is not merely a repetition of previous contents but an independent revelation that complements and corrects earlier information according to a precise divine plan. These aspects in which the Quran excels affirm that it is not a human work based on previous sources but a divine revelation intended to be an eternal message for humanity.

chunks.question: Are there any miracles for the Prophet Muhammad?
chunks.answer: Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was granted many miracles that confirm the truth of his prophethood. Some are mentioned in the Quran and Sunnah, while others are historically documented and witnessed by his contemporaries. One notable miracle is the protection of the Prophet from assassination attempts, such as the incident when Quraysh planned to kill him while he was sleeping. However, Allah saved him by blinding their vision as he passed among them, as mentioned in the verse: "And We have put before them a barrier and behind them a barrier and covered them, so they do not see" (Surah Yasin: 9). Another miracle was the multiplication of food and water during critical times, such as the siege of Khaybar and the Battle of Tabuk, where the Prophet blessed small amounts of food and water, making them sufficient for large numbers of people. He also foretold future events, such as the conquest of Mecca and the defeat of the Persians, followed by the victory of the Romans, which was fulfilled as stated in the verse: "The Romans have been defeated In the nearest land But they, after their defeat, will overcome" (Surah Ar-Rum: 2-3). The Prophet healed the sick through his prayers or by placing his blessed hand on them, as in the case of Qatadah ibn al-Nu'man during the Battle of Uhud. The conversion of his fiercest enemies, such as Umar ibn al-Khattab and Khalid ibn al- Walid, demonstrates his profound moral and spiritual influence. History also records the miracle of the splitting of the moon, mentioned in the Quran and witnessed by many at the time. The Quran itself is the greatest miracle of the Prophet, as it challenged humanity to produce anything like it, but none could. Allah says: "Say, 'If mankind and the jinn gathered in order to produce the like of this Quran, they could not produce the like of it, even if they were to each other assistants.'" (Surah Al-Isra: 88). The Quran is unique in its eloquence, legislation, prophecies, and alignment with modern science. The spread of Islam and its establishment of social justice serve as further evidence of the truth of the Prophet's message.

chunks.question: Do Muslims pray for Muhammad and the meaning of pray on him?
chunks.answer: We must understand that sending blessings upon the Prophet is not just a fleeting prayer, but a manifestation of respect and appreciation for the Prophet (peace be upon him) by enhancing his spiritual status in Islam. Firstly, Allah, the Almighty, commanded the believers to send blessings upon the Prophet in the Quran, saying: "Indeed, Allāh confers blessing upon the Prophet, and His angels [ask Him to do so]. O you who have believed, ask [Allāh to confer] blessing upon him and ask [Allāh to grant him] peace" [Al-Ahzab: 56]. Here, prayer does not only mean supplication, but represents a state of appreciation and honor for the Prophet (peace be upon him), as "prayer" from Allah means mercy, from the angels it means asking for forgiveness, and from the believers it means asking for blessings and respect. Secondly, in Islam, sending blessings upon the Prophet is not just a religious ritual, but also a means of increasing faith and connection with Allah and His Messenger. If Allah commands the believers to send blessings upon the Prophet, this indicates the importance of this act in strengthening the believer’s relationship with the Prophet (peace be upon him), who is the best of creation and the messenger through whom the divine message was delivered. From a rational perspective, sending blessings upon the Prophet is a constant reminder to Muslims that they need to connect with the prophetic heritage and follow his teachings in all aspects of their lives. It serves as an invitation to correct the believer's behavior and make the teachings of the Prophet (peace be upon him) central to understanding and guiding life.

chunks.question: Why did Prophet Muhammad marry Aisha when she was young?
chunks.answer: The marriage of Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, to Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, is a topic that is sometimes raised with the intent of casting doubt. However, when viewed through the lens of reason, logic, and historical, social, and religious context, this marriage reveals profound wisdom and was entirely normal by the standards of the time. Let us discuss the matter in detail. In the time of the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, marriage at a young age was common and socially acceptable across the world. There were no fixed legal age limits for marriage as we know them today. Instead, puberty and physical and social maturity were the primary criteria for determining readiness for marriage. In other cultures, marriage at young ages was common. In Europe, until the 19th century, marriage at the age of 7 or 10 was legally permitted. In America, the minimum legal age for marriage in Delaware in 1880 was 7 years. In France, the legal minimum age for marriage was 10 years and was later raised to 13. In the Bible, Isaac married Rebekah when she was very young, as mentioned in Genesis 24:59-60. Solomon had numerous wives, including 700 wives and 300 concubines, as stated in 1 Kings 11:3-4. This context highlights that early marriages were not unusual or exceptional but were a part of the cultural norms of societies worldwide. Factors Behind Marriage at This Age:

chunks.question: What are the pillars of faith?
chunks.answer: The Six fundamentals of faith A. Iman (Faith) means to believe in the heart, to confess by the tongue, and to act with the parts of the body. What are the pillars of Iman (Faith)? The pillars of Iman are six. The Muslim has to believe in: (1) Allah (2) His Angels (3) His Messengers (4) His Books (5) The Last Day (6) Qadar - Divine Preordainment: good or bad. 1-Belief in God Let me tell you about Almighty God, The Greatest, who created you from nothingness and saved you in the womb of your mother, and gave you hearing, sight, mind and heart, and honored you over all other creatures. We believe in the One True God alone without partners. We believe in the same God Who sent Abraham, Jesus, Moses, and Muhammad, peace be upon them all. Almighty God is One,Unique, and Perfect. God has no partners, no equals and no rivals. God is perfect. does not eat, nor drinks nor sleep. God has no father. No mother. No sons or daughters. No wives , no family. God alone is worthy of all worship. He is not like a man. He is not an idol. He is not a Trinity. He is the Most Powerful, who created the entire universe, stars, galaxies, skies, and all living beings and to him belong all the perfect/good attributes. God is able to do all things, and He is the one who gives life and death. God has full authority and power over all things. Obedience to God does not increase His Power, nor does disobedience decrease His power. God is the Most High. There is nothing above or comparable to God. The attributes of God do not resemble that of His creation. No part of God is present in anyone or anything. God is Perfect. God does not have any human limitations, such as resting on the seventh day after He created the universe. God always maintains attributes of perfection and does not do anything to compromise this perfection, such as “becoming a man”, as claimed by other religions. God does not do ungodly acts, so if God became man and took on human attributes, he would, necessarily, no longer be God. God is Almighty. Who overpowers everything, and who can not be overcome. He is unbeatable, and nothing can prevent Him from fulfilling what He wants. Almighty God is the All-Hearing Who responds to the supplication of His servant. He is so near to you. He even knows what's in your heart without saying it. You can talk to Him directly. Nothing in between No pastor No man No mediator It's just you and Him. Direct connection. Almighty God says : And when My servants ask you, [O Muḥammad], concerning Me - indeed I am near. I respond to the invocation of the supplicant when he calls upon Me, So let them respond to Me [by obedience] and believe in Me that they may be [rightly] guided" Quran(2:186) God says : "And We have already created man and know what his soul whispers to him, and We are closer[1528] to him than [his] jugular vein" ( 50:16 ) He is the Most Merciful ، The Most Forgiving. We need this , because all of us make sins and need to repent to our Lord. So when we commit a sin or fall short in our worship to Allah , we repent to him , knowing that he is the Most Merciful , The Most Forgiving. How do we repent? Just ask for forgiveness, and He forgives us. No mediator in between. It's just you and Him. One to one relationship. Allah (Almighty God) says in the Quran : " Say, "O My servants who have transgressed against themselves [by sinning], do not despair of the mercy of Allāh. Indeed, Allāh forgives all sins.[1354] Indeed, it is He who is the Forgiving, the Merciful.""(39:53) The name of God in Islam is “Allah” which means Almighty God. The word Almighty God is a standard translation of the word Allah in the English Bible. But it's still the same in the Arabic Bible till now. The word Allah is used by all Arab speakers from all faiths, including Arab Christians and Arab Jews. 2-Belief in the Prophets God loves us and has mercy on us that's why He sent us prophets (messengers) to show us the straight path. The first one was Adam, then Noah, Abraham, Moses, Jesus, and the last prophet Muhammad. God sends prophets (messengers) to teach us how to worship him. And every prophet was sent to a certain group of people. After the prophet dies and people mislead the way God send another prophet. And so on… All of the prophets were continuations of each other and were sent with the same messag , that there is no deity worthy of worship except the One True God, known in Arabic as Allah. Every prophet was the way to God in his time. Abraham and Noah were the way to their people in their time. And so are Jesus, Moses, and Muhammad. 3-Belief in angels The belief in the existence of angels: the true Muslim believes that God created the angels; they are different creations who are in the worship of God always, and they don’t disobey him. 4- Belief in divine books belief in all divine books, there were so many books, God sent it in succession, one after the other so that he updates his messages and keeps it on earth whenever humans modify it or alter it, so from these books are ( Torah, Psalms, Gospel, Quran), and we believe that the Quran is the final book, so it's the only one to be trusted now since it came to correct and show the right path after previous books were altered and modified and mistranslated by People. 5- Belief in predestination The belief in predestination. The true Muslim believes in the timeless knowledge of God. that he knows the past, present, and future, and he knows what will happen in advance before it happens. This is part of his perfection, and we believe that whatever happens to us unwillingly is made for wisdom, and it's part of the test and that we should be patient and succeed in it. 6-Belief in the last day of judgment The belief in the last day of Judgment, that one day this world will come to an end, and God will revive all dead people from the beginning of time right until the end , and he will judge each one of us individually with a fair judgement. According to Islam the only saved people are those who had faith in the one true God alone (without partners), and submitted to his will, by doing his commandments and teachings which are basically morals.

chunks.question: What are the pillars of Islam?
chunks.answer: We Muslims practice our faith according to the five pillars of Islam. The five pillars are: The shahadah, prayer, zakat, fasting, and pilgrimage. The shahadah is a simple profession of faith in the One True God, the God of Abraham, and the belief that Muhammad is His prophet and messenger which should be said with conviction in order to convert to Islam.

chunks.question: Why can we not be able to pray except in Arabic, and is it not possible to speak to God except in Arabic?
chunks.answer: Prayer in Arabic is an essential part of unity and collective communication in Islam. If we reflect on the essence of prayer, we find that it is not just a collection of words or phrases to be recited but rather a direct communication with Allah. This prayer is a unified law for all Muslims, regardless of their languages, which strengthens the sense of brotherhood among Muslims around the world. Allah, the Almighty, chose the Arabic language to be the language of the Quran, which is the miraculous word of Allah that cannot be altered or manipulated. Arabic is not just a regular language but a language rich in meanings and structure, allowing one to express precisely the will of Allah. For example, when Allah is described in the Quran as 'Ar-Rahman Ar-Rahim' (the Most Merciful, the Most Compassionate), these words convey His attributes with the utmost detail and precision, making them perfectly suitable for the Quran. Furthermore, when we look at the concept of prayer in Islam, it involves fixed words that are recited in every prayer, such as Surah Al-Fatiha and the Takbir. These words are an integral part of the worship mentioned in the prophetic tradition. Prayer is conducted in Arabic because it is the language the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) used to communicate with his companions. Therefore, repeating these words in prayer enhances spiritual communication with Allah. While it is permissible to supplicate and talk to Allah in any language outside of prayer, the formal prayer in Islam is performed in Arabic because it is the language chosen by Allah for the Quran and the prophetic tradition. If prayer were conducted in another language, it might lose some of its accuracy and original meanings. Moreover, the Arabic language preserves the purity of the religion and the correctness of worship. The Quran and the rhetorical miracles it contains could be distorted or lost if religious texts were translated incorrectly. Therefore, using Arabic in prayer protects against such distortion and keeps the texts intact.

chunks.question: What is the purpose of worship in Islam?
chunks.answer: The purpose of worship in Islam is to strengthen the connection between a person and their Creator and to cultivate piety (taqwa) in both heart and behavior. Worship is not merely a set of rituals but a means of self-purification and spiritual growth, helping individuals to recognize God's presence and observe His guidance in all actions and words. When a Muslim performs prayers, fasting, charity, or any other act of worship, the aim is to remind themselves of God's existence and their responsibilities as His servant. Worship enhances one's awareness of God, making them more receptive to His blessings and grace in this world and the Hereafter. It also refines morals, encouraging justice and kindness in dealing with others. Thus, worship in Islam is not only a path to drawing closer to God but also a means of achieving a balanced life built on inner and outer peace.

chunks.question: Who is a Muslim?
chunks.answer: The word "Muslim" means one who submits to the will of God. This is done by declaring that "there is no god except one God, and Muhammad is the messenger of God." In a broader sense, anyone who willingly submits to the will of God is a Muslim. Thus, all the prophets preceding the prophet Muhammad are considered Muslims. The Quran specifically mentions Abraham, who lived long before Moses and Christ that, "he was not a Jew or a Christian but a Muslim," because he had submitted to the will of God. Thus there are Muslims who are not submitting at all to the will of God, and there are Muslims who are doing their best to live an Islamic life. One cannot judge Islam by looking at those individuals who have a Muslim name but in their actions, they are not living or behaving as Muslims. The extent of being a Muslim can be according to the degree to which one is submitting to the will of God, in his beliefs and his actions.

chunks.question: Can anyone become a Muslim?
chunks.answer: Yes, anyone can. There are two declarations, which are necessary: 1- To bear witness that no one deserves to be worshiped except Allah. 2- To bear witness that Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) is the Messenger of Allah. This makes a person Muslim. But it should be said in Arabic. Next a person takes a shower is recommendable. Then what? After a person becomes Muslim, s/he is taught about prayers, fasting, alms to the poor, and pilgrimage. These are the pillars of Islam. Then what? Muslims are brothers and sisters. A Muslim should love for his brother or sister, what s/he loves himself/herself. Allah's wealth does not run out and Allah can provide for us all. We pray for each other, and love each other, and love for our brothers and sisters, what we love for ourselves.

chunks.question: Will the good deeds of non-Muslims be wasted?
chunks.answer: The Quran clearly states that Allah does not waste even an atom's weight of good or evil deeds. As He says: "So whoever does an atom's weight of good will see it,And whoever does an atom's weight of evil will see it". (Surah Al-Zalzalah: 7-8) The good deeds performed by non-Muslims are rewarded in this world. Allah may grant them blessings in their lives, facilitate their success, or relieve them of hardships. As for Muslims, they are rewarded for their good deeds in both this world and the Hereafter because their faith in Allah and their devotion make their actions accepted as pure worship intended for the eternal reward of the Hereafter. Ultimately, the final judgment rests with Allah Almighty. He alone knows what lies in people's hearts and is the most just in His rulings among His servants.

chunks.question: What is Sharia?
chunks.answer: Sharia is the comprehensive Muslim law derived from two sources, a) the Quran b) the Sunnah or traditions of Prophet Muhammad (Peace be upon him). It covers every aspect of daily individual andcollective living. The purpose of Islamic laws is protection of individuals' basic human rights to include right to life, property, political, and religious freedom and safeguarding the rights of women and minorities. The low crime rate in Muslim societies is due to the application of the Islamic laws.

chunks.question: What is the wisdom behind the legislation of stoning in Islam?
chunks.answer: The punishment of stoning is not exclusive to Islam; it has deep roots in other religions, particularly Judaism and Christianity. In the Torah, there are texts that prescribe stoning as a punishment, such as: "If a man commits adultery with another man's wife, both the adulterer and the adulteress must be put to death" (Leviticus 20:10). Similarly, in Deuteronomy, it states: "If a virgin is pledged to be married, and another man finds her in the city and sleeps with her, you shall take both of them to the gate of the town and stone them to death" (Deuteronomy 22:23- 24). The Torah does not limit stoning to adultery but also includes other offenses, such as: "Anyone who blasphemes the name of the Lord is to be put to death. The entire assembly must stone them" (Leviticus 24:16), and the punishment for disobedient sons: "Then all the men of his town are to stone him to death" (Deuteronomy 21:21). In Christianity, the New Testament shows how Jesus handled the issue of stoning with wisdom, as seen in the story of the adulterous woman (John 8:7). When the Jews wanted to stone her, Jesus said: "Let any one of you who is without sin be the first to throw a stone at her." He did not reject the punishment but used the situation to teach repentance and mercy. In ancient cultures, such as Babylonian law, the punishment for adultery included drowning or death. Among the Greeks, stoning was mentioned as a method of cleansing sin in the legend of Oedipus. Some Christian scholars have noted that the strict laws of the Old Testament aimed to protect society from moral decay, and stoning was seen as a means of deterrence. In Islam, the punishment of stoning is not an absolute rule but is applied under very strict conditions. It requires the testimony of four trustworthy witnesses who clearly saw the act, making its application nearly impossible except in very rare cases. The purpose of the punishment is to protect society from moral corruption, as adultery is considered a grave offense that impacts the family and community. Islam also emphasizes repentance and encourages the concealment of sins, as the Prophet Muhammad said: "Avoid implementing the legal punishments as much as you can. If there is any way out for the accused, let them go" (Abu Dawood). Stoning in Islam is not a new invention but an extension of a punishment found in previous religious laws, with strict conditions that limit its application to very specific circumstances.

chunks.question: Is Islam Intolerant of Other Religious Minorities?
chunks.answer: Islam recognizes the rights of religious minorities and ensures their protection and care within the framework of an Islamic state. The Quran emphasizes tolerance and justice toward those who do not oppose Islam, as Allah says: "Allah does not forbid you from those who do not fight you because of religion and do not expel you from your homes—from being righteous toward them and acting justly toward them. Indeed, Allah loves those who act justly." (Surah Al-Mumtahanah: 8). The Quran also declares: "There shall be no compulsion in [acceptance of] the religion." (Surah Al-Baqarah: 256). Islam guarantees the protection of religious minorities and their places of worship, such as churches and synagogues. For example, when Caliph Umar ibn Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) entered Jerusalem in 634 CE, he granted safety to all inhabitants and respected their freedom of worship. He even refused to pray inside the Church of the Holy Sepulchre out of respect for its status as a Christian place of worship. To protect minorities, Islam imposed the jizya, a symbolic tax in exchange for protection and exemption from military service, without forcing non- Muslims to change their religion. Islamic history is rich with examples of peaceful coexistence with religious minorities. During the Golden Age of Al-Andalus, Jews and Christians flourished under Islamic rule. Jews, in particular, enjoyed security and played significant roles in cultural and political life, while they faced persecution in other parts of Europe. Similarly, in other parts of the Islamic world, non-Muslims were granted the right to establish their own courts and apply their family laws. While Islam has a long history of protecting minorities, Muslims have not always been afforded the same tolerance in other societies. During the Spanish Inquisition, Muslims and Jews faced forced conversions and severe persecution. During the Crusades, Muslims faced massacres. In modern times, Muslim minorities continue to face discrimination and oppression in places like Bosnia and India. Islam calls for justice, coexistence, and respect toward religious minorities. Islamic history and Quranic teachings provide clear examples of these humanitarian values in practice.

chunks.question: What is Jihad?
chunks.answer: The word "Jihad" means struggle, or to be specific, striving in the cause of God. Any struggle done in day-to-day life to please God can be considered Jihad. One of the highest levels of Jihad is to stand up to a tyrant and speak a word of truth. Control of The self from wrongdoings is also a great Jihad. One of the forms of Jihad is to take up arms in defense of Islam or a Muslim country when Islam is attacked. This kind of Jihad has to be declared by the religious leadership or by a Muslim head of state who is following the Quran and Sunnah.

chunks.question: What is the Kaabah?
chunks.answer: The Kaabah is the sacred house of Allah and the center of worship that Allah commanded His Prophet Abraham and his son Ishmael to build more than four thousand years ago. It was constructed of stone on the site that was the first place of worship established by Prophet Adam. The Kaabah is not merely a building; it is a symbol of the unity of Muslims worldwide, as they face it in their daily prayers. When Allah commanded Prophet Abraham to invite people to perform pilgrimage to it, his call was in obedience to Allah's divine order. Today, as Muslims gather for Hajj or Umrah, they chant, "Here I am, O Allah, here I am," affirming their response to this divine invitation and continuing the message of monotheism.

chunks.question: Do Muslims worship the Kaaba and the Black Stone?
chunks.answer: Muslims do not worship the Kaaba or the Black Stone; they worship Allah alone. The Kaaba is the Qibla, meaning the direction Muslims face during their prayers, as commanded by Allah in the Quran: "So turn your face [i.e., yourself] toward al- Masjid al-Ḥarām." (Surah Al-Baqarah: 144). This direction unites Muslims in their prayers toward a single direction, but they bow and worship Allah alone. Islam promotes unity among Muslims. Without a designated Qibla, some might pray facing north while others face south. To unite Muslims in their worship of the One True God, Allah made the Kaaba the Qibla. Muslims in the west of the Kaaba face east, while those in the east face west. Muslims were the first to draw world maps, placing the south at the top and the north at the bottom, with the Kaaba at the center. Later, Western cartographers flipped the orientation, but the Kaaba remains at the world's center. When Muslims circumambulate around the Kaaba, it symbolizes their worship of Allah alone. Just as every circle has a single center, Allah is the only center of worship, with no partner or equal. Umar ibn Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) said about the Black Stone: "I know that you are a stone that can neither harm nor benefit. Had I not seen the Prophet (peace be upon him) kiss you, I would not have kissed you." (Sahih Bukhari). This statement shows that the Black Stone is symbolic and holds no intrinsic power, and Muslims do not worship or attribute holiness to it. During the time of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), Bilal ibn Rabah stood on the Kaaba to call for prayer. If Muslims worshipped the Kaaba, would they stand on it? This demonstrates that the Kaaba is not worshipped but serves as a unifying Qibla. The Bible contains clear references to the Kaaba and the Black Stone: In Isaiah 56:7, "For my house shall be called a house of prayer for all nations." This aligns with the Kaaba being a place of prayer for all Muslims. In Psalm 84:6: "Passing through the valley of Baca, they make it a spring." Baca refers to Mecca, and the Kaaba is the house mentioned, near the Zamzam well In Genesis 28:10-22, Jacob set up a Black Stone and called it the "House of God." In Genesis 35:1-3, God reminded Jacob of the stone he had set as the House of God. In Matthew 21:42-43: Jesus confirmed the stone set as the House of God. These references show that the use of a stone as a symbolic house of worship existed in previous scriptures, aligning with the Black Stone's role in Islam. The Book of Genesis mentions Hagar and the Zamzam well, where the angel found her near a spring of water in the wilderness. The well was called "Beer Lahai Roi" (the well of the Living One Who sees me) (Genesis 16:7). This reference indicates the blessing of the Zamzam well in the Hejaz region, near the Kaaba Muslims do not worship the Kaaba or the Black Stone but follow Allah's command to display unity in worship. The Kaaba is the first house built on earth for the worship of Allah alone, as stated in the Quran: "Indeed, the first House [of worship] established for mankind was that at Bakkah [i.e., Makkah]- blessed and a guidance for the worlds." (Surah Aal-e-Imran: 96)

chunks.question: What is the dress code for Muslims?
chunks.answer: Islam emphasizes modesty. No person should be perceived as a sex object. There are certain guidelines both for men and women that their dress should neither be too thin nor too tight to reveal body forms. For men, they must at least cover the area from the knee to navel, and for women, their dress should cover all areas except the hands and face.

chunks.question: What are the dietary prohibitions in Islam?
chunks.answer: Muslims are told in the Quran not to eat pork or pork products, meat of the animals who died before being slaughtered, or the carnivorous animals (as they eat dead animals), nor drink blood or intoxicants such as wine or use any illicit drugs.

chunks.question: Why is Pork Forbidden in Islam?
chunks.answer: The prohibition of pork in Islam has religious, environmental, and health dimensions that highlight the wisdom behind this legislation. Islam explicitly forbids the consumption of pork, as stated in the Quran: 'Prohibited to you are dead animals, [241] blood, the flesh of swine, and that which has been dedicated to other than Allāh.' (Al-Ma'idah 5:3). This prohibition is not new; it is a continuation of the teachings of previous divine revelations. The Torah (the holy book of Jews and Christians) also states: 'And the swine, though he divides the hoof and is cloven-footed, yet he does not chew the cud; he is unclean to you. Of their flesh you shall not eat, and their carcass you shall not touch; they are unclean to you.' (Leviticus 11:7-8). Similarly, in Deuteronomy: 'And the swine, because it divides the hoof yet does not chew the cud, it is unclean to you; you shall not eat their flesh nor touch their dead carcasses.' (Deuteronomy 14:8). This indicates that the prohibition of pork is shared between Islam and other divine messages, reinforcing the idea that it is part of divine teachings for human well-being. Pigs play a specific role in the ecosystem as natural scavengers, feeding on filth and waste, making them carriers of diseases. Even in modern environments where pigs are raised in clean conditions, their biological nature remains unchanged. This makes it challenging to ensure they are free from health risks associated with their dietary habits. Research has established a strong connection between pork consumption and several diseases, including parasitic worms, such as the pork tapeworm (Taenia Solium), which can cause significant damage to vital organs if it reaches the brain, heart, or liver. Pork contains high levels of unhealthy fats that increase the risk of heart disease and high blood pressure. While it is believed that cooking pork thoroughly kills parasites, studies have shown that some parasitic eggs, such as Trichiura Trichuris, can survive even after cooking. The prohibition of pork in Islam is not merely a matter of religious devotion but part of a legislative system aimed at protecting humans spiritually, physically, and environmentally. The wisdom behind this prohibition becomes clearer when considering the health and natural aspects of pigs, reflecting divine care for human well-being.

chunks.question: What is the Islamic Year?
chunks.answer: The Islamic year started from the migration (Hijra). of Prophet Muhammad (P) from Mecca to Medina in 622 AD. It is a lunar year of 354 days. The first month is called Muharram. 1996 AD is in Islamic year 1416 AH.

chunks.question: What are the major Islamic festivals?
chunks.answer: Idul Fitre marks the end of fasting in the month of Ramadan and is celebrated with public prayers, feasts and exchange of gifts. Idul Adha marks the end of the Hajj, or the annual pilgrimage to Mecca. After the public prayers, those who can afford sacrifice a lamb or a goat to signify Prophet Abraham's obedience to God, shown by his readiness to sacrifice his son Ishmael.

chunks.question: Why do Muslims sacrifice animals on Eid al-Adha?
chunks.answer: The sacrifice of animals during Eid al-Adha is a religious ritual that carries deep symbolic and spiritual meanings, along with social and humanitarian benefits. It is linked to the story of Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) and his son Ismail, where Ibrahim saw in a dream that Allah commanded him to sacrifice his son. In complete obedience and submission, he was prepared to carry out the command, but Allah stopped him and sent a ram to be sacrificed instead. This story embodies the ultimate act of obedience and the willingness to sacrifice what is dear for the sake of Allah. The purpose of the sacrifice is not the offering of meat or blood but the piety and devotion of hearts, as Allah says: "Their meat will not reach Allāh, nor will their blood, but what reaches Him is piety from you." (Quran 22:37). Islam instructs that the meat of the sacrifice should be distributed among family, relatives, and the needy, fostering social solidarity and providing the less fortunate with access to meat, which they might otherwise not afford. Through this ritual, Muslims learn to give up what is valuable for the sake of Allah and to help others, instilling values of selflessness and humility. The concept of sacrifice is not unique to Islam; it also exists in previous religions. For example, it is mentioned in the Torah: "You shall slaughter the ram, take its blood, and splash it on all sides of the altar. Then you shall cut the ram into pieces and burn it on the altar as a burnt offering to the Lord, a pleasing aroma" (Exodus 29:16-18). This demonstrates that sacrifices were also a means of expressing gratitude and obedience to God in earlier laws. The sacrifice during Eid al-Adha symbolizes complete obedience to Allah, teaches the values of selflessness and generosity, and provides an opportunity to enhance social solidarity. Islam makes this ritual a chance to elevate piety, revive moral values, and offer support to the needy, combining personal worship with communal cooperation.

chunks.question: Why is the family so important to Muslims?
chunks.answer: The family is the foundation of Islamic society. The peace and security offered by a stable family unit is greatly valued and seen as essential for the spiritual growth of its members. A harmonious social order is created by the existence of extended families; Children are treasured and rarely leave home until the time they marry.

chunks.question: How do Muslims treat the elderly?
chunks.answer: In Islam, caring for the elderly, especially one’s parents, is considered a great honor and a religious duty. Serving parents is viewed as a sacred obligation, no less important than acts of worship like prayer. Caring for them in their old age is an expression of gratitude for the sacrifices and efforts they made during one’s childhood. Raising and caring for parents is not seen as a burden but as a blessing and mercy from Allah. Mothers, in particular, hold a special status; when the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was asked, "Who is most deserving of my good company?" He replied, "Your mother." He was asked, "Then who?" He said, "Your mother." He was asked again, "Then who?" He said, "Your mother." Then he said, "Your father." When parents reach old age, Islam encourages children to treat them gently and with utmost respect, showing patience and mercy. The Quran provides clear guidance on this matter, as Allah says: "And your Lord has decreed that you worship not except Him, and to parents, good treatment. Whether one or both of them reach old age [while] with you, say not to them [so much as], "uff," and do not repel them but speak to them a noble word.And lower to them the wing of humility out of mercy and say, "My Lord, have mercy upon them as they brought me up [when I was] small" (Quran 17:23-24). In Islamic societies, nursing homes for the elderly are rare, as living with and serving parents is a fundamental family value. This care is not just a social obligation but a form of worship through which Muslims seek Allah’s pleasure, earning His blessings both in this world and the hereafter.

chunks.question: Is there equality between men and women in Islam?
chunks.answer: In Islam, men and women are equal before God in religious and legal matters. Allah says: "Indeed, the Muslim men and Muslim women, the believing men and believing women, the obedient men and obedient women, the truthful men and truthful women, the patient men and patient women..." (Al-Ahzab: 35). This means that women, like men, are equal in faith, righteous deeds, and their reward from God, without any discrimination. However, Islam assigns different roles for men and women in society based on their natural dispositions. It gives men the role of providing for and taking care of the family. This is not a privilege but a responsibility. Allah says: "Men are the protectors and maintainers of women, because Allah has given the one more (strength) than the other, and because they support them from their means..." (An- Nisa: 34). This role is not about superiority but about fulfilling duties. Men are tasked with providing and ensuring financial stability for the family, while women have a significant role in nurturing and raising the next generation. Women’s Rights in Islam:

chunks.question: Does Islam oppress women?
chunks.answer: Islam honors women and grants them rights that were unparalleled in any ancient civilization or culture. At a time when other societies regarded women as inferior or as property to be bought and sold, Islam established equality between men and women in dignity, rights, and responsibilities. Allah says: "And their Lord responded to them, 'Never will I allow to be lost the work of [any] worker among you, whether male or female; you are of one another.'" (Quran 3:195). Islam abolished horrific practices like female infanticide, which was prevalent in pre-Islamic Arabia, as Allah revealed: "And when the girl [who was] buried alive is asked For what sin she was killed.” (Quran 81:8-9). Women in Islam have the right to own and manage their property, whether before or after marriage, and retain their family names after marriage. They are not forced into marriage, as their consent is a prerequisite. Islam emphasizes the importance of education for both men and women. The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said: "Seeking knowledge is an obligation upon every Muslim." [Ibn Majah]. Islam also grants women the right to seek divorce if they face injustice or cannot continue the marriage. Women may work if they choose, provided it is within ethical boundaries, and they have full control over their earned wealth, spending it as they please. Additionally, Islam obligates men to provide for and protect women, ensuring their safety and dignity. The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "The best of you is the one who is best to his family, and I am the best among you to my family." [Reported by Al-Tirmidhi]. It is crucial to distinguish between the teachings of Islam and the practices of some Muslims. When oppression occurs, it is often due to cultural traditions or ignorance of Islamic teachings. Islam laid down clear principles to elevate women’s status and protect their rights, and any violation of these principles stems from societal or individual shortcomings. While the Western world began improving women’s rights in the 19th and 20th centuries, Islam granted these rights over 1400 years ago. Rights considered modern in Western societies, such as financial independence, education, and fair treatment, have been fundamental in Islamic teachings since the beginning. In conclusion, Islam elevated the status of women, granting them dignity, rights, and responsibilities at a time when such concepts were unheard of elsewhere. It emphasizes mercy, justice, and kindness in their treatment, as Allah commands: "And live with them in kindness." (Quran 4:19).

chunks.question: Why Does Islam Prohibit Relationships Before Marriage?
chunks.answer: In Islam, the dignity of women is held in the highest regard and is deeply respected. The Arabic word for a woman's womb, "rahm," is derived from one of Allah's names, "Ar-Rahman" (The Most Merciful), reflecting the close connection between women and their Creator, the King of kings and the Giver of life. Allah has chosen women to carry and bring life into existence, which is an honor and a noble position. In Islam, women are treated with respect and honor at every stage of their lives. If a woman is in her father's house, raising and providing for her is considered an act of worship for which the father is rewarded by Allah. If she is in her husband's house, treating her kindly and spending time with her is also considered an act of worship for which the husband is rewarded. When Islam was revealed, it granted women their rights and restored their dignity, which had been abused during pre-Islamic times. Unfortunately, this challenge persists in many societies today. One such challenge is the concept of premarital relationships. Some argue that these relationships provide freedom for women and criticize Islam and Muslims for being traditional or conservative. However, when considered rationally and objectively, which scenario is more respectful and dignified for women?

chunks.question: Why does Islam prevent Muslim women from marrying non-Muslim men?
chunks.answer: In Islam, a Muslim man is not permitted to marry a non-Muslim woman unless she is Christian or Jewish. He is not allowed to marry a woman of any other faith. However, a Muslim woman is not allowed to marry a non-Muslim man, even if he is Christian or Jewish. The reason for this is that Islam places great importance on the marital bond between a husband and wife, which must be built on a solid foundation. Allah says in the Quran: "And of His signs is that He created for you from yourselves mates that you may find tranquility in them; and He placed between you affection and mercy. Indeed in that are signs for a people who give thought" (Al-Rum: 21). When a Muslim man marries a Christian or Jewish woman, Islam commands him to respect her faith. He is not allowed to prevent her from practicing her religious rituals or from attending church or synagogue. This respectful attitude ensures the protection and stability of the family. However, when a Muslim woman marries a non-Muslim man, respect for her religion cannot be guaranteed. A Muslim believes in all prophets and respects Christianity and Judaism, whereas a non-Muslim may not believe in the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). This means a Muslim woman cannot be assured of her freedom to practice her religion, and she would have to live with a man who does not respect her faith. For example, a Muslim woman's adherence to her religious obligations could deprive her husband of some of his marital rights, such as abstaining from marital relations during fasting, which a non-Muslim husband may not accept. Additionally, she would not be able to share meals with him while fasting, travel for Hajj or Umrah without his permission, or perform her daily prayers and other voluntary acts of worship on time. Moreover, Islam places the responsibility for raising children on the father. He is the spiritual leader of the household and is responsible for teaching the children about Islam. If a Muslim woman marries a non-Muslim man, he will not be able to teach the children Islamic values or support their commitment to Islamic practices. This could result in children growing up detached from Islamic teachings, weakening both the family and the Muslim community. In other words, the wife’s adherence to her religious practices and her responsibility to educate her children in Islam could lead to conflict with a non-Muslim husband, causing instability in the marriage and family life.

chunks.question: Why is polygamy allowed in Islam?
chunks.answer: Polygamy is often misunderstood and criticized without a true understanding of its context in Islam. It is important to clarify that polygamy is neither a new phenomenon nor exclusive to Islam; it has been practiced historically across cultures and religions, including Judaism and Christianity, where it was allowed and even common. Islam did not invent polygamy but came to regulate it with strict conditions to protect women's rights and ensure justice. Before Islam, men could marry an unlimited number of women without bearing any responsibility toward them. Islam limited this to a maximum of four wives, provided that fairness and equality among them are maintained. Allah says in the Quran: "Then marry those that please you of [other] women, two, three, or four. But if you fear that you will not be just, then [marry only] one." (Surah An-Nisa: 3) If a man cannot achieve fairness, he is prohibited from having multiple wives, emphasizing that justice is a fundamental principle in Islamic law. The allowance for polygamy in Islam serves specific social and humanitarian purposes. For instance, it offers a solution for widows, divorcees, and orphans, promotes social solidarity, and addresses societal imbalances, such as a surplus of women compared to men, especially after wars. Islamic history demonstrates how polygamy was a means to provide care and protection to women who might otherwise face neglect or hardship. Critics often ignore the fact that polygamy is not unique to Islam. The Bible itself contains numerous examples of prophets who practiced polygamy, such as Abraham, Jacob, and Solomon. Furthermore, polygamy is not explicitly forbidden in the Bible, which even provides guidelines for fair treatment of multiple wives, as stated in Exodus 21:10: "If he takes another wife, he must not deprive the first one of her food, clothing, and marital rights." This demonstrates that polygamy was accepted and regulated in earlier religious traditions. Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) practiced polygamy not for personal desires but for humanitarian, religious, and political reasons. For the first 25 years of his married life, he was married to only one wife, Khadijah (may Allah be pleased with her), and did not marry anyone else until her passing. His subsequent marriages primarily aimed to care for widows, strengthen social bonds, and spread the message of Islam. Most of his wives were widows or divorcees, and each marriage had a specific purpose beyond personal gratification. In the modern era, some criticize polygamy in Islam while ignoring the prevalence of extramarital affairs and infidelity in societies that claim to uphold monogamy. Studies have shown that many women in such relationships lack legal and financial protection, with some preferring the rights and status provided by legitimate second marriages under Islamic law. Islam regulates polygamy with conditions that ensure the protection of all parties involved, contrasting sharply with the unregulated and exploitative practices found elsewhere. Polygamy is not mandatory in Islam. The majority of Muslim men choose to have only one wife, recognizing the challenges of fulfilling the necessary conditions for multiple marriages. Allah has acknowledged the difficulty of achieving perfect fairness in the Quran: "And you will never be able to be equal [in feeling] between wives, even if you should strive [to do so]." (Surah An-Nisa: 129) Ultimately, Islam does not encourage polygamy as a means of exploiting women or satisfying desires. Instead, it governs it with wisdom and conditions aimed at addressing social issues, protecting women's rights, and ensuring justice. Criticism of polygamy in Islam often stems from misunderstanding or double standards, especially when compared to the widespread prevalence of unregulated extramarital relationships in societies that claim to reject polygamy.

chunks.question: Why does Islam allow men polygamy and forbid it to women?
chunks.answer: Polyandry (a woman marrying more than one man at the same time) is strictly prohibited in Islamic law and is also rejected by other divine religions. This prohibition is not arbitrary or discriminatory but is based on rational, logical, and religious foundations aimed at protecting the family and society and ensuring their stability. Islam unequivocally prohibits polyandry, as clearly stated in the Quran: "And [prohibited to you are] married women except those your right hands possess..." (Surah An-Nisa: 24). This verse explicitly forbids a woman from being married to more than one man at the same time. Islam highly values family structure and places great emphasis on organizing marital relationships to ensure the clarity of children's lineage and the clear division of responsibilities. In Christianity, there are clear references to the exclusivity of the marital relationship between one man and one woman. For example, 1 Corinthians 7:2 states: "But because of the temptation to sexual immorality, each man should have his own wife, and each woman her own husband." This emphasizes that marriage is an exclusive covenant between one man and one woman, leaving no room for polyandry. There are several rational and logical reasons for prohibiting polyandry. First, in cases of polyandry, it becomes practically impossible to determine the biological father of children easily, leading to confusion in lineage. This can have severe psychological and social consequences for the child, as children who are unaware of their father's identity often experience mental health issues and difficulties in forming healthy social relationships. From a physiological and social perspective, men can fulfill their marital duties even if they have more than one wife. In contrast, women with multiple husbands would struggle to meet the demands of multiple marital relationships, especially due to the hormonal and psychological changes associated with their menstrual cycles and other factors. When a woman has multiple sexual partners, the likelihood of sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) increases significantly, even if all relationships are within marriage. These diseases could then spread to all husbands. On the other hand, in cases where a man has multiple wives and all relationships are confined to marriage, such risks are minimized. Polyandry disrupts the foundation of family structures, which affects the stability of society as a whole. The family is the basic unit of society, and polyandry complicates the division of roles and responsibilities within this unit, leading to social instability. Women are naturally inclined to form deep emotional bonds with one partner, while men are biologically more predisposed to polygamy. Attempts to alter this natural disposition result in psychological and behavioral imbalances, negatively impacting both genders. The prohibition of polyandry is not a restriction on women but rather a regulation aimed at protecting women and their children from psychological and social chaos. It ensures family and societal stability and reflects divine wisdom designed to achieve justice and harmony between genders.

chunks.question: Why the hijab in Islam?
chunks.answer: The hijab in Islam represents values of modesty, respect, and the preservation of a woman's dignity. It is not merely an attire but part of a comprehensive ethical system aimed at protecting society from moral decay. In Islam, the hijab balances individual rights with societal harmony, emphasizing the respect for women as whole individuals rather than objects of temptation or attraction. Islamic Perspective on Modesty: Islam calls for modesty for both men and women. Allah commands believers to lower their gaze and guard their chastity, as stated in the Quran: "Tell the believing men to reduce [some] of their vision and guard their private parts That is purer for them. Indeed, Allāh is [fully] Aware of what they do And tell the believing women to reduce [some] of their vision and guard their private parts and not expose their adornment except that which [necessarily] appears thereof and to wrap [a portion of] their headcovers over their chests..." (Surah An-Nur: 30-31). The Hijab Is Not a New Concept: What makes the hijab unique in Islam is that it is not an innovation but a continuation of the teachings of previous prophets. All divine religions have called for modesty. In the Bible, there are clear references to covering the head as a sign of respect and modesty. For example: In 1 Corinthians 11:5-6: "But every woman who prays or prophesies with her head uncovered dishonors her head..." In Genesis 24:65: "Then she took her veil and covered herself." Even Mary, the mother of Jesus—who is a symbol of purity and sanctity in both Christianity and Islam—is always depicted wearing a headscarf in images and statues. The Wisdom Behind the Hijab in Islam: The hijab reflects Islam’s respect for the nature of women and their psychological and social needs. It protects women from unwarranted gazes, granting them a sense of security and privacy. Additionally, it reminds society of the value of women as individuals, not merely their outward appearance. The concept of hijab is not a novel idea introduced by Islam; rather, it continues the divine teachings of previous prophets, organizing them to ensure human rights and dignity. Wearing the hijab symbolizes a woman’s respect for herself, her pride in her religious identity, and her adherence to Allah’s commands, serving as a means of drawing closer to Him.

chunks.question: How to respond to the verse of beating up women in the Quran?
chunks.answer: Islam addresses the verse regarding striking women in the context of organizing family relationships and resolving conflicts in a gradual manner. It begins with admonishment and wise advice as the first step. If the issue persists, the next step is to refrain from sharing the bed as a clear signal that there is a problem that needs resolution. As a final measure, light and symbolic striking is permitted, under strict guidelines, ensuring that it causes no physical or psychological harm. This has been interpreted as using very light tools, like a miswak. The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) never struck any of his wives and was a role model in treating women with kindness and respect. He said, "The best of you are those who are best to their families, and I am the best among you to my family," reflecting the ideal approach in dealing with wives. Furthermore, the imperative form used in the verse, "and strike them," in Arabic does not imply obligation but can indicate allowance or permissibility, making this action exceptional rather than a standard practice. Islam came to protect women and uphold their dignity. This verse is not a justification for violence against women; rather, it is part of a system aimed at safeguarding the family and resolving conflicts in peaceful and organized ways. Domestic violence, prevalent in many cultures, has no basis in Islamic teachings. Islam imposes strict limits to protect women from harm. The Prophet (peace be upon him) emphasized that the best men are those who treat their wives well, and he exemplified this in his life.

chunks.question: What is the role of Al-Hoor Al-'Ayn in Paradise, and how does it align with Allah's justice between men and women?
chunks.answer: Men and women have different natures that can be easily observed in daily life. Allah created humans and knows their nature and the consequences of evil. This is why He commanded believers in the Quran not to look at women in an inappropriate way and commanded women to wear modest clothing to protect them from harm and help men lower their gaze. In Islam, engaging in a sexual relationship outside of marriage is considered a major sin punishable by hellfire. Believing men who obey Allah’s commands, do not harm women, and refrain from illicit relationships are rewarded in Paradise with beautiful women (Al-Hoor Al-‘Iyn) as their wives. As for believing women, they are granted beauty far surpassing that of Al-Hoor Al-‘Iyn by seventy times. A believing woman enters Paradise as a reward for her righteous deeds, making her of a higher status than Al-Hoor Al-‘Iyn, who were created solely as a reward for the believers. Allah is the Most Just and Wise. The ultimate goal of every believer, male or female, is to attain Allah’s pleasure and enter Paradise. In Paradise, a person is granted every form of delight that no eye has seen, no ear has heard, and no mind has imagined. Allah says: 'We [angels] were your allies in worldly life and [are so] in the Hereafter. And you will have therein whatever your souls desire, and you will have therein whatever you request [or wish] as accommodation from a [Lord who is] Forgiving and Merciful.' (Fussilat 41:31-32). The status of a believing woman in Paradise is far superior to that of Al-Hoor Al-‘Iyn. She enters Paradise as a reward for her righteous deeds and is honored for her piety and commitment. In contrast, Al-Hoor Al-‘Iyn were created in Paradise solely as a reward for believers. There is a significant difference between someone who enters Paradise as a reward for their deeds and someone who was created as a reward for others. The believing woman is a queen and lady in Paradise, while Al-Hoor Al-‘Iyn, no matter how beautiful, are of a lower status than the queen.

chunks.question: What is the wisdom behind circumcision in Islam?
chunks.answer: Circumcision in Islam and the Bible Circumcision is a practice related to religious commitment and is part of the covenant between God and His servants in many religions, including Islam and Christianity. Circumcision in the Bible: In the Bible, circumcision is clearly mentioned as part of the covenant between God and His people. In the Old Testament, it is referred to as a sign of the covenant that God made with Abraham and his descendants. In Genesis 17:9-14, God says to Abraham: "This is my covenant, which you shall keep, between me and you and your descendants after you: every male among you shall be circumcised... Any uncircumcised male who is not circumcised in the flesh of his foreskin shall be cut off from his people; he has broken my covenant." This verse makes it clear that circumcision was a fundamental sign of the covenant with God and was seen as an essential requirement for maintaining that relationship with God. Circumcision in Islam: In Islam, circumcision is considered a Sunnah of Fitrah (natural practice), representing cleanliness and purification. It is seen as an act of maintaining bodily purity. The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) mentioned it in many sayings, encouraging circumcision as part of personal hygiene. A well- known hadith states: "Five practices are part of the Fitrah: circumcision, shaving the pubic hair, trimming the mustache, cutting the nails, and plucking the armpit hair." Why is circumcision practiced in Islam?

chunks.question: What is the Islamic view on abortion, homosexuality and AIDS, euthanasia and suicide, and organ transplantation?
chunks.answer: a. Abortion: Islam considers abortion as murder and does not permit it except to save the mother's life. Allah says: 'Do not kill your children out of poverty; We will provide for you and them.' (Quran 6:151, interpreted alongside 17:31). b. Homosexuality and AIDS: Islam categorically opposes homosexuality and considers it a sin. However, Muslim physicians are advised to care for AIDS patients with compassion just as they would for other patients. c. Euthanasia and Suicide: Islam is opposed to both euthanasia and suicide. Muslims do not believe in heroic measures to prolong the misery of a terminally ill patient. d. Organ transplantation: Islam stresses saving lives. Allah says: 'Whoever kills a soul unless for a soul or for corruption [done] in the land—it is as if he had slain mankind entirely.' (Quran 5:32). Thus, transplantation in general would be considered permissible in necessity provided a donor consent is available. The sale of the organ is not allowed.

chunks.question: How does Islam address the issue of racism and nationalism?
chunks.answer: " Islam teaches us that all humans were created from the same origin, clay, which means there is no justification for anyone to consider themselves superior to another. We are all created from the same components, regardless of our cultural or racial differences. In the sight of Allah, superiority is not based on skin color or race but on righteous deeds and piety. The differences in races and cultures in Islam are not a means of division or discrimination but a way for people to know and understand one another. Allah says: "O mankind, indeed We have created you from male and female and made you peoples and tribes that you may know one another. Indeed, the most noble of you in the sight of Allah is the most righteous of you. Indeed, Allāh is Knowing and Aware." (Quran 49:13). This diversity is a blessing from Allah and part of His creative magnificence, as He says: "And of His signs is the creation of the heavens and the earth and the diversity of your languages and your colors. Indeed in that are signs for those of knowledge." (Quran 30:22). The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) emphasized this principle of equality in his farewell sermon, saying: "O people, your Lord is One, and your father is one. There is no superiority of an Arab over a non-Arab, nor a non-Arab over an Arab, nor of a white over a Black, nor a Black over a white, except by piety. Have I not conveyed the message?" (Musnad Ahmad). Islam strictly prohibits boasting about one’s race or culture at the expense of others. The Prophet (peace be upon him) warned against tribalism and said, "He is not one of us who calls for tribalism, or fights for tribalism, or dies for tribalism." (Sunan Abu Dawood). Islam rejects all forms of racism and nationalism. It teaches that all people are equal before Allah and that true virtue lies in piety and good deeds, not in racial or cultural affiliations.

chunks.question: How does Islam guarantee human rights?
chunks.answer: Islam establishes a solid foundation for ensuring human rights at all levels, emphasizing human dignity, justice, and freedom. The Qur'an clearly declares the principle of freedom of belief, as Allah says: "There shall be no compulsion in [acceptance of] the religion." (Qur'an 2:256), meaning that the choice of religion and faith is a personal right safeguarded without coercion. Islam protects human life and property, considering them sacred regardless of religion or ethnicity. Allah says: "And whoever saves one[260] - it is as if he had saved mankind entirely." (Qur'an 5:32), reflecting the importance of preserving human life. Islam upholds the principle of equality among people and encourages cooperation and mutual understanding between nations and communities. Allah says: "O mankind, indeed We have created you from male and female and made you peoples and tribes that you may know one another. Indeed, the most noble of you in the sight of Allāh is the most righteous[1521] of you. Indeed, Allāh is Knowing and Aware." (Qur'an 49:13), emphasizing that superiority is not based on lineage or race but on piety and righteous deeds. In an Islamic state, the rights of religious minorities are safeguarded, and their beliefs are respected. Everyone is treated with fairness and equality. Justice is a fundamental principle of governance in Islam, as Allah says: "Indeed, Allāh orders justice and good conduct and giving [help] to relatives." (Qur'an 16:90). Islam not only preserves individual rights but also encourages societal cooperation to achieve collective good, emphasizing mercy and mutual respect in human relationships.

chunks.question: Is Islam Intolerant of Other Religious Minorities?
chunks.answer: Islam recognizes the rights of religious minorities and ensures their protection and care within the framework of an Islamic state. The Quran emphasizes tolerance and justice toward those who do not oppose Islam, as Allah says: "Allah does not forbid you from those who do not fight you because of religion and do not expel you from your homes—from being righteous toward them and acting justly toward them. Indeed, Allah loves those who act justly." (Surah Al- Mumtahanah: 8). The Quran also declares: "There shall be no compulsion in [acceptance of] the religion." (Surah Al-Baqarah: 256). Islam guarantees the protection of religious minorities and their places of worship, such as churches and synagogues. For example, when Caliph Umar ibn Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) entered Jerusalem in 634 CE, he granted safety to all inhabitants and respected their freedom of worship. He even refused to pray inside the Church of the Holy Sepulchre out of respect for its status as a Christian place of worship. To protect minorities, Islam imposed the jizya, a symbolic tax in exchange for protection and exemption from military service, without forcing non- Muslims to change their religion. Islamic history is rich with examples of peaceful coexistence with religious minorities. During the Golden Age of Al-Andalus, Jews and Christians flourished under Islamic rule. Jews, in particular, enjoyed security and played significant roles in cultural and political life, while they faced persecution in other parts of Europe. Similarly, in other parts of the Islamic world, non-Muslims were granted the right to establish their own courts and apply their family laws. While Islam has a long history of protecting minorities, Muslims have not always been afforded the same tolerance in other societies. During the Spanish Inquisition, Muslims and Jews faced forced conversions and severe persecution. During the Crusades, Muslims faced massacres. In modern times, Muslim minorities continue to face discrimination and oppression in places like Bosnia and India. Islam calls for justice, coexistence, and respect toward religious minorities. Islamic history and Quranic teachings provide clear examples of these humanitarian values in practice.

chunks.question: Does Islam promote violence and terrorism?
chunks.answer: Islam is a religion of peace and mercy, and it rejects terrorism in all its forms. Killing is considered one of the gravest sins in Islam. The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said: “The first cases to be adjudicated among people on the Day of Judgment will be those of bloodshed.” The Quran emphasizes fairness and justice, even towards non-Muslims, as it states: “Allāh does not forbid you from those who do not fight you because of religion and do not expel you from your homes - from being righteous toward them and acting justly toward them. Indeed, Allāh loves those who act justly.” (Quran 60:8). Islam categorically rejects unjust violence and the killing of innocents. The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: “Whoever kills a person who has a treaty with the Muslims shall not smell the fragrance of Paradise” (Reported by Bukhari). The Quran affirms the sanctity of human life, declaring: “whoever kills a soul unless for a soul or for corruption [done] in the land - it is as if he had slain mankind entirely. And whoever saves one - it is as if he had saved mankind entirely. And Our messengers had certainly come to them with clear proofs. Then indeed many of them, [even] after that, throughout the land, were transgressors” (Quran 5:32). Since the dawn of Islam, killing women, children, monks, and non-combatants has been prohibited, with strict rules preventing aggression during warfare. The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: “Do not kill an elderly person, a child, or a woman” (Reported by Abu Dawood). Jihad in Islam is not synonymous with terrorism. It refers to the struggle against evil within oneself and society. Jihad includes self-improvement, spreading goodness, resisting oppression, and defending oneself when necessary. It does not involve killing innocents or committing acts of terror. The Quran states: “Fight in the way of Allāh those who fight against you but do not transgress. Indeed, Allāh does not like transgressors. ” (Quran 2:190). Regarding violence in other religious texts, the Bible contains passages that explicitly call for killing, such as: “Now kill all the boys. And kill every woman who has slept with a man” (Numbers 31:17-18) and “Kill the old men, the young men and women, the mothers, and the children” (Ezekiel 9:6). These verses show direct orders for violence against vulnerable groups, raising questions about why such texts are overlooked when discussing terrorism. Throughout history, the most horrific mass atrocities were not committed in the name of Islam. For example, Joseph Stalin killed 20 million people, and Mao Zedong killed between 14 to 20 million people. The two World Wars claimed over 70 million lives, and none of the perpetrators were Muslim. Similarly, the Crusades carried out in the name of the Church led to the deaths of hundreds of thousands, while the atomic bombs in Hiroshima and Nagasaki killed hundreds of thousands. As for extremist groups like ISIS and Boko Haram, they do not represent Islam in any way. Their actions directly contradict the clear teachings of Islam, which call for peace and justice. Allah says: “There shall be no compulsion in [acceptance of] the religion” (Quran 2:256), and “whoever kills a soul unless for a soul[258] or for corruption [done] in the land[259] - it is as if he had slain mankind entirely.” (Quran 5:32). Islam calls for the rejection of violence and condemns terrorism, regardless of the perpetrator’s identity.

chunks.question: Was Islam spread by the sword?
chunks.answer: The Quran clearly states that faith cannot be imposed by force. As Allah says: "There shall be no compulsion in [acceptance of] the religion." (Quran 2:256). This verse establishes a fundamental principle in Islam, prohibiting any coercion in matters of faith. It is true that Islamic armies carried swords during some conquests, but this was for defensive purposes or to liberate people from oppression, not to force them to embrace Islam. At that time, the sword was the standard weapon for defense and warfare. However, the spread of Islam was not tied to the use of force. Many regions that became predominantly Muslim, such as Indonesia, China, and large parts of Africa, were never reached by Islamic armies. Instead, Islam spread in these areas through trade and peaceful preaching. The claim that Islam spread by the sword can be refuted with a simple comparison. If this claim were true, why have religious minorities in Muslim-majority countries remained on their own faiths? For example, today, approximately 10% of the population in the Arab world are Christians. Additionally, in India, where Muslims ruled for 700 years, the majority of the population remains Hindu, as they were not forcibly converted to Islam. If the spread of a religion is assumed to be through force, we might ask: Did Christianity spread through guns or bombs? Certainly not. Christianity spread through missionary efforts. Similarly, Islam is spreading in the modern world through peaceful preaching. It is currently the fastest-growing religion in the United States, with over 6 million followers, without any military intervention. In conclusion, the spread of Islam was not achieved by the sword but through peaceful means, such as preaching, trade, and ethical interactions with people. Claims to the contrary are inconsistent with historical facts and the true nature of Islam as a religion that promotes peace and freedom.

chunks.question: Who is Jesus in Islam?
chunks.answer: 10 Facts About Jesus The Story of Jesus Jesus (peace be upon him) is one of the noble prophets sent by God to guide humanity to the worship of God alone. In Islam, Jesus (peace be upon him) is not considered divine nor the son of God, but rather a messenger, like all other prophets, calling to monotheism.
