Allah says: "The Messiah, Jesus the son of Mary, was but a messenger of Allāh and His word which He directed to Mary and a soul [created at a command] from Him." (Quran, 4:171) The birth of Jesus (peace be upon him) was a miraculous event, as he was born to the Virgin Mary without a father. Allah says: "And We made the son of Mary and his mother a sign" (Quran, 23:50) Islam rejects the idea of Jesus being divine or the son of God because God does not require children or partners. Allah says: "The Messiah, son of Mary, was not but a messenger; [other] messengers have passed on before him. And his mother was a supporter of truth" (Quran, 5:75) "Indeed, Allāh is but one God. Exalted is He above having a son" (Quran, 4:171) Jesus (peace be upon him) performed many miracles by God's permission, such as healing the sick, giving sight to the blind, and even bringing the dead back to life. Allah says: "And I cure the blind [from birth] and the leper, and I give life to the dead - by permission of Allāh." (Quran, 3:49) These miracles were a testament to his truthfulness as a prophet and messenger of God. Islam also teaches that Jesus (peace be upon him) was neither crucified nor killed. Instead, Allah saved him and raised him to heaven. Allah says: "And they did not kill him, nor did they crucify him; but [another] was made to resemble him to them. And indeed, those who differ over it are in doubt about it.." (Quran, 4:157) Jesus (peace be upon him) will return at the end of times to reaffirm the message of monotheism. Jesus (peace be upon him) preached repentance and worship of God alone. Islam reaffirms his pure and original message, which was to call humanity to the worship of the One True God without intermediaries or partners. Allah says: "[Jesus said], "And indeed, Allāh is my Lord and your Lord, so worship Him. That is a straight path" (Quran, 19:36).

chunks.question: Is Jesus the Son of God?
chunks.answer: The Christian belief that Jesus is the Son of God contradicts several texts in the Bible and logic. Let's examine the evidence showing that Jesus cannot be the Son of God in terms of divinity. The Bible mentions many "sons of God," not just Jesus. For instance, in Exodus 4:22, God says, "Israel is my firstborn son." In Psalm 89:26-27, it says, "I have chosen David as my firstborn son." In Deuteronomy 32:19, God speaks of "His sons and daughters." In 2 Samuel 7:14, He says, "I will be his Father, and he shall be My son." Similarly, angels are called "sons of God" in Job 38:7, and the term also refers to righteous people, such as Solomon and David in 2 Samuel 7:13-14. Therefore, the term "Son of God" refers to a special relationship or a high status, not divinity. It's noteworthy that Jesus often refers to Himself as the "Son of Man" rather than the "Son of God." For example, in Mark's Gospel, the term "Son of God" is used zero times, but "Son of Man" is used 13 times. In Matthew, "Son of God" is used zero times, and "Son of Man" appears 30 times. Similarly, in Luke, "Son of God" is used zero times, but "Son of Man" appears 25 times. When asked directly in Luke 22:70, "Are you the Son of God?" Jesus does not confirm but replies, "You say that I am He." This shows that Jesus did not explicitly call Himself the Son of God. In several verses, Jesus shows that He is fully human, not divine. In John 8:40, He says, "I am a man who has told you the truth that I heard from God." In Matthew 26:39, He prays, "My Father, if it is possible, may this cup be taken from me. Yet not as I will, but as you will." Some might argue that Jesus being born without a father makes Him the Son of God, but this logic fails when we consider Adam, who was created without a father or mother. In Quran 3:59, it says, "Indeed, the example of Jesus to Allah is like that of Adam. He created him from dust; then He said to him, 'Be,' and he was." The Bible also mentions Melchizedek, who had no father, mother, or genealogy, and is said to be "like the Son of God" in Hebrews 7:1-3. Does this mean Melchizedek is also divine? This shows that the absence of a father does not equate to divinity. Islam emphasizes that Jesus is a Messenger of God, not the Son of God. He is the Word of God in the flesh, as stated in the Quran. Jesus performed miracles, but these were done by God's permission, not as a result of His own divinity. Thus, the term "Son of God" is metaphorical, referring to righteous people and prophets, and does not imply divinity

chunks.question: Is Christ the Lord?
chunks.answer: Jesus admits that he cannot do anything by himself, indicating his dependence on God and denying his divinity. In John 14:28, it states, "For my Father is greater than I." This verse confirms that Jesus is not God, as God cannot be lesser than himself. In Matthew 24:36, Jesus says, "But about that day or hour no one knows, not even the angels in heaven, nor the Son, but only the Father." Jesus's ignorance of the hour is clear proof that he is not all-knowing, a characteristic unique to God. In John 20:17, Jesus refers to God as "My God," which raises the question, if Jesus were God, how could he refer to God as "My God"? Additionally, in John 1:18, it is written, "No one has ever seen God." Yet, people saw and touched Jesus, proving he is not God. Jesus clearly acknowledges that he is a human being sent by God in John 8:40: "But now you seek to kill me, a man who has told you the truth that I heard from God." Jesus repeatedly refers to himself as the "Son of Man," affirming his humanity, as seen in Mark 2:10: "But I want you to know that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins." In Numbers 23:19, it is stated, "God is not a man, that He should lie, nor a son of man, that He should change His mind." This directly refutes the divinity of Jesus, who is repeatedly called the "Son of Man." In Malachi 3:6, God says, "I the Lord do not change." If God became human, this would represent a change in His nature, contradicting the immutable nature of God. The Bible teaches that Jesus died in Mark 15:37: "And Jesus cried out with a loud voice and gave up his spirit," yet God is eternal and cannot die, as stated in 1 Timothy 1:17: "To the King eternal, immortal, invisible, the only God, be honor and glory forever and ever." In Mark 13:32, it says, "But about that day or hour no one knows, not even the angels in heaven, nor the Son, but only the Father." If Jesus does not know the hour, he cannot be all-knowing, a defining characteristic of God. Additionally, in James 1:13, it is written, "For God cannot be tempted by evil, nor does he tempt anyone," yet the Bible states that Jesus was tempted by Satan: "Then Jesus was led by the Spirit into the wilderness to be tempted by the devil" (Matthew 4:1). Bart Ehrman pointed out that the divinity of Jesus was not originally part of his teachings but rather developed in later centuries. His book "How Jesus Became God" explains that the idea of Jesus's divinity was a product of theological evolution over time. John Hick asserted that miracles are not evidence of divinity, as earlier prophets performed great miracles without anyone claiming they were gods. The Arians and other early Christian sects rejected the idea that Jesus was God. They regarded him as a great prophet and messenger of God. In Islam, Jesus is regarded as a servant and messenger of God, as stated in the Quran: "The Messiah would never disdain to be a servant of Allah" (Surah An-Nisa: 172). The miracles performed by Jesus, such as raising the dead and healing the sick, were by God’s permission, as stated in Surah Al-Ma'idah: 110: "And when you brought forth the dead with My permission." Islam emphasizes the absolute oneness of God, with no partners or equals, as seen in Surah Aal-E-Imran: 51: "Indeed, Allah is my Lord and your Lord, so worship Him. That is the straight path."

chunks.question: Is the doctrine of the Trinity explicitly mentioned in the Bible?
chunks.answer: The doctrine of the Trinity, which claims that God consists of three persons: the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit, contradicts both clear biblical texts and logic. The Bible explicitly states that God is one, as mentioned in Isaiah: "I am the first, and I am the last; apart from me there is no God." (Isaiah 44:6), and confirms: "I am the Lord; that is my name! I will not yield my glory to another." (Isaiah 42:8). These verses refute the concept of the Trinity and affirm the monotheism advocated by Islam: "Say, He is Allah, [Who is] One." (Al-Ikhlas: 1). The Bible also asserts that God is not a human being, as stated in Numbers: "God is not human, that he should lie, not a human being, that he should change his mind." (Numbers 23:19), while Jesus himself says: "I am a man who has told you the truth that I heard from God." (John 8:40). This distinction between God and Jesus is further supported by the Bible's declaration: "I, the Lord, do not change." (Malachi 3:6). If God does not change, how could He become a human? This contradicts the idea of divine incarnation. The Bible describes God as a spirit, as in John: "God is spirit." (John 4:24), whereas Jesus said: "A spirit does not have flesh and bones, as you see I have." (Luke 24:39). This clearly demonstrates that Jesus is not a spirit and therefore cannot be part of God. The only verse that explicitly supports the Trinity: "For there are three that bear record in heaven: the Father, the Word, and the Holy Spirit; and these three are one." (1 John 5:7) has been proven to be a later addition and is absent in earlier manuscripts. In Matthew, Jesus said: "No one knows the Son except the Father." (Matthew 11:27), which excludes the Holy Spirit's knowledge of the Father. Furthermore, in Mark: "But about that day or hour no one knows, not even the angels in heaven, nor the Son, but only the Father." (Mark 13:32), which raises the question: How can the Holy Spirit be God if it is unaware of the hour? Passages often cited to support the Trinity, such as Jesus' baptism in Matthew: "As soon as Jesus was baptized, he went up out of the water. At that moment heaven was opened, and he saw the Spirit of God descending like a dove and alighting on him." (Matthew 3:16), do not prove the Trinity. The presence of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit simultaneously does not imply they are one. Similarly, the plural form is used in Genesis: "Then God said, ‘Let us make mankind in our image, in our likeness.’" (Genesis 1:26) is a form of reverential language, not evidence of multiplicity. If Jesus were God, why did he say: "But about that day or hour no one knows, not even the angels in heaven, nor the Son, but only the Father." (Mark 13:32)? And if he was sent only to the Israelites, as he said: "I was sent only to the lost sheep of Israel." (Matthew 15:24), how can he be God for all humanity? These questions, along with the verses affirming God's oneness and denying His humanity or having partners, reveal the inconsistency of the Trinity with both the Bible and logic. Islam provides a clear concept of God: "Allah—there is no deity except Him, the Ever-Living, the Self-Sustaining" (Al-Baqarah: 255).

chunks.question: Is Jesus, peace be upon him, Muslim?
chunks.answer: To understand whether Jesus lived according to principles aligned with Islam, it's important first to consider how he expressed his reverence and relationship with God and how he worshiped and followed the teachings. Reason and logic compel us to search the texts to extract truths without bias. Let's look at the evidence from the Gospels that suggests Jesus lived a life reflecting the core of Islam, which is the oneness of God and submission to God's will. In the Gospels, Jesus demonstrates a deep commitment to prayer, which is a fundamental part of worship in Islam: Jesus Praying on the Mountain: In Matthew (14:23), it is recorded, "After he had dismissed them, he went up on a mountainside by himself to pray. When evening came, he was there alone." Jesus isolates himself for prayer, a practice similar to Muslims who are dedicated to praying at specific times. Jesus Praying in Gethsemane: Matthew (26:39) describes how Jesus prayed, saying, "Going a little farther, he fell with his face to the ground and prayed, 'My Father, if it is possible, may this cup be taken from me. Yet not as I will, but as you will.'" Jesus prostrates with his face to the ground in a position that resembles the prostration in Islamic prayer. The description of Mary's attire in the Bible reflects the modesty followed by Muslim women: Mary's Head Covering: Although there is no direct mention of Mary's veil in the Gospels, traditional artistic depictions of Mary always show her wearing a head covering, reflecting her association with virtue and modesty, which aligns with Islamic values.

chunks.question: Why Jesus will return and Muhammad died and will not return?
chunks.answer: The difference in the missions of Jesus and Muhammad (peace be upon him) can be explained according to the roles each was assigned according to their religious beliefs. Jesus, according to both Islamic and Christian doctrine, did not complete his mission entirely due to his ascension to heaven and the promise of his return to complete it. On the other hand, the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) completed his message by delivering the Holy Quran as a comprehensive guide and the seal of the prophethood. He declared before his death that the religion of Islam had been completed and that God had perfected His grace upon the believers; thus there is no need for his return to complete a mission because he already fulfilled it. In the Bible, it is clearly stated that Jesus will return. For example, in the Acts of the Apostles (1:11), the angels say to the disciples, "Men of Galilee, why do you stand looking into the sky? This Jesus, who has been taken up from you into heaven, will come back in the same way as you have seen him go into heaven." This prophecy reinforces the idea of his awaited return, which is an integral part of Christian doctrine. Islam asserts that Jesus (Isa, peace be upon him) is one of God's prophets, not a deity nor the son of God, and acknowledges that he was raised to heaven and will return at the end of times to break the cross, kill the pig, denounce idol worship and polytheism, and affirm the worship of the one God. Islam considers this return as a correction of the misconceptions about his personality and teachings that were misunderstood by some. His return represents the unification of the heavenly religions under the banner of monotheism and Islam.

chunks.question: Why does Islam not consider crucifixion and atonement necessary for the salvation of humanity?
chunks.answer: The doctrine of salvation, which claims that Christ was crucified for the sins of mankind, faces several challenges from an Islamic perspective and even within the Bible itself. First, Islam emphasizes that God is the Most Forgiving and Most Merciful. He forgives sins through sincere repentance without the need for intermediaries or sacrifices. Allah says in the Quran: 'No bearer of burdens will bear the burden of another.' (Quran 6:164), meaning that every individual is accountable for their own actions. In the Bible, there is evidence supporting this principle. For instance, in Ezekiel: 'The soul who sins is the one who will die.' (Ezekiel 18:20), and in Deuteronomy: 'Parents are not to be put to death for their children, nor children put to death for their parents.' (Deuteronomy 24:16). These texts reject the idea that one person bears the sins of another. Second, the Bible itself shows that sins were forgiven before the arrival of Jesus through sincere repentance. In the Gospel of Mark: 'And so John the Baptist appeared in the wilderness, preaching a baptism of repentance for the forgiveness of sins.' (Mark 1:4-5). If sins could be forgiven before Jesus, why was his crucifixion necessary? Third, the notion that God needs a sacrifice to erase sins contradicts His attributes as a complete and self-sufficient deity. In Islam, God does not require bloodshed for forgiveness but rather forgives through repentance and mercy. Even in the Bible, it says: 'Let the wicked forsake their ways... and turn to the Lord, and he will have mercy on them.' (Isaiah 55:7). Fourth, the Bible contains contradictions regarding the concept of atonement. If Jesus came to be crucified for humanity's sins, why do we find passages depicting him fleeing from death? In the Gospel of John: 'They picked up stones to stone him, but Jesus hid himself, slipping away from the temple grounds.' (John 8:59). And in Matthew: 'My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?' (Matthew 27:46), which reflects a rejection of the crucifixion. In conclusion, the doctrine of salvation seems inconsistent with God's justice and mercy, as well as with texts that emphasize individual accountability and the sufficiency of repentance for the forgiveness of sins.

chunks.question: How can the concept of atonement and sacrifice in Christianity align with divine justice?
chunks.answer: The concept of divine love and sacrifice, particularly in John 3:16, has often been questioned on logical grounds. Divine justice requires that every individual bear responsibility for their own actions, so how can God punish an innocent person (Christ) for the sins of others? Punishing someone else for another’s sin is illogical and unethical. Islam provides a rational and consistent understanding: God forgives sins directly without the need for mediation or sacrifice. Divine forgiveness in Islam does not require complex conditions; it is based on sincere repentance and devotion, reflecting both mercy and justice. Other passages in the Bible indicate that there are many 'sons of God.' For example, 'For all who are led by the Spirit of God are sons of God' (Romans 8:14) and 'Blessed are the peacemakers, for they shall be called sons of God' (Matthew 5:9), showing that 'Son of God' can refer to a spiritual relationship, not literal only-ness. Islam emphasizes God’s infinite love and mercy. Allah says: 'My mercy encompasses all things' (Quran 7:156) and 'Indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Merciful' (Quran 2:173). The Quran explicitly denies the event of the crucifixion: 'And they did not kill him, nor did they crucify him; but [another] was made to resemble him to them' (Quran 4:157). Allah also states: 'And no bearer of burdens will bear the burden of another' (Quran 6:164), affirming individual accountability. Forgiveness in Islam is achieved through repentance and righteous deeds, not through the sacrifice of an innocent person, which aligns with divine justice and logic.

chunks.question: 2. Who is Jesus?
chunks.answer:
In Islam, Jesus is seen as one of the mightiest prophets and messengers of God. Known as 'Isa' in Arabic, he is revered
for his teachings of love, compassion, humility, and righteousness. Muslims believe that he was born to the Virgin Mary
through a miraculous birth that transcends human understanding. However, they reject the Christian belief that he is the
Son of God or part of a Trinity. Instead, they regard him only as a human being who was sent by God to guide humanity
towards the path of righteousness. According to Islamic scripture, Jesus performed several miracles during his lifetime
such as healing the blind and raising the dead - all through God's power. In fact, Muslims believe that Jesus will return in
the end times to restore justice to the world and defeat evil forces. Jesus holds a pivotal position in Islam - his messages
have been an integral part of shaping Muslim beliefs and practices until today.
Jesus, also known as Isa, is a highly respected and revered figure in Islam. He is considered to be one of
the greatest prophets of God, alongside Adam, Abraham, Moses, and Muhammad. Muslims believe that
Jesus was sent by God as a messenger to guide humanity towards the path of righteousness.
Islamic accounts of Jesus’ life differ from those found in the New Testament. While both accounts agree
that Jesus was born of a virgin, Muslims believe that he was not actually crucified, but rather raised
bodily into heaven by God. This belief is based on the Qur’an, which states that “they killed him not, nor
crucified him, but it appeared so unto them” (Surah An-Nisa 4:157).
Muslims also believe that Jesus performed numerous miracles during his life, through the power of
Allah. These miracles included healing the blind and lepers, raising the dead, and even creating life from
clay. According to Islamic tradition, Jesus accomplished these miraculous feats in order to demonstrate
the power of God to the people.
In addition to performing miracles, Jesus also taught extensively about the nature of God and the
importance of living a virtuous life. He stressed the need to love and respect one another, and to treat
each other with kindness and compassion. He also emphasized the importance of worshiping and
following God, and of practicing good deeds and avoiding evil behavior.
Overall, Jesus is highly regarded in Islam as a prophet and messenger of God, who was sent to guide
humanity towards the path of righteousness. His teachings and miracles continue to serve as an
inspiration and guide for Muslims today, who seek to live according to the principles of love,
compassion, and righteousness that he espoused.

chunks.question: 3. what's Islam?
chunks.answer:
Islam is based on five pillars that serve as the foundation for its practice: belief in the Oneness of God and his
Prophets, performance of prayer five times a day, giving of alms to those in need, fasting during Ramadan, and
performing pilgrimage to Mecca at least once in a lifetime if able. Islam places great emphasis on social justice
and moral values such as honesty, kindness, compassion and respect for one's parents, neighbors and fellow
human beings. Muslims aspire to live their lives according to Islamic teachings with love for God being at its
very core.
Islam is one of the fastest-growing religions in the world, with over 1.8 billion followers globally. It is a monotheistic faith
practiced by Muslims worldwide, which is based on the teachings of the prophet Muhammad, who is considered the last
and final prophet sent by God. Islam is best understood as a way of life that governs every aspect of an individual's life
and encourages adherents to behave ethically and morally.
Islam is derived from the Arabic word 'salam,' which means peace, submission, and surrender to God. The essence of
Islam is to submit oneself to the will of God and to follow His commandments set forth in the holy book of Islam, the
Quran. Muslims believe that the Quran is the literal word of God, revealed to the prophet Muhammad through the
archangel Gabriel. The Quran is the primary source of guidance for both personal and community life for Muslims
worldwide.
In Islam, there is no God but Allah, and Muhammad is His messenger. Muslims believe in the Oneness of God and that
He is the Creator of everything in existence. They also believe in the Day of Judgment and that every person will be
accountable for their actions in this life. They also believe that Prophet Muhammad gave guidance to Muslims by his
behaviors and teachings, known as Hadith.
Islam respects the importance of the family, and it encourages marriage and family life. Family is considered the
cornerstone of society, and both men and women have specific roles and responsibilities within the family. Women are
regarded as the backbone of the family, and it is their primary responsibility to raise children and maintain the
household. Men are encouraged to provide for their families and protect them.
Five pillars of Islam are the core of the faith and provide a framework for religious practice. They include:
1. Shahada: Affirming that there is no god but Allah and that Muhammad is His messenger.
2. Salat: Performing five daily prayers.
3. Zakat: Giving to the needy and poor.
4. Sawm: Fasting during the month of Ramadan.
5. Hajj: Making the pilgrimage to Mecca at least once in a lifetime for those who are financially and physically able.
In summary, Islam is a religion that emphasizes commitment to Allah, the creator, and to living a righteous and fulfilling
life. It provides guidance on personal relationships, family life, and societal behaviors. The religion has a rich history, and
its followers continue to put its core values into practice.

chunks.question: 4. What do you think about trinity?
chunks.answer:
Islam strictly rejects the concept of the Trinity, which is the Christian belief that there are three co-equal persons
in one Godhead- the Father, the Son (Jesus), and the Holy Spirit. Muslims firmly believe in Monotheism which
asserts that there is only one God who governs this universe. In Islam, associating partners with Allah (Shirk) is
a great sin and ascribing divine attributes to anyone other than Allah is considered blasphemy. The Quran
emphasizes that Allah has no progeny or associates and affirms His Oneness throughout several verses. Hence,
according to Islamic beliefs, any form of polytheism or tritheism is considered unacceptable and goes against
Tawheed (Oneness of God).
Islam rejects the concept of Trinity, which is the belief that God is three persons in one: Father, Son, and
Holy Spirit. This doctrine is an essential tenet of Christianity, but for Muslims, it contradicts the core
principle of monotheism, the oneness of God. Islam teaches that God is one and indivisible, and that
associating partners with Him is the gravest sin. Thus, the notion of a triune God is seen as a form of
idolatry and blasphemy.
The Quran strongly condemns the notion of Trinity and refutes it explicitly. The Quran says, "Say not
'Three' (Trinity): Desist, it will be better for you: For Allah is One God." (4:171). This verse emphasizes
the oneness of Allah and negates the idea of a plurality of persons in Godhead. It puts an end to any
speculation regarding the Trinity as a divine mystery.
Moreover, the Quran highlights the semantic ambiguity of the term Trinity, which may lead to different
interpretations. The word "Trinity" is not found in the Bible. It was coined by theologians to express the
complex relationship between God, Jesus, and the Holy Spirit. However, this concept has led to
divisions and disputes among Christians themselves, particularly between the Eastern and Western
churches.
Islam, on the other hand, believes in the absolute unity and simplicity of God. He is not composed of
parts or attributes that can be divided or shared. Therefore, attributing partners to God contradicts the
very essence of divine transcendence and uniqueness.
Furthermore, the Islamic view of Jesus Christ as a prophet and messenger of God is different from the
Christian notion of him as the Son of God. Muslims believe in the virgin birth of Jesus but reject the idea
of his divinity or equal status with Allah. Instead, they see him as a human being who was chosen by
God to deliver his message to humanity.
In conclusion, Islam considers the Trinity as a theological error that distorts the doctrine of monotheism.
Muslims believe in the absolute oneness of God, and any attempt to associate partners with Him is a sin.
The Quran refutes the notion of a triune God and emphasizes the simplicity and unity of Allah. Therefore,
the Islamic perspective on the Trinity is a clear expression of its unwavering commitment to the belief in
one God.

chunks.question: 5. Is Jesus son of God?
chunks.answer:
In Islam, Jesus is not considered to be the son of God. Instead, he is regarded as a prophet and messenger of
Allah, sent to guide humanity towards the right path. Islamic beliefs hold that Allah's oneness cannot be shared
by others in the form of children or partners. While Muslims revere Jesus and his teachings, they reject the idea
of him being divine or having any association with God in terms of kinship. The Quran emphasizes that believing
in the Trinity or Jesus' divinity is a grave sin against monotheism. Additionally, Muslims believe that Jesus was
not crucified but instead raised directly to heaven by God, and that someone else was mistakenly executed in his
place. Overall, while recognizing and respecting Jesus' significance as a prophet in their faith, Muslims do not
consider him God's son or part of a divine trinity.
In Islam, Jesus is considered as a highly respected and significant prophet who delivered the message
of Allah to humanity. However, the concept of Jesus as the son of God is not accepted in Islam. The
Quran explicitly denies the notion that God has any offspring, and thus, Jesus is not considered God's
son in Islam.
Muslims believe in Tawhid, the concept of the oneness of God. It is one of the fundamental beliefs of
Islam, and the Quran emphasizes this by stating, "Say, He is Allah, the One and Only; Allah, the Eternal,
Absolute; He neither begets nor is born, and there is nothing like Him" (112:1-4). This verse clearly
negates the idea of God having a son or offspring, and hence it is not acceptable for Muslims to believe
in Jesus as the son of God.
Moreover, the Quran mentions the birth of Jesus, which was miraculous, as he was born to Mary, without
any male involvement. Allah says in the Quran, "And [mention] when the angels said, 'O Mary, indeed
Allah has chosen you and purified you and chosen you above the women of the worlds. O Mary, be
devoutly obedient to your Lord and prostrate and bow with those who bow [in prayer].' That is from the
news of the unseen which We reveal to you, [O Muhammad]. And you were not with them when they cast
their pens as to which of them should be responsible for Mary. Nor were you with them when they
disputed" (3:42-44). The Quran acknowledges Jesus' miraculous birth by the will of God but never
suggests that he is the son of God.
The Islamic belief in Jesus is that he was a messenger of God sent to preach the message of Islam, just
like other prophets. He delivered the message of submission to God, emphasizing that there is no deity
worthy of worship except Allah. This message is the cornerstone of Islamic belief, and Muslims believe
in Jesus as a prophet but not as the son of God.
In conclusion, the concept of Jesus as the son of God is not accepted in Islam. Muslims believe in the
oneness of God, and the Quran clearly negates the idea of God having any offspring. Jesus is a highly
respected prophet in Islam, who preached the message of submission to God. Muslims believe in Jesus
as a messenger of God who delivered the message of Islam, but not as the son of God.

chunks.question: 6. what are the differences between Islam & christianity?
chunks.answer:
There are a number of key differences between Islam and Christianity. One major difference is their
concept of God: Christians believe in the Holy Trinity, the idea that God exists as three persons in one
(Father, Son, and Holy Spirit), while Muslims are strictly monotheistic, believing that there is only one
God (Allah). Another fundamental difference lies in their holy texts: Christians follow the Bible, which
they believe is the inspired word of God; whereas Muslims follow the Quran, which they believe was
revealed to Muhammad by Allah. Similarly, Islam teaches that all prophets from Adam to Jesus were sent
by Allah and considers Muhammad as the final prophet; while Christianity believes that Jesus is the Son
of God and part of the Holy Trinity. Overall, these varied beliefs result in different practices for religious
rituals, moral codes, and social customs within each faith community.
Islam and Christianity are two of the world's largest and most widespread religions. They have different religious
beliefs, practices, and teachings, making them distinct from each other. In this essay, we will discuss the
significant differences between Islam and Christianity.
One of the primary differences between Islam and Christianity relates to the concept of God. Muslims believe
that there is only one God, who is called Allah. Christians, on the other hand, believe in the Holy Trinity, which
consists of God the Father, God the Son, and God the Holy Spirit. Muslims believe that God is all-powerful, just,
and merciful. In contrast, Christians believe that God is loving and merciful, but also just and holy.
Another significant difference between Islam and Christianity is the way they interpret the role of prophets.
Muslims believe that God has revealed his message through a series of prophets, with Muhammad being the
last and final one. In contrast, Christians believe in Jesus Christ as the Son of God and the ultimate prophet.
Christians believe that Jesus was sent to earth to save humanity from sin and death.
The religious scriptures of both Islam and Christianity are also different. Muslims consider the Quran to be the
verbatim word of God, revealed to Muhammad over 23 years. Christians believe in the Bible, which consists of
the Old and New Testaments. The Old Testament contains the Jewish scriptures, while the New Testament is
primarily focused on the life and teachings of Jesus Christ.
Another significant difference between Islam and Christianity is their approach to prayer. Muslims pray five times
a day, facing Mecca. They use a prayer rug and recite prayers from the Quran. Christians, on the other hand,
primarily pray in church or at home. They use various aids such as prayer beads, candles, and crucifixes for
prayer and worship.
Finally, the way death and afterlife are perceived is different between the two religions. Muslims believe in a Day
of Judgment when all people will be held accountable for their deeds. They believe that those who lead a good
life and follow the teachings of Islam will go to Paradise, while those who lead a bad life will go to Hell. Christians
also believe in a Day of Judgment, with those who follow Jesus going to Heaven, and those who do not going to
Hell.
In conclusion, Islam and Christianity are two different religions with distinct beliefs, values, and practices. The
differences between these two faiths can be seen in their teachings about God, the role of prophets, religious
scriptures, prayer, and afterlife. Despite these differences, both religions share the common goal of promoting
peace, harmony, and brotherhood among humanity.

chunks.question: 7. Jesus was the way,the Truth and the life?
chunks.answer:
Islam holds that Jesus was a prophet of God and a messenger of truth, but it diverges from Christian doctrine
when it comes to the belief that he was the way, the truth and the life. Islamic teachings emphasize that all
prophets were sent by God with unique messages for specific times and communities, so while Jesus played a
significant role in reminding people to turn towards God with sincere hearts, he was not the only path to reach
Him. Instead, Islam teaches that salvation lies in adhering to the words of Muhammad as conveyed by Allah
through revelation. Muslims respect Jesus as a holy figure who preached compassion and mercy towards all, but
their ultimate source for guidance is the Quranic scripture which outlines a comprehensive message of worship
and righteous conduct as well as eschatological beliefs about what will happen at the end of time.
Islam, being one of the largest religions in the world, has its own opinion on Jesus Christ. As a prophet and
messenger of Allah or God, Jesus plays a significant role in Islamic beliefs. However, Islam's perspective on
Jesus differs from that of Christianity. This essay will delve into Islam's opinion regarding Jesus as the way, the
truth, and the life.
The Quran, the holy book of Muslims, acknowledges Jesus as one of the prominent prophets among many
others. The Quran states, "He [Jesus] said, 'Indeed, I am the servant of Allah. He has given me the Scripture and
made me a prophet, and He has made me blessed wherever I am.'" (19:30) As a true messenger of God, Jesus
preached the message of monotheism - worshipping only one God. Muslims believe that Jesus was sent by God
to guide people towards the righteous path and to warn them of the consequences of disobeying God’s will.
Islam regards Jesus as a miracle-working prophet who cured the sick, healed the leper, and even raised the
dead. The Quran tells the story of Jesus creating a bird out of clay and breathing life into it, which then flew
away. (3:49) This act of God's power establishes Jesus as a supernatural prophet.
However, Islam's perspective on Jesus as the way, the truth, and the life differs from that of Christianity. Muslims
believe that Jesus was not God, the son of God, or part of the Trinity. According to Islamic belief, Jesus did not
die on the cross, nor was he resurrected. Instead, God raised him to heaven before he could be crucified.
Islam believes that the message of Jesus was the message of submission to God, just like all the other prophets.
Muslims believe that following the commandments of God and the teachings of His prophets is the only way to
lead an honorable and successful life here and afterlife. Muslims do not follow any one individual or leaders, nor
do they believe that any one person can guarantee their salvation.
Islam's opinion on Jesus as the way, the truth, and the life is fundamentally different from that of Christianity.
However, both religions do derive guidance from the teachings of Jesus. Muslims believe that Jesus showed
people the right path and that the way to salvation is to follow that path. They consider the preaching of Jesus to
be inspiring and life-changing, as it leads one towards God's will.
In summary, Islam's view of Jesus as the way, the truth, and the life is one of veneration of a prophet and
messenger of God. Islam acknowledges Jesus's teachings and miracles while believing in different theological
areas concerning him compared to Christian beliefs. Muslims follow Jesus's missions as a prophet, realizing that
his message can help them to lead a better life both in this world and in the hereafter.

chunks.question: 8. Jesus had many miracles , why Muhammad didn't have any miracle?
chunks.answer:
Muhammad, the founder of Islam, is frequently contrasted with Jesus Christ in several aspects. While both
figures are regarded as excellent prophets and significant figures in the development of religion, there are certain
aspects where their lives diverge, with Jesus performing many miracles, but Muhammad lacking them. The
absence of miracles in Muhammad's life has raised several questions and debates among scholars and the
general public. This essay aims to examine and explain, in detail, the reasons behind why Muhammad did not
have any miracles like Jesus.
Firstly, it's necessary to understand that the purpose of miracles was different in both religions. In Christianity,
miracles were seen as ways to prove that Jesus Christ was the son of God and had divine powers. However, in
Islam, the primary focus was on the Quran, which was seen as a miracle in itself. Muslims believe that the Quran
was directly revealed to Muhammad by Allah and is considered the final and complete revelation. Therefore,
there was no need for further miracles to establish the authenticity of Muhammad's message.
Secondly, it's important to note that history is a crucial factor when understanding the lives of Jesus and
Muhammad. Jesus lived in a time when miracles were significant; they played a crucial role in Jewish society,
and people were looking for a messiah figure to perform them. In contrast, Muhammad lived in a time where
rationality and science were developing. Therefore, it's possible that Muhammad avoided performing miracles to
focus on his teachings and mission, rather than gaining followers through wonders.
Thirdly, Muhammad's mission was different from that of Jesus. Jesus was sent to create a new covenant with
humanity and save humanity from sin. However, Muhammad's mission was to unite and reform the Arabian
tribes and create a society based on justice and equality. Therefore, his focus was on spreading the message
and teachings of Allah, rather than performing miracles.
Finally, it's important to acknowledge that there have been several instances where Muhammad has been
associated with miracles. For example, the splitting of the moon, the water flowing from his fingers, and the
feeding of a large group of people with a small amount of food. However, these accounts are not agreed upon by
all Muslims and are treated as less important than the teachings of the Quran.
In conclusion, Muhammad's lack of miracles is not a weakness in his claim as a prophet. Instead, it highlights the
unique nature of his message and mission. His focus was on spreading the message of Allah and creating a just
and equal society. The Quran was seen as his primary miracle, and he devoted much of his life to teaching and
spreading its message. Therefore, Muhammad's message and teachings remain just as powerful and influential
today as they were during his lifetime.

chunks.question: 9. Why is pork prohibited in Islam?
chunks.answer:
Pork is prohibited in Islam due to a clear directive mentioned in the holy book of Quran. Muslims believe that
Allah (God) has prohibited the consumption of pork for several reasons, including health, moral and spiritual
purposes. According to Islamic teachings, pigs are considered unclean animals and therefore their meat is also
unclean. Pigs have a low digestive ability thus they consume anything which makes them susceptible to
diseases that can be transmitted to humans upon consumption of their meat. Additionally, pork contains toxins
and harmful substances like cholesterol which may lead to various health problems such as obesity or heart
disease. Pork consumption is seen as a temptation towards indulgence in worldly pleasures by some scholars;
the lack of control over one's desires is not encouraged in Islam. Therefore, refraining from the consumption of
pork is believed to preserve an individual’s physical well-being as well as maintain spiritual purity and self-control
within the Muslim community.
Pork is one of the most commonly consumed meats worldwide. However, in Islam, pork is one of the prohibited
foods, and Muslims are forbidden from consuming it or cooking it. This prohibition of eating pork is not only a
religious obligation in Islam but also has several scientific reasons. This essay will address why pork is prohibited
in Islam, both from religious and scientific perspectives.
From a religious viewpoint, pork is prohibited in the Islamic faith as it has been stated in the Quran; "forbidden to
you are dead animals, blood, the flesh of swine, and that which has been dedicated to other than Allah." (Surah
Al-Ma'idah: 3). This indicates that pork is impure and harmful to human consumption, and it has been forbidden
by Allah. This prohibition of pork is not only limited to Muslims but also Jews and some Christian sects, as it is
mentioned in the Bible (Leviticus 11:7-8).
Furthermore, pigs and other prohibited animals have been mentioned by the Prophet Muhammad in the Hadith,
one of the Islamic scholars' compilations. The Prophet Muhammad mentioned: "A true believer does not eat
blood, a dead animal, or pork." (Bukhari, Muslim) The Prophet highlighted the severity of consuming pork,
making it clear that it is strictly forbidden in Islam.
From a scientific perspective, pork is a dirty and high-risk meat to consume, which can cause numerous health
issues. Pigs are the scavengers of the animal kingdom and are known for consuming anything they find,
including feces, urine, and other contaminated food. This means that their flesh contains harmful bacteria and
toxins such as Salmonella, E.Coli, and Trichinella, which cause food poisoning and other serious illnesses.
Moreover, pigs carry several viruses and parasites, including tapeworms, viruses that lead to swine flu, and
influenza, which can cause severe diseases like meningitis, and even death. Additionally, pork has high-fat
content, which contributes to obesity, heart disease, and diabetes.
In conclusion, pork is prohibited in Islam due to religious and scientific reasons. Islam prohibits consuming pork
to maintain cleanliness, purity, and good health. Pig's habitat and dietary habits increase the risk of food
poisoning, viruses, and parasites. Therefore, Muslims follow the rules stated in Quran and Prophet’s Hadiths to
avoid the harmful effects of pork consumption. Additionally, this prohibition plays a significant role in maintaining
and promoting the Islamic ethics of cleanliness, which is essential in daily life.
10. Jesus is the word of God in islam
In Islam, Jesus is considered a revered prophet and messenger of Allah. He is also known as the word of God,
or Kalimatullah, because he was born through the miraculous power of Allah's spoken word. The Quran affirms
that Jesus brought divine guidance to humanity, preaching love and compassion for all people. However, Muslim
beliefs about Jesus differ from those of Christianity in that Muslims do not view him as the son of God nor do
they believe in his crucifixion and resurrection. Rather, they believe that he was miraculously raised into heaven
before his captors could harm him. Furthermore, Muslims believe that their faith completes and supersedes
earlier religious traditions and accepts Jesus' teachings within a larger framework of Islamic monotheism.
Therefore, when Muslims refer to Jesus as the word of God, they acknowledge his prophetic status within Islam
while underscoring his unique relationship to Allah's divine utterance.
The phrase "Jesus is the word of God" is often used in Islamic contexts, and it refers to Jesus' unique role in the
Muslim faith as a messenger of God. In the Quran, the holy book of Islam, Jesus is frequently referred to as the
"word" or "kalimah" of God. The Quranic description of Jesus as the word of God establishes a crucial
connection between Jesus and the divine, and it reflects the Islamic belief in the singular nature of God's
message.
At the heart of the Islamic understanding of Jesus as the word of God is the belief that Jesus was a prophet who
was chosen by God to convey His message to humanity. According to the Quran, Jesus was sent to the world to
teach people about the truth of God's message and to guide them towards a life of obedience to God's will. In
this sense, Jesus was seen as a word that conveyed God's message to humanity.
The Quranic description of Jesus as the word of God also emphasizes the divine nature of Jesus. According to
Islamic belief, Jesus was not just an ordinary person, but he was a manifestation of the divine message that God
sent down to humanity. The Quranic verses that describe Jesus as the word of God emphasize his unique
position as a messenger of God, and they echo the Islamic belief in the oneness of God's message.
In addition to emphasizing the divine nature of Jesus, the Quranic description of him as the word of God also
highlights the importance of the message that he brought to humanity. According to Islamic belief, Jesus'
teachings were a continuation of the prophetic tradition that had been established by earlier prophets. His
message was about the importance of living a life of obedience to God's will, and it emphasized the importance
of compassion and social justice.
Ultimately, the Quranic description of Jesus as the word of God serves to emphasize the centrality of the divine
message in the Islamic faith. It highlights the belief that God's message is a unifying force that transcends time
and place, and that it is delivered to humanity through a series of divinely inspired messengers. By emphasizing
the importance of Jesus' message, the Quranic description of him as the word of God reinforces the importance
of living a life of faith and submission to God's will.

chunks.question: 11. Is Jesus God?
chunks.answer:
From the Islamic point of view, Jesus is considered a prophet and a revered figure in spiritual history. However,
Muslims reject the idea that Jesus is God or the son of God as inferior to Allah’s supreme authority. Instead, they
uphold the belief in monotheism which says that there is only one true God- Allah. Muslims hold Jesus in high
esteem as an important messiah and messenger of Allah who was born miraculously but appointed as a human
being with no divine properties. In Islam, emphasizing that Jesus was born without any filial link to divinity
signifies submitting to God's will and understanding his Oneness. Furthermore, the Qur'an teaches that idolizing
anyone besides Allah constitutes blasphemy (shirk) – an unforgivable sin. Thus, from an Islamic lens, denying
Jesus’ divine nature does not detract from his unique position as an esteemed Prophet and guardian of Muslim
beliefs in ethical teachings such as compassion, equality, and justice.
Islam, like Christianity, recognizes the importance of Jesus in the world. Muslims believe Prophet Jesus was a
prophet of Allah or God. The foundation of Islam is the belief in tawhid or the Oneness of God. In the Islamic
faith, Jesus is regarded as an important prophet or messenger of God, but he is not seen as God or a divine
being.
The Islamic view of Jesus is quite different from the Christian view of Jesus. While Christianity believes Jesus
was the son of God and a part of the Holy Trinity, Islam strictly denies the concept of the Trinity. Muslims believe
that Jesus was a mortal human being who was chosen by God to be a prophet and deliverer of His message.
Jesus' miraculous birth to the Virgin Mary was believed to be a miraculous event, but it does not make him
divine.
Muslims regard Jesus as one of the great prophets who was sent to guide the people of Israel. According to the
Quran, Jesus was sent to confirm the previous prophets' teachings and to warn people to follow God's
commandments. Islam believes that Jesus performed some miraculous things through the permission of God,
such as healing the blind and the sick, and raising the dead. But Muslims also believe that Jesus' abilities were
not attributed to him alone; rather, they were God's power and enabled by Allah’s permission.
The Quran recognizes Jesus as the Messiah, a title bestowed not only on Jesus but also on Prophet Muhammad
(peace be upon him). The title Messiah indicates a messenger or savior of God, but it does not imply divinity.
Muslims accept that Jesus was crucified by the Romans, although the Quran denies that he died on the cross.
The Quran says that God raised Jesus to Himself, and he will return in the last days as a just leader who will
establish righteousness on the earth.
In conclusion, Islam does not consider Jesus as God, but purely as a prophet of Allah with no divine nature.
While Muslim does not deny Jesus' great significance in history, they make it clear that considering him God is a
sin in the religion. Muslims respect Jesus’ teachings and believe in his second coming, but they have a
distinctive point of view from the Christian’s belief in Jesus Christ being divine. It reinforces to Muslims that they
should devote their worship and gratitude towards the one and only God, Allah.

chunks.question: 12. Jesus will return,why not Muhammad?
chunks.answer:
According to Islamic belief, Jesus will return as a prophet before the end of times. However, it is important to
note that Muhammad is considered the last and final prophet in Islam, making it impossible for him to return after
his passing. Muslims strongly believe that Jesus will no longer be a deity upon his return but rather a messenger
who will clarify misconceptions about his earlier years on earth. As narrated in various Hadiths (sayings of
Prophet Muhammad), Jesus is expected to kill Dajjal (the Antichrist) and will lead prayers as an Imam for
Muslims. Although there are differences between Islamic and Christian beliefs about Jesus’ return, the former
encourages all its followers to respect Christ and consider him one of the greatest messengers sent by Allah
(God).
Islam regards Jesus (peace be upon him) as one of the greatest prophets of Allah (God). Muslims believe in his
miraculous birth, his ability to perform miracles, and his ascension to heaven without facing death. In Islam,
Jesus is expected to return to this world, and his return is an important aspect of Islamic eschatology (end of
times). However, Islam differs from Christianity in the nature and timing of Jesus' return.
In Islam, it is believed that Jesus will return to establish justice and peace on earth. He will descend from the
heavens, accompanied by angels, at a time when the world is engulfed in chaos and tyranny. His role will be to
unite people under the banner of Islam and establish a just and ethical society. The Quran mentions Jesus'
return in several verses:
"And (Jesus) shall be a Sign (for the coming of) the Hour (of Judgment): therefore have no doubt about the
(Hour), but you (should) follow Me: this is a Straight Way." (43:61)
"He (Jesus) said: 'I am indeed a servant of Allah. He has given me revelation and made me a prophet; and He
has made me blessed wheresoever I be, and has enjoined on me Prayer and Charity as long as I live; (He) has
made me kind to my mother, and not overbearing or miserable; so peace is on me the day I was born, the day I
die, and the day I shall be raised up to life (again)!'" (19:30-33)
However, Islam's view of Jesus' return and his role in the end of times differs from the Christian view, which
regards Jesus' return as the final judgment day. Islam does not regard Jesus as a divine figure, but rather as a
prophet of Allah. Therefore, Muslims do not believe that Jesus will return to save humanity in the sense that
Christians understand it.
As for why Muhammad will not return, Islam holds that he was the last prophet sent by Allah to guide humanity.
The Quran says:
"Muhammad is not the father of any of your men, but (he is) the Messenger of Allah, and the Seal of the
Prophets: and Allah has full knowledge of all things." (33:40)
This verse indicates that Muhammad was the last prophet of Allah, and after him there will be no further
prophets. Therefore, his role as a prophet has been fulfilled, and he will not return to earth.
In conclusion, Islam believes in Jesus' return to establish justice and peace on earth, but it differs from the
Christian view in the nature and timing of his return. While Muhammad is regarded as the last prophet of Allah
and will not return to earth, his teachings and guidance continue to inspire and guide Muslims.

chunks.question: 13. Do Muslims worship Kabbah & black stone?
chunks.answer:
I can confidently assert that Muslims do not worship the Kaaba or black stone. The Kaaba itself is a cuboid
structure in Mecca towards which Muslims face while performing their prayers. This is because the direction of
prayer (qiblah) was initially set towards Jerusalem, but later it was changed to Makkah (the location of the
Kaaba) by Prophet Muhammad under divine instruction. The Black Stone is merely a sacred object located on
one corner of the Kaaba and holds significance as it is believed to have come from heaven. Muslims perform a
ritual during Hajj or Umrah in which they kiss or touch the Black Stone as part of their pilgrimage, but it does not
hold any essential religious meaning beyond this act - it's just a revered symbol akin to other holy artifacts of
other religions. In short, the worship among Muslims is directed solely towards Allah and not any physical object.
There is a widespread misconception among non-Muslims that Muslims worship the Kabah and the black stone.
However, this belief is entirely unfounded and based on a lack of understanding of Islamic theology and history.
Firstly, it is crucial to understand that Muslim worship is directed solely towards Allah, the one and only God in
Islam. Muslims believe that Allah is the sole creator of the universe and that he is the only being worthy of
worship. Thus, to suggest that Muslims worship any physical object, including the Kabah or the black stone, is
entirely inaccurate.
The Kabah, which means "cube" in Arabic, is a sacred site located in the city of Mecca. Muslims consider it to be
the first house of worship established by Adam and later rebuilt by the Prophet Ibrahim and his son Ismail. The
Kabah is regarded as the holiest site in Islam and functions as a focal point for Muslim prayer and pilgrimage.
However, it is vital to understand that Muslims do not worship the Kabah as an object of veneration. Instead, the
Kabah serves as a symbol of the oneness of God and the unity of the Muslim community. Muslims believe that
the Kabah is a physical manifestation of the divine presence of Allah, but it is not to be worshipped as an idol or
a deity.
Similarly, the black stone, a small corner stone embedded in the eastern wall of the Kabah, is also held in high
regard by Muslims. According to Islamic tradition, the black stone was given to Prophet Ibrahim by the angel
Gabriel and is believed to possess healing powers. Pilgrims to the Kabah perform a ritual called tawaf, in which
they walk around the Kabah seven times, and kiss or touch the black stone.
However, this act of touching or kissing the black stone is not an act of worship, but rather a symbolic gesture of
one's devotion and obedience to Allah. The black stone is considered a blessed stone, but it has no divine or
magical powers, and Muslims do not worship it as an object of veneration.
In conclusion, it is entirely incorrect to suggest that Muslims worship the Kabah or the black stone. Muslim
worship is directed solely towards Allah, and these physical objects serve only as symbols of Muslim unity,
devotion, and submission to God. Muslims engage in acts of homage towards these objects as a means of
expressing their faith and connection to Islamic tradition, but they do not worship them as idols or deities. It is
essential to understand the distinctions and nuances of Islamic faith and practice to avoid misconceptions and
misinterpretations.

chunks.question: 14. Does Muhammad have miracles?
chunks.answer:
In Islam, Muhammad is revered as a prophet and messenger of Allah.. One such event includes the night
journey (al-Isra) in which Muhammad was transported from Mecca to Jerusalem, and then ascended to heaven
(Mi'raj). Additionally, it is believed that his ability to recite and utter the Quran without any prior learning or
training is also considered miraculous. Overall, these occurrences serve as manifestations of God’s guidance
through His chosen prophet and reinforce the truthfulness of Islam as a faith-based on divine revelation rather
than human interpretation.
Islam, like many other religions, attributes miracles to its founder, Prophet Muhammad. The existence and nature
of these miracles are a topic of much debate among Muslim scholars, with some viewing them as literal events
while others interpret them more symbolically. In this essay, we will explore the various arguments surrounding
the question of whether Muhammad had miracles in Islam.
The concept of miracles (known as karamat or mu'jizat in Arabic) is central to Islamic theology. Muslims believe
that Allah, the supreme being, possesses the power to intervene in the natural order of things and perform acts
that defy human logic and understanding. As the last prophet of Islam, Muhammad is said to have been granted
the ability to perform miracles as a sign of his divine connection and authority.
One of the most famous miracles attributed to Muhammad is his splitting of the moon. This event is referenced in
several places in the Quran, including in Surah Al-Qamar (Verse 1), which states, "The hour has come near, and
the moon has split [in two]. And if they see a miracle, they turn away and say, ‘Passing magic.’" Some scholars
interpret this passage as a metaphorical reference to a political or social schism, while others believe it to be a
literal account of Muhammad splitting the moon in two.
Another commonly cited miracle is the Prophet's night journey (Al-Isra), during which he is believed to have
traveled from Mecca to Jerusalem and then ascended to the heavens. This event is detailed in Surah Al-Isra
(Verse 1), which states, "Exalted is He who took His Servant by night from al-Masjid al-Haram to al-Masjid
al-Aqsa, whose surroundings We have blessed, to show him of Our signs. Indeed, He is the Hearing, the
Seeing." Some scholars view this event as a physical journey, while others interpret it as a spiritual experience.
Other miracles attributed to Muhammad include his ability to predict future events, his healing of the sick, and his
splitting of the rock at Hira. However, some Muslim scholars reject these accounts as exaggerated or fabricated.
In conclusion, the question of whether Muhammad had miracles in Islam is a complex one that continues to be
debated among scholars. While some believe in the literal truth of the reported miracles, others view them as
metaphorical expressions of Muhammad's spiritual power and authority. Regardless of one's interpretation, these
miracles serve as a powerful symbol of Muhammad's role as a messenger of Allah and a guiding force for
Muslims around the world.

chunks.question: 15. Is Jesus the spirit of God?
chunks.answer:
In Islam, Jesus is recognized as a great prophet and messenger of Allah, but not as the son of God. Instead, he
is considered a human being who was greatly blessed by God with miracles and teachings for the guidance of
mankind. While there are different interpretations within Islamic theology, most would agree that Jesus was not
divine nor did he embody the spirit of God in the way that is understood in Christianity. Rather, Muslims believe
that God's spirit is present in all of creation and accessible to humanity through prayer and spiritual practices.
Therefore, while Jesus holds an important position in Islamic theology, his role is distinct from that described by
Christians, who see him as both fully human and fully divine.
Islam is a monotheistic religion that regards Prophet Muhammad as the last and final messenger of God. The
Quranic teachings recognize Jesus as a prophet of God, born of the Virgin Mary, and performing miraculous acts
such as healing the sick and raising the dead. However, the Islamic view of Jesus differs from the Christian view,
which regards him as the son of God and the incarnation of the divine spirit. According to Islam, Jesus is not the
spirit of God, but a human messenger sent by God to guide humanity towards the path of righteousness.
The Islamic understanding of God is based on the concept of Tawhid, which acknowledges the oneness and
unity of God. Muslims believe that God is the ultimate source of all existence, and that nothing can be compared
to God in essence or nature. Therefore, it is considered a grave sin in Islam to associate partners with God, or to
attribute divine attributes to anything other than God. This fundamental principle of Tawhid is reflected in the
Islamic view of Jesus, who is regarded as a mortal being created by God, and not as a divine being possessing
the spirit of God.
The Quranic teachings describe Jesus as a prophet who was sent to guide the children of Israel towards the
path of righteousness. Jesus performed miracles such as healing the sick, raising the dead, and speaking from
his cradle as an infant, all of which were regarded as signs of his prophethood. According to the Quran, Jesus
was born of the Virgin Mary, and he spent his life preaching the message of God to his people. However, the
Quranic account of Jesus's life differs from the Christian view in several respects. For example, the Quran denies
the Christian doctrine of the Trinity, and the divinity of Jesus.
In Islam, the spirit of God is regarded as a separate entity from Jesus, who is considered a human being.
Muslims believe that the spirit of God is a divine force that pervades all of creation, including humanity.
According to the Quranic teachings, the spirit of God is not confined to a particular place or time, but is
omnipresent and eternal. Therefore, it cannot be equated with Jesus, who is a finite being bound by the
limitations of time and space.
In conclusion, Islam does not regard Jesus as the spirit of God, but as a messenger sent by God to guide
humanity towards righteousness. Muslims believe in the oneness of God, and reject the notion of associating
partners with God. Therefore, the Islamic view of Jesus differs from the Christian view, and emphasizes his role
as a prophet and messenger, rather than his divinity or incarnation of the spirit of God.

chunks.question: 16. Jesus doesn't have a sin, but Muhammad has a sin?
chunks.answer:
it is important to provide clarity on the concept of sin in Christianity and Islam. According to Christian doctrine,
Jesus Christ was born without original sin and lived a perfect life, making him the only sinless human being who
ever existed. On the other hand, Islamic teachings acknowledge that Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) was not
infallible, but believe that he sought repentance whenever he made mistakes or errors in judgment. It is
important to remember that both Christianity and Islam emphasize the importance of seeking forgiveness for
one's transgressions towards God and fellow humans. Therefore, whether or not a religious figure has sinned
does not diminish their respective faiths' importance on moral values such as love, compassion, and empathy
towards others.
it is not programmed to support or promote religious biases. Therefore, this essay will not make any claims or
assertions about the historical or religious significance of Jesus Christ or Muhammad. However, it is essential to
explore the origin and notion of sin in Islam and Christianity.
In the Christian faith, sin refers to any violation against God's laws or divine principles. The story of Adam and
Eve in the book of Genesis describes the origins of sin-how it entered the world and how it affects humanity.
Christians believe that Jesus Christ, the Son of God, came to earth to save humanity from the consequences of
sin-broken fellowship with God, death, and eternal separation from Him. According to the Bible, Jesus Christ
lived a perfect, sinless life, making him the only suitable sacrifice for the atonement of sin, as well as
demonstrating the way to live a sinless life.
The concept of sin in Islam is different. Muslims believe that Allah (God) created humans pure, without sin, and
with the ability to recognize right from wrong. However, humans are prone to sin due to shaytan or Satan's
temptation, their own desires, or other external factors. Sin, known as 'dhanb' in Arabic, means to act against
God's commands, forgetting God, or hurting others physically or mentally. Muslims believe that the prophets and
messengers of God, including Muhammad, are sinless in terms of receiving divine revelations. However, they
are not perfect, and as humans, they can make mistakes, repent and learn from them.
Therefore, we cannot say that Muhammad or any prophet or messenger of Allah has sinned. However, they are
not immune to errors and have admitted to making mistakes. Muhammad, for example, once ordered the killing
of a group of people who had assassinated some of his followers. Later, when he learned about their
repentance, he regretted his decision and asked for forgiveness. This incident shows that even the best of
Muslims can make mistakes and need to seek forgiveness.
It is essential to avoid making comparisons that could offend either religion or its followers. Both Islam and
Christianity teach the importance of forgiveness and repentance. Muslims believe that God's mercy is vast and
that He forgives all sins, except for shirk or associating partners with Him. Christians believe that through faith in
Jesus Christ, believers can receive forgiveness for their sins and eternal life with Him.
In conclusion, both Islam and Christianity acknowledge the significance of sin and the need for forgiveness. The
concept of sin in Islam and Christianity differs; however, both religions reveal that even the best of their followers
can make mistakes and need to seek forgiveness. Therefore, rather than comparing and contrasting the lives of
Jesus and Muhammad, it is best to focus on what we can learn from their teachings, repenting and seeking
forgiveness from God for our mistakes.

chunks.question: 17. Why do Muslims pray in Arabic?
chunks.answer:
Muslims pray in Arabic because it is the language of the Qur'an, the holy book of Islam. The use of Arabic
maintains the authenticity and accuracy of reciting Allah's revelations as stated in the Qur'an, which are believed
to be pure and unaltered since its inception over 1,400 years ago. Furthermore, recitation in Arabic helps
Muslims to better connect with their faith by instilling a sense of unity among global worshippers. It acts as a
cohesive element that binds different communities who may speak different languages but can still communicate
with one another through prayers recited in standardized uniformity. Additionally, Quranic verses carry deep
spiritual meanings that cannot be fully expressed in translation without losing some essence or subtlety.
Therefore Muslims pray in Arabic not just for ritualistic reasons but also for the transcendent experience it offers
through meditative prayer practices embedded within Islamic spiritual traditions.
Muslims pray in Arabic because it is the language of the Islamic holy book, the Quran. The Quran is the direct
word of God as revealed to the Prophet Muhammad in the Arabic language over 1,400 years ago. Since the
Quran is considered to be the ultimate source of guidance for Muslims, it is natural that prayers are also
conducted in Arabic.
Moreover, the Arabic language has a special status in Islam, not only because it is the language of the
Prophet Muhammad and the Quran but also because it has been chosen by God as the language of the
final revelation. The Quran itself refers to Arabic as a "clear language" (Quran 26:195) that is easy to
understand and has a depth of meaning that cannot be fully translated into other languages.
When Muslims pray in Arabic, they are not only communicating with God but are also connecting with
the rich history and spiritual tradition of Islam. Arabic language is often used in the daily life of Muslims
in the form of phrases like "Assalamu alaikum" (peace be upon you) and "Bismillah" (in the name of
Allah). Therefore, the Arabic language has become integral to Muslim culture.
Additionally, Arabic is a unifying language for Muslims all around the world. Regardless of cultural and
ethnic differences, Muslims are united through their shared faith and shared language. Therefore,
praying in Arabic helps to foster a sense of community and togetherness among Muslims.
It is also important to note that while Arabic is the primary language used in Islamic prayers, Muslims
may also recite prayers in their own native languages during non-obligatory or voluntary prayers, such
as the night prayer of "tahajjud" or the "dua" (supplication) after the obligatory prayers. These additional
prayers are recited in the local language of the Muslim community to help them better understand the
meaning and importance of the prayers.
In conclusion, Muslims pray in Arabic because it is the language of the Quran, which is the ultimate
source of guidance for Muslims. Additionally, the Arabic language is an essential part of Muslim culture
and has significant spiritual and cultural importance. It also unifies Muslims from all over the world,
regardless of their cultural and ethnic differences. While obligatory prayers are recited in Arabic,
Muslims have the freedom to use their native languages during other voluntary prayers

chunks.question: 18. "the father and I are one" ,is that true?
chunks.answer:
From a Muslim point of view, the statement "the father and I are one" can be understood in reference to the
oneness of Allah (SWT). In Islam, there is the concept of Tawhid which means the belief in the oneness and
unity of Allah. The statement can also be interpreted as a way for individuals to draw closer to Allah by
developing a stronger relationship with Him through love, fear, and obedience. This understanding affirms that
Muslims believe in the complete oneness and indivisibility of God, without any partners or associates. The idea
that we are one with Allah is not meant to imply any form of divinity or inherent power; rather it conveys humility
and submission towards Him. As proclaimed by Prophet Muhammad (PBUH), "Allah has said: He who has
known himself knows his Lord." By knowing oneself and acknowledging our dependency upon Him, we connect
ourselves with Allah's mercy, compassion and guidance.
The phrase "the father and I are one" originates from the Gospel of John in the Christian Bible, where
Jesus is quoted as saying this in the context of describing his relationship with God the Father. This
statement is often used to support the Christian belief in the doctrine of the Trinity, which teaches that
God exists as three persons in one: the Father, the Son (Jesus), and the Holy Spirit. However, the
question posed here is whether this statement holds any significance in Islamic theology.
To begin with, it is important to note that Islam and Christianity have different understandings of who
God is. While Christians believe in a three-in-one God, Muslims, on the other hand, believe in a single,
indivisible God (Allah). Therefore, the idea of Jesus and the Father being one is not in line with Islamic
teachings.
In Islam, the oneness of God is one of the most fundamental beliefs, known as Tawheed. Muslims believe
that Allah is the only deity and that He has no partners, equals, or associates. In the Quran, Allah (swt)
says, "Say, He is Allah, [who is] One, Allah, the Eternal Refuge. He neither begets nor is born, nor is
there to Him any equivalent" (112:1-4).
The phrase "the father and I are one" cannot be attributed to Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) because it is
not found in the Quran, nor is it spoken by the Prophet. Instead, the Quran teaches that Allah is unseen
and incomparable, and that he alone is the ultimate and true authority.
In Islamic theology, the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) is considered the last and final messenger of Allah.
He is considered a human being with no attributes of divinity, and his purpose was to deliver the
message of God to humanity. Therefore, there is no room for any claim of oneness with Allah in Islam.
In conclusion, the statement "the father and I are one" holds no significance in Islamic theology. Islam
teaches the belief in the absolute unity of God and the idea of the Trinity is considered a deviation from
the monotheistic belief. Contrarily, Islam instructs its followers to put their complete trust in Allah and to
submit themselves to Him alone. Muslims, therefore, hold very different beliefs from Christians on this
matter.

chunks.question: 19. No one can see God except through Jesus?
chunks.answer:
According to Islamic beliefs, the statement "No one can see God except through Jesus" goes against the
fundamental concept of Tawheed or oneness of God. While Muslims greatly revere Prophet Jesus as a
messenger of Allah, they do not consider him to be divine or a mediator between human beings and God.
Rather, Islam teaches that every individual has direct access to God through sincere prayers and worship
without the need for an intermediary. The Quran mentions in numerous verses that Allah is All-Seeing and
All-Hearing, implying that He is always present and attentive to His creations' supplications. Hence, the notion
that only through Jesus can one perceive God is not embraced in Islam as it contradicts with the belief in
monotheism upheld by Muslims worldwide.
The statement "No one can see God except through Jesus" is a Christian belief that Jesus Christ is the
only way to God. However, Islam, which is the second-largest religion in the world, has a different
perspective on this statement.
Islam teaches that every individual has the potential to see and connect with God through personal
devotion and seeking knowledge. In Islam, Allah is portrayed as one who is transcendent and infinite,
and thus, cannot be seen or comprehended by human faculties.
Islam emphasizes the importance of surrendering to the will of Allah, and seeking his guidance and
mercy. The way to do so is by following the teachings of the Quran, which is the holy book of Islam, and
the example of the Prophet Mohammed.
Islam also teaches that Jesus was a prophet and a messenger of God, but not divine. Muslims believe
that God can reveal himself to anyone he chooses, and there have been many examples throughout the
history of Islam of people who have had spiritual experiences with God.
Muslims believe that the way to experience God is through prayer, worship, and serving others. In Islam,
the concept of Tawhid, or the oneness of God, is central to the faith. Muslims believe that everything in
the universe is interconnected and that the ultimate purpose is to submit to the will of Allah.
In conclusion, the statement "No one can see God except through Jesus" is a Christian belief, and it
does not apply to Islam. In Islam, the way to connect with God is through surrendering to his will,
seeking his guidance, and serving others. Islam emphasizes that everyone has the potential to connect
with Allah and experience his presence. Muslims believe that Jesus was a prophet and a messenger of
God, and although his teachings are respected, he is not the only way to God.

chunks.question: 20. What's the meaning of Jihad?
chunks.answer:
Jihad refers to the struggle or effort made by an individual in the pursuit of righteousness and the betterment of
society. In Islamic terms, this concept carries a deeper connotation that involves spiritual, social, and physical
struggles aimed at achieving a righteous and just society. Jihad is frequently associated with military campaigns
waged against non-believers, but this is a misinterpretation. Islam emphasizes peace, but acknowledges that
there may be situations where self-defense is necessary. The greater Jihad in Islam is to strive towards
individual spiritual development by engaging in regular prayer and participating in charitable activities for
community improvement. Jihad does not condone violence against innocent people or aggression towards
non-Muslim communities. Instead, it promotes courage and determination to resist oppression and uphold the
principles of justice and freedom for all individuals irrespective of their religious affiliation or background.
Jihad is one of the most widely misunderstood Islamic concepts. It is often associated with violence and
terrorism, particularly by some Western media outlets. However, the term has a much broader and
complex meaning than this simplistic portrayal.
In Arabic, Jihad means “struggle” or “effort,” and it has both spiritual and physical dimensions. The
spiritual Jihad involves a personal struggle to improve oneself and overcome one’s inner weaknesses,
such as greed, arrogance, and envy. It aims to purify one’s intentions and actions, develop a closer
relationship with God, and attain spiritual excellence. This type of Jihad is, in fact, the most important
and the highest form of struggle, as the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said, “The most
excellent Jihad is that for the conquest of self.”
The physical Jihad, on the other hand, involves a struggle against enemies of Islam, particularly those
who threaten the safety and security of Muslims and their lands. However, this type of Jihad is often
misinterpreted as a call for indiscriminate violence or aggression against non-Muslims. In reality, Islam
