should start by researching the fundamental beliefs of Islam, its practices, and its history. This can be done
through reading available literature, attending lectures, or consulting with knowledgeable individuals. The next
step is to recite the Shahada, which is the declaration of faith in Islam. This entails affirming that there is no deity
worthy of worship except Allah and that Muhammad (peace be upon him) is His prophet. It is also essential to
adopt Islamic practices such as prayer, fasting during Ramadan, giving Zakat (charity), and making a pilgrimage
to Mecca if possible. Joining an Islamic community can significantly aid in one's conversion as they provide
moral support and guidance for new members. Ultimately, sincere commitment and adherence are crucial in
embracing any religion fully.
Converting to Islam is a serious decision that requires deep understanding and contemplation. Islam is
the world's second-largest religion, with over 1.5 billion followers worldwide. It's a faith that emphasizes
character, honesty, and compassion towards others. Converting to Islam can be a life-changing
experience, and it's essential to understand the practices and beliefs before taking such a step.
The first step towards converting to Islam is to gain knowledge about the religion's core beliefs and
practices. Reading the Quran and other essential Islamic texts is an excellent way to get started. The
Quran is the holy book of Islam, and it contains Allah's teachings and the Prophet Muhammad's words,
who is the final prophet of Islam. Getting familiar with the five pillars of Islam, such as Salah (prayer),
Zakat (charity), Sawm (fasting), and Hajj (pilgrimage to Mecca), is also important.
Once you've gained sufficient knowledge about the religion, the next step is to make the declaration of
faith, which is also known as the shahada. The shahada is a proclamation of one's belief in the oneness
of Allah and the prophethood of Muhammad. Saying the shahada in front of witnesses or reciting it in
private is enough to convert to Islam.
After accepting Islam, it's crucial to begin learning about the Islamic way of life. Seek guidance from
knowledgeable Muslims and make an effort to attend mosque regularly. Gaining an understanding of
Islamic traditions and culture can be a great asset in living as a Muslim.
One of the critical elements of the Islamic faith is praying five times a day. Learning how to perform the
Salah is necessary. It's a good idea to learn from someone well versed in Islamic prayer or attending a
local mosque where people can help to learn the rituals.
Another significant aspect of Islamic faith is charity, a fundamental principle of Islam. Muslims are
obligated to give a portion of their wealth annually to help those in need. Muslims should be generous
with their wealth, give to charitable causes, and spend time helping people in their communities.
Additionally, fasting is an essential part of the Islamic faith. Muslims fast from dawn to dusk during the
Holy month of Ramadan, abstaining from food, drink and other physical needs. It is one of the most
significant acts of worship, as it helps to purify the soul and improve one's relationship with God.
Finally, the pilgrimage (Hajj) to Mecca is considered a significant obligation for every capable Muslim. It
is a once-in-a-lifetime journey that allows Muslims worldwide to be united in their faith and worship. It is
a personal and spiritual journey to seek forgiveness and draw closer to God.
In conclusion, converting to Islam is a beautiful decision, but it requires adequate preparation,
knowledge, and commitment. It can be challenging initially but rewarding in the long term. After making
the declaration of faith, it's essential to learn the fundamentals of Islam's practices

chunks.question: 50. What are the pillars of Islam?
chunks.answer:
The five pillars of Islam are the fundamental practices that every Muslim must follow. The first pillar is Shahada,
which is the declaration of faith in Allah and the Prophet Muhammad as His messenger. The second pillar is
Salah, referring to the obligatory daily prayers performed five times a day. The third pillar is Zakat, meaning
giving alms or charity to the needy and less fortunate. The fourth pillar is Sawm, or fasting during Ramadan for
an entire month as an act of devotion and self-discipline. Finally, Hajj, or pilgrimage to Mecca at least once in a
lifetime, during the Islamic month of Dhu al-Hijjah stands as the fifth pillar. These pillars represent essential
tenets that guide Muslims in their relationship with God and other people and emphasize individual devotion
alongside communal practice, charity and kindness amidst struggle: culminating into fulfilling one's obligations
towards fellow humans on this shared earth before being rewarded in heaven after death.
Islam is one of the major religions of the world, with over 1.8 billion followers. It is a complete way of life, and its
core principles are represented by its five pillars. These pillars are regarded as the foundation of Islam and
provide a framework for Muslims to follow. Each pillar has its own unique significance, and by observing all five
of them, a Muslim can strengthen their faith and connect with Allah.
The first pillar is Shahada or the declaration of faith. It is the fundamental statement that reflects a Muslim's
beliefs in Allah and Muhammad, as his prophet. It is a simple statement, "There is no god but Allah, and
Muhammad is his messenger." By reciting this statement, a Muslim acknowledges the supremacy of Allah and
accepts the teachings of the Prophet, making a commitment to follow them.
The second pillar is Salah or prayer. Every Muslim is required to offer five daily prayers, which are held at
specific times throughout the day. Prayer is the most direct way of establishing a connection with Allah, and
Muslims are encouraged to perform it in congregation. It also provides a sense of discipline, as individuals are
required to follow a specific format and posture during prayer.
The third pillar is Zakat or charity. It is a mandatory obligation on Muslims to give a portion of their wealth to
those in need. By giving Zakat, Muslims demonstrate their commitment to social justice, compassion, and
generosity towards others. It helps to create a sense of community and unity amongst fellow Muslims by
highlighting the importance of taking care of each other.
The fourth pillar is Sawm or fasting. It is observed during the month of Ramadan, where Muslims refrain from
eating, drinking, and engaging in any physical desires during daylight hours. Fasting is seen as a way to purify
the soul, gain self-discipline, and empathize with those who are less fortunate. It is also a way of practicing
self-control and learning to be mindful of one's actions.
The fifth and last pillar is Hajj or pilgrimage. It is a journey to the holy city of Mecca, where Muslims gather for a
specific time to perform several rituals at the Kaaba. It is an essential obligation for Muslims who are physically
and financially able to undertake it once in their lifetime. The Hajj provides a unique opportunity for Muslims
worldwide to come together, connect with one another, and strengthen their faith.
In conclusion, the five pillars of Islam provide guidelines for Muslims to follow and connect with Allah. They act
as the foundation of one's faith and are integral in becoming a better, more devout Muslim. Each pillar represents
a different aspect of Islam, and by observing them, Muslims can achieve a sense of inner peace, discipline, and
social responsibility. The pillars of Islam demonstrate Allah's compassion and love towards his creation and
serve as a reminder to humanity of the importance of fulfilling their religious duties.

chunks.question: 51. Why should I pray?
chunks.answer:
As a Muslim, the daily prayers hold great significance in our faith and are mandatory for every able-bodied adult.
Prayer connects us with Allah and reminds us of His presence in our lives, allowing us to seek blessings and
guidance from Him. It also helps to purify our hearts and minds, reminding us of our ultimate purpose in life - to
worship Allah alone. The act of prayer teaches discipline, punctuality and patience which can be applied in all
aspects of our lives. It creates a sense of community within the Muslim Ummah as we all stand together facing
the same direction towards the Kaaba. The benefits of prayer are numerous, both spiritually and mentally; it
brings inner peace while helping us become better human beings. Therefore, praying should not only be viewed
as an obligation, but a privilege granted to believers by Allah Almighty that strengthens their relationship with
Him in this life and the hereafter.
As a Muslim, prayer is one of the most fundamental pillars of Islam. It is considered as a direct connection
between the believer and the Creator. Prayer is not only an act of worship but also a source of spiritual and
physical benefits that enhance the individual's faith and overall well-being. Therefore, every Muslim has a duty to
perform obligatory prayers and adopt the habit of praying regularly.
Firstly, prayer is a means of connecting with Allah. It is a communication tool that enables the believer to have a
direct conversation with the Creator. By reciting verses from the Quran and saying supplications, the Muslim
expresses his or her gratitude, seeks forgiveness, and seeks guidance from Allah. The act of prayer creates a
spiritual connection with Allah, creating a sense of connection, fulfillment, and peace within the believer.
Secondly, prayer is an indication of submission to Allah's will. It is a way of acknowledging that Allah is the one
who controls everything in the universe, and the human being is entirely dependent on Him. Prayer helps the
individual to be humble and selfless, reminding them that everything they have been given is a blessing from
Allah. The individual also acknowledges their sins and weaknesses and seeks forgiveness from Allah. Through
this, the believer accepts their shortcomings and looks to Allah for guidance and forgiveness, strengthening their
faith and creating a sense of hope.
Thirdly, prayer is a source of physical benefits. It acts as a form of physical exercise and allows the body to
stretch and move, providing many physical benefits. Paying attention to one's posture during prayer helps to
maintain good blood circulation, which enhances overall well-being, and it can even act as a stress reliever,
creating a sense of relaxation and tranquility.
Fourthly, praying regularly promotes a sense of discipline and routine in the believer's life. It helps to establish a
daily routine that becomes a habit and a way of life. This habit helps to prioritize the individual's life, ensuring that
they always make time for their faith and spiritual growth.
In conclusion, as a Muslim, prayer has been instituted as an essential aspect of one's life. It helps to create a
sense of connection, submission, and fulfillment that strengthens one's faith and enhances overall well-being.
Every Muslim should adopt the habit of praying regularly, cultivating discipline and prioritizing spirituality as a
way of life. Praying should be an integral component of one's life, and it reminds the individual to be grateful,
humble, and selfless as they continuously strive to be closer to Allah.

chunks.question: 52. Is Jesus the son of God in Islam?
chunks.answer:
In Islam, Jesus is considered a prophet and messenger of God; however, the concept of him being the son of
God is rejected. This notion contradicts the Islamic belief in monotheism, which emphasizes that there is only
one divine entity who created all things. Muslims believe that Jesus was born to Virgin Mary through a
miraculous birth, which was a sign from Allah’s power and mercy. According to Islamic teachings, Jesus
performed miracles like healing the sick and raising the dead with permission from Allah but not by his own will
or authority. Muslims also believe that he didn't die on the cross but ascended to heaven alive where he currently
awaits his return just like other major prophets such as Mohammed himself. In conclusion, while Jesus holds
great respect in Islam as an esteemed prophet among many others sent from Allah throughout history till Quran
described him as being “honoured in this world and Hereafter” (Quran 3:45), what sets him apart isn’t any special
divinity that could put him above limitations consistent for human beings on earth but his extra-ordinary teachings
and wisdom coupled with miraculous powers bestowed upon him by Almighty alone for guidance of mankind
towards salvation.
Islam and Christianity share many beliefs, but one of the most significant differences between these two religions
is on the subject of Jesus. The question of whether Jesus is the son of God in Islam is a complex one that has
been debated by scholars for centuries. While the Islamic faith recognizes Jesus as a prophet, they do not
believe he is the son of God. In this essay, we will explore the Islamic perspective on Jesus and his position in
the Islamic faith.
Firstly, it’s essential to understand that Islam regards Jesus as one of the most important prophets. Muslims
believe that he was born of the virgin Mary, who is one of the most respected women in Islam. They also believe
that Jesus performed miracles through the power of Allah, including healing the sick and raising the dead.
Prophet Jesus is also granted a high degree of respect in Islamic culture and holds a special place in the hearts
of many Muslims.
However, the significant difference between Christianity and Islam regarding Jesus is that Islam does not believe
that he is the son of God. Allah is believed to be above the need and capacity of having offspring or containing
any partners. “Say, "He is Allah, the One; Allah, the Eternal, Absolute; He begetteth not nor is He begotten. And
there is none like unto Him." (Quran, 112:1-4). From Islamic perspective, giving birth is a distinct property of
women, and it dishonors Allah to consider him having a partner or an equal. Therefore, Muslims reject the
concept of the Trinity, which connects Allah with Jesus and the Holy Spirit.
The belief in the oneness of God (monotheism) is the most significant tenet of Islam, and associating a partner or
equal with Allah is considered the most cardinal sin in this religion. Muslims believe that the word "son" as used
in the Bible doesn't have a literal meaning but rather a symbolical term indicating a close or faithful relationship
with God. In the Quran, Prophet Jesus is referred to as "The Messiah, son of Mary," who calls people to believe
in Allah and called them to follow his message or guidance.
Furthermore, Muslim scholars have argued against the concept of Jesus being the son of God by referring to
historical evidence from the Bible. They believe that Jesus himself never claimed to be the son of God, and this
idea is a later development in Christianity. Therefore, it is more a matter of interpretation rather than historical
facts or religious proofs.
In conclusion, while Muslims do not believe that Jesus is the son of God, they hold him in high regard as one of
the greatest prophets in Islam. Although there are differences between Islamic and Christian perspectives on
Prophet Jesus, some values stand in common ground such as Mary's virginity, Jesus's healing miracles, and
guiding people towards a life of faith, and good deeds. Muslim beliefs about Jesus reflect an essential aspect of
Islamic spirituality and deepen the ties between Islamic and Christian religions.

chunks.question: 53. Do I have to change my name if I become a Muslim?
chunks.answer:
No, there is no Islamic requirement to change your name if you become a Muslim. However, it is recommended
to choose a name that has a good meaning and reflects well on the religion. In Islamic tradition, a person's name
holds signification and importance, therefore selecting an appropriate name can be seen as an opportunity to
strengthen one's relationship with God. Many Muslims choose Arabic names because of their historical
significance in Islamic culture, but it is not mandatory for non-Arabic individuals to adopt such names. Ultimately,
the decision to change or keep one's name after conversion lies with the individual based on their personal
preference and circumstances. It is important for new converts to consult with knowledgeable Muslim scholars or
leaders who can provide guidance during this process of transition.
Changing one's name is a voluntary act, and while it is recommended to choose a suitable name according to
Islamic etiquette, it is not an obligation. Islam recognizes the importance of identity and a person's name plays a
significant role in defining one's identity. Therefore, it is a common practice for individuals who embrace Islam to
change their name to a more appropriate and meaningful one. However, many Muslims continue to use their
birth name, and there is no requirement in the Quran or Sunnah to adopt a new name.
When someone converts to Islam, it is a significant life-changing decision. They are reborn as a new person, and
it is natural for them to want to reinvent themselves. Changing one's name is a way to symbolize this renewal of
faith and identify themselves with the Islamic values they have embraced. It enables them to let go of any
negative associations with their previous life and embrace a new identity that aligns with their beliefs.
However, choosing to adopt a new name is not a decision to be taken lightly. Islam places great importance on
one's intention, and the intention behind the name change is crucial. The new name should reflect the person's
personality, beliefs and the values they aspire to live by. It should also be easy to pronounce and not mimic the
names of non-Muslim deities, as Islam prohibits any association with other religions.
Moreover, it is important to remember that Islam does not forbid the use of non-Arabic or non-Muslim names.
Islam is a universal religion that welcomes people from all corners of the world, and their names are a part of
their cultural heritage. There are examples of companions of Prophet Muhammad (Peace be upon him) and
scholars in Islam who kept their non-Arabic names after embracing Islam. This shows that Islam promotes
diversity and does not require everyone to adopt an Arabic or a Muslim name.
In conclusion, changing one's name upon converting to Islam is a personal choice. While it is a common
practice, it is not an obligation in Islam. If one chooses to change their name, it should reflect their personality
and identity, and not mimic the names of other religions. One's cultural heritage and diversity should be
celebrated, and Islam does not require everyone to have an Arabic or Muslim name. Therefore, it is essential to
make an informed, heartfelt decision when considering a name change and ensure that the intention behind it is
pure

chunks.question: 54. Why do you pray five times a day?
chunks.answer:
As a fundamental pillar of Islam, the act of praying five times a day is an essential component of a Muslim's daily
life. The Qur'an emphasizes the importance of maintaining spiritual connection with Allah throughout the day,
and prayer is seen as an opportunity to seek forgiveness, express gratitude, and ask for guidance. Moreover,
prayer serves as a reminder that Allah is constantly watching over us and that we should strive to live our lives
with piety and mindfulness. By praying at specific times each day - before dawn, midday, midafternoon,
sundown, and after dark - Muslims are able to structure their routines around this central religious practice.
Prayer also promotes discipline and self-control while encouraging individual growth in faith by helping people
turn away from worldly distractions and focus on their relationship with Allah. For many believers, the daily ritual
of prayer provides emotional comfort and an unmatched sense of purpose in life.
As a Muslim, prayer holds a significant place in my life. One of the fundamental pillars of Islam is Salah or
prayer, which involves the act of prostrating oneself before Allah five times a day. This practice is deeply
ingrained in our faith and has been instilled since childhood, but it is not just a religious obligation; it serves a
more profound and comprehensive purpose in our spiritual journey.
Firstly, praying five times a day helps to maintain our connection with Allah throughout the day. As Muslims, our
ultimate goal is to submit to Allah's will, and Salah helps us to focus our attention towards Him, ensuring that our
consistency of faith remains even in the most challenging of situations. It provides a reminder to us that no
matter how busy our lives may become or the pressures we may face, Allah is always there and is only a prayer
away.
Additionally, Salah is a source of spiritual purification. It is a cleansing ritual for our minds and souls, as we
cleanse ourselves physically with water before prayer, this purification is extended to the soul during the act of
Salah. It helps to wash away any impurities and negativities that may have accumulated during our daily
activities, leaving us refreshed and pure.
Moreover, Salah acts as a unifying factor among Muslims. All Muslims perform the same rituals of purification
and recitation of verses from the Quran during prayer, regardless of gender, race, or ethnicity. Thus, it reinforces
the sense of brotherhood and sisterhood among Muslims and promotes a sense of community.
Lastly, Salah enhances our spiritual and mental well-being. The act of standing before Allah and reciting His
words provides a sense of peace and tranquillity to the mind and the soul. It strengthens our relationship with
Allah, which we often seek in times of trouble, and instills confidence in our faith. Salah helps us to remember
Allah and his blessings, and it provides a sense of purpose and meaning to our daily lives.
In conclusion, Salah is an essential aspect of a Muslim's life, and performing it five times a day holds great
significance. It helps us to maintain our connection with Allah, purify our souls and minds, unify us with other
Muslims, and strengthens our spiritual well-being. Therefore, it is not just an obligation but a means of spiritual
development and growth that helps us to lead a fulfilled and meaningful life.

chunks.question: 55. Who is Muhammed?
chunks.answer:
Muhammad is the prophet of Islam who received divine revelations from Allah, which later became the sacred
text of Quran. Born in Mecca in 570 AD, he was orphaned at an early age and raised by his grandfather and
uncle. In his early life, he worked as a shepherd and then as a merchant. At the age of 40, he began receiving
revelations from Allah through Angel Gabriel, which continued until his death. Muhammad devoted his life to
spreading the teachings of Islam and forming a community called Ummah based on the principles of justice,
equality, charity and submission to Allah's will. Muslims regard him as a model for ethical behavior and follow his
example in personal conduct, social relationships and religious practices. His prophethood marked the beginning
of Islamic civilization and continues to shape Muslim identity and spirituality today.
Muhammad is the central figure of Islam, and he is believed to be the last prophet sent by Allah (God) to guide
and teach humanity. Born in Mecca in 570 AD, Muhammad was orphaned at an early age and raised by his
grandfather and uncle. He worked as a merchant and lived a comparatively ordinary life until he received his first
revelation from Allah at the age of 40.
This event took place in a cave outside of Mecca, where Muhammad had retreated for contemplation and
reflection. There, he was visited by the angel Gabriel, who delivered the first of many revelations that would later
become the Qur'an, the holy book of Islam. These revelations continued to come to Muhammad over the next 23
years of his life, guiding him and teaching him how to live a life that would please Allah.
Muhammad's teachings and the revelations he received established the core principles of Islam, emphasizing
the importance of faith and good deeds, social justice, and the equality of all believers. He preached the oneness
of God and the need for people to submit to his will. Muhammad's teachings also established the Five Pillars of
Islam, which include the declaration of faith, prayer, fasting, charity, and pilgrimage to Mecca.
Apart from being a prophet and messenger of Allah, Muhammad is highly revered and respected by Muslims as
an exemplary human being. Accounts of his life detail his virtues which became exemplary to the believers, from
his kindness, honesty, and generosity to his patience, humility, and compassion towards his fellow beings. He is
seen as a model of faith, piety, and righteousness who demonstrated how to live a life devoted to God while also
being fully engaged in the world.
Muslims view Muhammad's life as a shining example of humility, simplicity, and service to others. He is said to
have emphasized the importance of treating all people with kindness and respect, regardless of their race,
religion, or social status. He spoke out against oppression and injustice, and fought to defend the rights of those
who were marginalized or oppressed. These actions are reflected in his teachings of social justice and the
equality of all people under the eyes of Allah.
In conclusion, Muhammad is regarded as the final and most important prophet in the Islamic faith. He is seen as
a model of love, compassion, and service to one's fellow humanity. His teachings and revelations form the very
foundation of Islam, including the Five Pillars that guide the religious practice of Muslims worldwide. His life and
character are reflective of the best qualities that a human being can possess, and thus, Muslims deeply revere
and respect him. His life and teachings have impacted the world profoundly, leaving behind a legacy of peace
and compassion.

chunks.question: 56. What's your evidence for the Quran?
chunks.answer:
The evidence for the Quran stems from its unique literary style, its coherence, and its historical accuracy. The
Arabic language used in the Quran is considered one of the most refined and sophisticated forms of the
language, displaying incredible literary beauty and eloquence that is unmatched in any other book or text.
Additionally, the consistent message, themes, and structure found throughout the entire book represent a
coherent message that could not have been produced by an individual without divine intervention. Furthermore,
the Quran contains a great deal of accurate information about historical events and places from different time
periods, which has been confirmed through archaeological discoveries. This consistency in both form and
content provides substantive evidence towards it being a divine revelation as claimed by Islamic tradition.
The Quran, the holy book of Islam, has been a subject of extensive debate and discussion among
scholars for decades. Muslims revere it as the Words of Allah transmitted to the Prophet Muhammad
through the Angel Gabriel. The Quran forms the backbone of Islam, and it is considered the most reliable
and authentic source of knowledge about their religion. The question of evidence for the Quran has been
much-discussed, and in this essay, we will attempt to explore some of the evidence available in support
of its authenticity.
First and foremost, Muslims believe that the Quran is divine because Allah Himself has testified to it.
Many verses in the Quran claim to be the Words of Allah, and this is taken as evidence of its authenticity
by Muslims. The Quran says, “Verily, We have sent down the Reminder (the Quran), and surely, We will
guard it (from corruption).” [Quran 15:9]. Thus Muslims consider it the exact words the Almighty
revealed to His Prophet.
Secondly, historical evidence shows that the Quran is the same as it was during the time of the Prophet
Muhammad. The Quran was written down in the 7th century, during the lifetime of the Prophet, on
various materials such as bones, leather and parchment papers. Many companions of the Prophet wrote
down the Quranic verses, and it was compiled under the supervision of the Prophet himself, as
described in several authentic Hadiths.
Furthermore, the Quranic verses contained in the present-day Quran that originated in the seventh
century are similar, if not identical, to those inscribed on rocks and other surfaces in Arabia and dated
back to the early seventh century. Many verses of Quran were either memorized by the Prophet's
companions or engraved on stones and mentioned in Hadiths. Additionally, the first four Caliphs of
Islam kept copies of the Quran and corrected any errors. This is evidence that the Quran has been
preserved with exceptional accuracy from the early days of Islam.
The linguistic style and coherence of the Quran is another evidence that it must be the divine revelation.
The Quran is written in unique and incomparable Arabic, even though it was revealed over 1400 years
ago. Its grammatical structure, rhyme, rhythm, and spelling have never been matched, despite several
attempts by experts in Arabic language. Muslims believe that the inimitable literary style of the Quran is
impossible for any human to replicate, and this is indicative of its divine origin.
In conclusion, there are several pieces of evidence supporting the authenticity of the Quran. Muslims
firmly believe that the Quran is the direct word of Allah, and this is a belief that is unshakable.
Furthermore, the Quran has been preserved with exceptional accuracy since the time of the Prophet, and
historical evidence shows that it has not been corrupted in any way. The linguistic style and coherence
of the Quran is remarkable and has never been equalled by any other piece of literature. Thus, it can be
concluded that the evidence for the Quran's authenticity is solid,

chunks.question: 57. Where is happiness?
chunks.answer:
In Islam, happiness is not simply a transient emotion but instead a state of contentment that one can achieve
through fulfilling their duties towards Allah and living a moral life. True happiness comes from being in harmony
with oneself and one’s environment, as well as from engaging in acts of worship, kindness to others, and
pursuing righteous actions. The Quran describes paradise as the ultimate abode of bliss and joy in which
believers will attain true happiness free from all forms of sorrow and grief. Additionally, it is emphasized that
material possessions or worldly success should not be equated with happiness or define one's value as a
person; rather, true fulfillment lies in leading an ethical life, seeking knowledge, helping those in need, worshiping
Allah sincerely, reflecting on His creation, and having faith in His divine plan. Hence, the Islamic perspective on
happiness revolves around achieving inner peace by fulfilling one’s spiritual and social obligations while holding
onto hope for eternal reward.
Happiness is a widely sought-after concept, and it is vital for every human being. Islam gives us an
understanding of what happiness is and how we can achieve it. Muslims believe that happiness lies in living a
fulfilling life, both spiritually and physically. Muslims find happiness by following the Quran, Sunnah, and the
guidance provided by the Prophet Muhammad.
Islam teaches that happiness is not merely dependent on worldly pleasures or material possessions. Muslims
believe that happiness is found in the remembrance of Allah and by fulfilling their obligations towards Him.
Muslims find true happiness through a deep connection with Allah and an appreciation for every blessing that He
has bestowed upon them.
Islam teaches that happiness lies in practicing the five pillars of Islam: the declaration of faith (Shahada),
performing the five daily prayers (Salah), fasting during Ramadan (Sawm), giving charity (Zakat), and making a
pilgrimage to Mecca (Hajj). These five pillars provide believers with a sense of purpose and meaning in life, and
they allow Muslims to fulfill their obligations to Allah and their fellow human beings.
Islam also emphasizes the importance of inner peace and tranquility. Muslims are encouraged to practice
mindfulness and self-reflection to achieve inner peace. This can be done through daily prayers, reading Quran,
and seeking guidance from knowledgeable individuals. By focusing on their relationship with Allah, Muslims can
find inner calmness and true happiness.
Islam also places great emphasis on family relationships and the importance of caring for others. Muslims are
taught to show compassion, kindness, and generosity towards their families and those in need. By building
strong family ties and helping others, Muslims can find a sense of purpose and happiness.
In conclusion, Islam teaches that true happiness is found in living a balanced and fulfilling life that is grounded in
faith, mindfulness, and compassion. Muslims find happiness by building a strong relationship with Allah, living a
righteous life, being kind to others, and fulfilling their obligations towards Him. Islam provides a comprehensive
guide to happiness that is accessible to everyone, and it offers a path to true and lasting satisfaction in this life
and the hereafter.

chunks.question: 58. What is the difference between Sunni and Shia Muslims?
chunks.answer:
The primary difference between Sunni and Shia Muslims can be traced back to a disagreement over who should
have succeeded the Prophet Muhammad as the leader of the Islamic community. Sunnis believe that Abu Bakr,
a close companion of the Prophet, was rightfully appointed as caliph after Muhammad's death, while Shias argue
that Ali, Muhammad's cousin and son-in-law, was the rightful successor. This led to a split in Islam and
subsequent theological differences between the two groups. In terms of beliefs and practices, Sunnis make up
the majority of Muslims worldwide and tend to emphasize following established schools of thought and practice
(madhabs). Shias place greater emphasis on individual interpretation and follow a succession of imams (leaders)
who are believed to be divinely guided. There are also notable differences in ritual practices such as prayer
styles and holiday observances between Sunni and Shia communities.
Sunni and Shia Islam are the two major sects comprising Islam. They differ in their religious beliefs, practices,
and interpretation of the Quran. Despite their shared ancestry, these Islamic divisions have significantly different
beliefs, and their differences have led to significant historical and contemporary conflicts throughout the Muslim
world. This essay aims to highlight the salient differences between Sunni and Shia Muslims.
The primary difference between Sunni and Shia Muslims is their view of the authority of religious leaders. Shia
Muslims believe that leadership of the Muslim community after prophet Muhammad's death should have passed
on to Ali, the prophet's cousin and son in law, through lineage. They also believe that Ali's descendants, known
as Imams, possess spiritual and political authority inherited directly from the prophet. In contrast, Sunni Muslims
believe that political authority should be given to the person best suited to lead the community according to the
example of the prophet Muhammad.
Another significant difference between Sunni and Shia Muslims is their religious practices. Although both sects
share many religious traditions, Shia Muslims have different holy days and a different religious calendar than
Sunni Muslims. For instance, Shia Muslims commemorate the martyrdom of Ali on the tenth day of Muharram,
known as Ashura, and the death of the Prophet's daughter, Fatima, on the fifth day of Jamadi-ul-Sani.
Additionally, there are differences in some of their religious practices. For example, in Shia Islam, pointing fingers
during prayer is a crucial ritual when taking an oath, while it is not mandatory in Sunni Islam. Likewise, Shia
Muslims perform prayer three times a day, while Sunni Muslims offer five daily prayers.
Moreover, Shia Muslims commemorate their Imams' deaths, while Sunni Muslims do not, claim that
commemoration in such a manner is unnecessary and not part of the teachings of the Prophet.
Furthermore, Sunni and Shia Muslims have different opinions on various theological concepts, such as the
nature of the Quran, the Imamate, and the concept of saints. For example, Shia Islam teaches that the Quran
has both an apparent (zahir) and an inner (batin) meaning, whereas Sunni Muslims believe the Quran is clear
and straightforward. Similarly, Shia Muslims believe that the Imamate, or the spiritual and political authority, is a
divine appointment, while Sunni Muslims believe that leadership is based on consensus.
In Conclusion, the fundamental differences between Sunni and Shia Muslims are rooted in their beliefs around
leadership, religious practices, and theological concepts. It is essential to understand these differences and
respect each sect's views to achieve a greater sense of shared humanity and peace in the Muslim world. While
their differences have been the source of historical conflicts, mutual understanding and respect can lead towards
a greater unity, falling under the overarching umbrella of Islam.

chunks.question: 59. Do Muslims believe in Jesus?
chunks.answer:
Muslims believe in Jesus as a prophet and messenger of God, but they do not accept the belief that he is the
son of God or part of the Holy Trinity. According to Islamic teachings, Jesus was one of the most important
prophets sent by Allah before Prophet Muhammad. Muslims revere and respect him for his teachings and
exemplary conduct. They also firmly believe in his miraculous birth from Virgin Mary, healing powers, and his
ascension into heaven. However, Islam vehemently opposes any notion that attributes divine qualities to any
human being or an entity in partnership with God. Therefore, while Muslims have great reverence for Jesus as a
holy figure sent from God, they do not equate him with divinity in the same way that Christians do.
Muslims are followers of the Islamic faith, and one of the most common questions they are asked is whether or
not they believe in Jesus. The answer to this is yes, but it is important to understand the Muslim perspective on
Jesus and how it differs from that of Christians.
In Islam, Jesus, known as Isa in Arabic, is regarded as a prophet who was sent by Allah (God) to guide the
people of his time. He is considered to be one of the greatest prophets of Islam, alongside other prophets like
Moses and Abraham. Muslims believe that Jesus was born of a virgin named Mary, and that He performed many
miracles during His lifetime.
However, there are some fundamental differences between the Christian and Muslim beliefs about Jesus.
Muslims do not believe that Jesus is the son of God or that He was crucified on the cross. According to Islamic
teachings, Jesus was not crucified but rather God saved Him and raised Him to heaven before He could be
arrested.
Muslims believe that Jesus will return to Earth before Judgment Day, and He will defeat the antichrist and
establish peace and justice on Earth. He is also believed to be a witness on the Day of Judgment.
Overall, while Muslims do believe in Jesus, their beliefs about Him differ from those of Christians in important
ways. Muslims believe that Jesus was a prophet, but not the son of God, and that He did not die on the cross.
Through the teachings of the Quran and Islamic scripture, Muslims are encouraged to honor and respect Jesus,
as they believe He was one of Allah's most important messengers.

chunks.question: 60. Does one need to go to a mosque to convert?
chunks.answer:
In order to convert to Islam, one does not necessarily need to go to a mosque. The process of converting
primarily involves the recitation of the shahada, or declaration of faith, in the presence of two Muslim witnesses.
This ritual can be performed anywhere and does not require the presence of an imam or an official religious
authority. However, mosques can provide valuable resources and support for individuals who are interested in
converting to Islam. Mosques typically offer educational classes, counseling services, and opportunities for
communal worship and prayer. Additionally, being part of a mosque community can help new converts feel more
connected to their faith and facilitate their learning about Islamic traditions and practices. Ultimately, while going
to a mosque is not necessary for converting to Islam, it can be beneficial for those seeking guidance and
community in their spiritual journey.
Religion is often considered one of the most complex aspects of life. It not only provides a sense of community
but also impacts personal beliefs and ideologies. Several individuals contemplate changing their religion or faith,
commonly known as converting. Converting to a new religion is a significant decision that requires extensive
contemplation and research. One common question that arises during this process is whether one needs to go to
a mosque to convert to Islam. The answer to this question usually varies based on individual beliefs, thought
process, and cultural background.
To begin with, it is essential to understand that Islam is a religion that believes in the practice of five pillars- belief
in the oneness of God, prayer, fasting, charity, and pilgrimage. Conversion to Islam is a straightforward process
that only requires uttering the Shahada, the Islamic declaration of faith, which includes the statement of belief
that "There is no god but Allah, and Muhammad is his prophet." It is a simple declaration that signifies
acceptance and commitment to the Islamic faith. Thus, one cannot emphasize the requirement of going to a
mosque to utter or declare the Shahada.
However, mosques play a significant role in the Islamic community as they represent a place of worship, social
gathering, and education. Going to a mosque for the first time can add value to one's experience and
understanding of Islamic practices. It provides an individual with a platform to interact with members of the
community and seek guidance from Islamic scholars. Moreover, attending a mosque can provide a sense of
belonging and togetherness among individuals who share the same faith.
Additionally, mosques can be a reliable source for information on Islamic beliefs and practices. Conversing with
other community members and Islamic scholars can deepen one's understanding of Islam and clarify any
misconceptions or doubts. Mosques also offer various educational programs and classes for individuals wishing
to learn more about Islam. These classes often cover topics such as Islamic history, culture, and traditions,
among others.
In conclusion, there is no necessity for an individual to go to a mosque to convert to Islam. However, mosques
do offer invaluable benefits for individuals who seek guidance and assistance in understanding Islamic beliefs
and practices. Mosque visits can provide a sense of community, offer access to educational programs, and
deepen one's understanding and appreciation of the Islamic faith. Ultimately, the decision to attend a mosque
lies with the individual and should be based on their personal beliefs and goals.

chunks.question: 61. How can I go to a local mosque and pray?
chunks.answer:
To attend prayers at a local mosque, start by researching the mosque's congregation and prayer times, which
you can find on the mosque's website or by calling them. It is important to dress modestly and respectfully in
loose-fitted clothing that covers your arms, legs, and head for women. Upon arrival, seek out any signs or
indications of gender separation within the prayer hall; there may be separate areas for men and women. Before
entering the main hall, wash your hands up to the wrist, then rinse your mouth and nose in preparation for
prayer. Ablution facilities are often available on-site for this purpose. Try not to arrive late as it is advised to
perform two units of raka'ahs before joining the congregational prayer. During the service, follow along with the
Imam's lead and stand when required; pray with proper etiquette like avoiding talking during Salah (prayer).
Afterward, feel free to ask questions or stick around for any post-prayer gathering that follows tradition.
Going to a local mosque to pray is a sacred and spiritual experience that is cherished by millions of people
around the world. For Muslims, visiting the mosque regularly is a way to connect with their faith, commune with
the community, and seek guidance and support from their fellow believers. However, for those who are new to
the Islamic faith or unfamiliar with the customs and rituals of the mosque, this experience may seem daunting or
intimidating. In this essay, we will outline some simple steps and tips to help you feel more comfortable and
confident when attending your local mosque.
The first step towards going to a local mosque to pray is to research the mosque's location, hours, and services.
This information can usually be found on the mosque's website, social media pages or by talking to other
members of the community. It's important to make sure that you know when the mosque is open, what services
are offered, and what to expect when you arrive.
Once you have found a suitable mosque, it's important to dress appropriately for the occasion. Muslim men and
women are expected to dress modestly and conservatively, covering their arms, legs, and hair if they are female,
and avoiding tight or revealing clothing. It's also important to remove your shoes before entering the mosque, as
a sign of respect and cleanliness.
When you arrive at the mosque, you will usually be greeted by members of the community, who will guide you
through the process of performing wudu, or the ritual cleansing of the hands, face, and feet. This is an important
step in preparing for prayer and should be done carefully and mindfully.
Once you have completed wudu, you should find a spot in the prayer hall, facing towards Mecca, and make sure
that you do not disrupt the flow of the community, which will usually be bowing and prostrating in unison.
The prayer itself is usually led by an imam, who will recite verses from the Quran and lead the community in
various postures and expressions of worship. It's important to follow the movements of the imam closely and
participate fully in the prayer, focusing your mind and heart on the words and meanings of the Quranic verses.
After the prayer is over, it's customary to socialize and chat with fellow members of the community, sharing food
and drink and building bonds of friendship and brotherhood. This is an important part of mosque culture and
should be approached with an open and friendly attitude.
In conclusion, going to a local mosque to pray is a rich and fulfilling experience that can deepen your connection
with Islam and bring you closer to your fellow believers. By following these simple steps and tips, you can ensure
that your visit to the mosque is respectful, mindful, and nurturing, leaving you with a sense of peace and spiritual
renewal.

chunks.question: 62. Why do many Muslims kill innocents?
chunks.answer:
it is not ethical for anyone to make any generalizations or assumptions about a particular group of people.
However, it is widely known that Islam as a religion strictly forbids the killing of innocent people. Unfortunately,
some individuals or groups with political agendas have used distorted interpretations of religious texts to justify
their violent actions against civilians. In addition, socioeconomic factors such as poverty, lack of education, and
political instability can contribute to extremism and radicalization among certain Muslims. Ultimately, these
individuals who commit such heinous crimes do not represent the majority of Muslims worldwide who strive to
promote peace and harmony in society. It is important for everyone to condemn terrorism and work towards
building a more peaceful world through education and dialogue.
No one can write such an essay which insightes terror or hatred, However, we would like to clarify that the
assumption that many Muslims kill innocents is baseless, misleading, and contradicts the principle of Islam which
prohibits killing innocent human beings. Islam is an Abrahamic religion which values human life and condemns
any act of violence or terrorism that targets innocent people.
Furthermore, it is important to understand that the actions of a few extremist groups or individuals do not reflect
the beliefs or practices of the entire Muslim population. Islamophobic propaganda and biased media coverage
often portray an inaccurate and negative image of Muslims, resulting in harmful stereotypes and discrimination.
It is crucial to recognize that terrorism is a global issue that affects people of all religions and backgrounds. It is
not a problem exclusive to Muslims. Addressing the root causes of extremism, such as poverty, political
instability, and injustice, is essential in preventing acts of violence.
In conclusion, the notion that many Muslims kill innocents is unfounded and harmful. Instead, it is vital to
promote peace, understanding, and respect between different religions and cultures. Only through empathy and
education can we defeat prejudice and violence.

chunks.question: 63. Can a Muslim man marry 4 women?
chunks.answer:
According to Islamic law, Muslim men are allowed to marry up to four wives at a time provided that they can treat
each wife fairly and equally. This practice is known as polygamy and is often misunderstood by non-Muslims.
The Quran permits it in certain circumstances such as providing financial and emotional support for widows,
divorcees or women who may find it difficult to marry. However, Islam emphasizes the importance of treating all
wives with equal care and affection, which includes providing them with adequate food, clothing, shelter along
with dividing their time among them fairly. Polygamy is not a requirement for Muslims nor is it encouraged if one
cannot fulfill the responsibilities of marriage towards multiple partners. It should be mentioned that many Muslim
countries have banned this practice since it has been subject to abuse in some cases where men use it as an
excuse for coercive control over their wives rather than building respectful relationships based on love and
mutual consent.
Islamic law allows Muslim men to have up to four wives under certain conditions. This practice is known as
polygyny and is a controversial issue in many societies. While some see it as a way to provide for more women
and children, others view it as discriminatory and unfair to women.
In Islam, a man can only marry up to four women if he can provide for them equally. This means that he must
have the financial means, housing, and time to care for all of his wives and their children fairly. If a man cannot
fulfill these requirements, he is not allowed to take on additional wives.
Furthermore, the Quran states that a man should treat all of his wives with equal love and respect. He should not
favor one wife over another or treat one wife unfairly. If he is unable to do so, then he should not marry more than
one wife.
Polygyny in Islam is not an obligation, but rather a permission granted by God under certain conditions. It is
meant to address situations where there is a shortage of men for various reasons, such as war or disease. In
such circumstances, polygyny may benefit society by providing for the needs of more women and children who
would otherwise be left without support.
However, polygyny can also be abused and can lead to problems such as jealousy, favoritism, and neglect. It is
therefore emphasized in Islam that a man should only take on additional wives if he can fulfill his responsibilities
to all of them equally.
It is also important to note that polyandry, the practice of a woman having multiple husbands, is not allowed in
Islam. This is because Islam places a strong emphasis on family and lineage, and it is necessary to know who
the father of a child is in order to establish inheritance rights and fulfill other obligations.
In conclusion, Muslim men are allowed to marry up to four women under certain conditions, including providing
for them equally and treating them with love and respect. Polygyny is not an obligation, but rather a permission
that is meant to address specific circumstances. However, it is important to ensure that this practice is not
abused and that women are not treated unfairly.

chunks.question: 64. What happens to me if I convert to islam?
chunks.answer:
If you choose to convert to Islam, you will enter into a rich and diverse community of believers with over 1.5
billion adherents worldwide. The process of conversion involves making a declaration of faith, called the
shahada, in which one testifies that there is no god but Allah and that Muhammad is his prophet. Afterward, it is
recommended to seek out a mosque or Islamic center for support and guidance from fellow Muslims. Living as a
Muslim involves following the Five Pillars of Islam: witnessing that there is no god but Allah and that Muhammad
is his prophet; praying five times daily; giving to charity; fasting during Ramadan; and making the pilgrimage to
Mecca at least once in your lifetime if possible. Although converting may come with challenges such as familial
or societal pressure, many who have done so report feeling spiritually fulfilled and connected to something larger
than themselves.
If an individual decides to convert to Islam, he or she can expect some significant changes. Firstly, he or she
must make a sincere declaration of faith in Allah and His prophets, particularly Prophet Muhammad (peace be
upon him). The new Muslim will recite the Shahada, which is the declaration of faith, either in private or in the
presence of a Muslim witness.
After conversion, the new Muslim will be welcomed into the Muslim community, which is commonly called
Ummah. They will be given a Muslim name and are no longer called by their original name, whichever religion
they followed before. The new Muslim will begin to practice the Five Pillars of Islam, which are the foundation of
Islamic faith. These consist of the declaration of faith (Shahada), prayer (Salah), fasting during the month of
Ramadan (Sawm), giving Zakat (charity), and performing Hajj (pilgrimage) provided they have the resources.
Due to conversion to Islam, the new Muslim must change his or her lifestyle regarding dress and behavior,
particularly regarding opposite genders. Women will wear the hijab and cover all parts of their bodies except
faces and hands. Men wear traditional Islamic clothing or their own choice of modest clothing. In Islam, it's
prohibited to use vulgar language, consume alcohol or any drugs, and involve in adultery acts. Islam also lays
down ground rules for sexual relationships and restricts intimate relationships between any genders outside of
marriage.
The new Muslim will now participate in the Islamic calendar month and events, such as Eid al-Fitr and Eid
al-Adha. He or she will be required to attend Islamic prayers every Friday, where they will listen to sermons and
offer congregational prayers. The Muslim community encourages each other to follow these Islamic rules and
practice their faith collectively.
Finally, it's important to mention, Islam is a peaceful religion that doesn't promote terrorism or violence. Any
terroristic or violent acts go against the fundamental teachings of Islam, and that person is guilty of the crime.
Islam aims to promote peace, love, and harmony in society through its teachings, and a Muslim is expected to
follow them strictly.
In conclusion, conversion to Islam is an essential decision for an individual. It's important to research and
understand the Islamic principles and customs before taking that step. One must be prepared to make significant
changes and live according to the Islamic way of life. If a person adheres to these teachings and practices it with
honesty, he or she will receive the love and support of the Islamic community and find peace, satisfaction, and
happiness in life.

chunks.question: 1-What is Islam?
chunks.answer:
The word "Islam" means peace and submission.
Peace means to be at peace with yourself and your
surroundings and submission means submission to
the will of God. A broader meaning of the word
"Islam" is to achieve peace by submitting to the will
of God.
This is a unique religion with a name which signifies
a moral attitude and a way of life. Judaism takes its
name from the tribe of Juda, Christianity from Jesus
Christ, Buddhism from Goutam Buddha and
Hinduism from Indus River. However, Muslims derive
their identity from the message of Islam, rather than
the person of Muhammed (Peace be upon him), thus
should not be called "Muhammadans".

chunks.question: 2- Who is Allah?
chunks.answer:
Allah is the Arabic word for "one God". Allah is not
God of Muslims only. He is God of all creations,
because He is their Creator and Sustainer.

chunks.question: 3-Does Allah look like us?
chunks.answer:
No, Allah is perfect. He is not like any of His
creations. A Muslim does not say a single thing
about Allah other than what Allah says about
Himself. Allah is Perfect and Unique.

chunks.question: 4-What is the Kabah?
chunks.answer:
The Kabah is the place of worship, which God
commanded Abraham and Ishmael to build over four
thousand years ago. The building was constructed of
stone on what many believe was the original site of a
sanctuary established by Adam. God commanded
3
Abraham to summon all mankind to visit this place,
and when pilgrims go there today they say 'At Thy
service, O Lord', in response to Abraham's
summons.

chunks.question: 5- Who is a Muslim?
chunks.answer:
The word "Muslim" means one who submits to the
will of God. This is done by declaring that "there is
no god except one God and Muhammad is the
messenger of God." In a broader sense, anyone who
willingly submits to the will of God is a Muslim. Thus,
all the prophets preceding the prophet Muhammad
are considered Muslims. The Quran specifically
mentions Abraham who lived long before Moses and
Christ that, "he was not a Jew or a Christian but a
Muslim," because, he had submitted to the will of
God. Thus there are Muslims who are not submitting
at all to the will of God and there are Muslims who
are doing their best to live an Islamic life. One
cannot judge Islam by looking at those individuals
who have a Muslim name but in their actions, they
are not living or behaving as Muslims. The extent of
being a Muslim can be according to the degree to
which one is submitting to the will of God, in his
beliefs and his actions.
6- Who was Muhammad? (Peace be upon him)
In brief, Muhammad (Peace be upon him) was born
in a noble tribe of Mecca in Arabia in the year 570
AD. His ancestry goes back to Prophet Ishmael
(Peace be upon him), son of Prophet Abraham
(Peace be upon him). His father died before his birth
4
and his mother died when he was six. He did not
attend a formal school since he was raised first by a
nurse as it was the custom those days, and then by
his grandfather and uncle. As a young man, he was
known as a righteous person who used to meditate
in a cave. At age 40, he was given the prophethood
when the angel, Gabriel, appeared in the cave.
Subsequently, the revelations came over 23 years
and were compiled in the form of a book called the
Quran which Muslims consider as the final and the
last word of God. The Quran has been preserved,
unchanged, in its original form and confirms the
truth in the Torah, the psalms and the Gospel. (1)
7-How did Muhammad (peace be upon him)

chunks.question: become a prophet and a messenger of God?
chunks.answer:
At the age of 40, while engaged in a meditative
retreat, Muhammad (peace be upon him) received
his first revelation from God through the Angel
Gabriel. This revelation, which continued for twenty-
three years, is known as the Quran.
As soon as he began to recite the words he heard
from Gabriel, and to preach the truth that God had
revealed to him, he and his small group of followers
suffered bitter persecution, which grew so fierce that
in the year 622 God gave them the command to
emigrate. This event, the Hijrah, 'migration', in
which they left Makkah for the city of Madinah some
260 miles to the north, marks the beginning of the
Muslim calendar.
After several years, the Prophet (peace be upon him)
and his followers were able to return to Makkah,
where they forgave their enemies and established
Islam definitively. Before the Prophet (peace be
5
upon him) died at the age of 63, the greater part of
Arabia was Muslim, and within a century of his death
Islam had spread to Spain in the West and as Far
East as China.
8- Do Muslims worship Muhammad? (Peace be
upon him)
No. Muslims do not worship Muhammad (Peace be
upon him) or any other prophets. Muslims believe in
all prophets including Adam, Noah, Abraham, David,
Solomon, Moses and Jesus. Muslims believe that
Muhammad (Peace be upon him) was the last of the
prophets. They believe that God alone is to be
worshiped, not any human being.
___________________________
1-Khan,The personality of Allah’s last messenger , p (17-
34)

chunks.question: 9-What is the Quran?
chunks.answer:
The Quran is a record of the exact words revealed by
God through the Angel Gabriel to the Prophet
Muhammad (peace be upon him). It was memorized
by Muhammad (peace be upon him) and then
dictated to his companions, and written down by
scribes, who crosschecked it during his lifetime. Not
one word of its 114 Surahs, has been changed over
the centuries, so that the Quran is in every detail the
unique and miraculous text which was revealed to
Muhammad (peace be upon him) fourteen centuries
ago.
6

chunks.question: 10-What is the Quran about?
chunks.answer:
The Quran, the last revealed Word of God, is the
prime source of every Muslim's faith and practice. It
deals with all the subjects which concern us as
human beings: wisdom, doctrine, worship, and law,
but its basic theme is the relationship between God
and His creatures. At the same time, it provides
guidelines for a just society, proper human conduct
and an equitable economic system .

chunks.question: 11-Are there any other sacred sources?
chunks.answer:
Yes, the Sunnah, the practice and example of the
Prophet (peace be upon him), is the second
authority for Muslims. A Hadith is a reliably
transmitted report of what the Prophet (peace be
upon him) said, did, or approved. Belief in the
Sunnah is part of the Islamic faith.
Examples of the Prophet's sayings
The Prophet (peace be upon him) said:
'God has no mercy on one who has no mercy for
others.'
'None of you truly believes until he wishes for his
brother what he wishes for himself.'
'Powerful is not he who knocks the other down,
indeed powerful is he who controls himself in a fit of
anger.'
(From the Hadith collections of Bukhari, Muslim,
Tirmidhi and Baihaqi.)

chunks.question: 12-How do we know Islam is the truth?
chunks.answer:
1- It is the only religion that holds Allah as One,
Unique, and Perfect.
2- It is the only religion that believes in the sole
worship of Allah, not Jesus, not an idol, and not an
7
angel, only Allah.
3- The Quran does not contain contradictions.
4- The Quran contains scientific facts, which are
1300 years ahead of their time. The Quran, while
revealed 1400 years ago contains scientific facts,
which are only now being discovered. It is not in
contradiction to science.
5- Allah has challenged the world to produce the like
of the Quran. And He says they won't be able to.
6- Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was the
most influential man in history. In the book "The 100
most influential men in History", written by non-
Muslim, the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon
him) was #1. Prophet Jesus (peace be upon him)
was #3. It should be noted that even the Prophet
Jesus (peace be upon him) was a prophet sent by
Allah.

chunks.question: 13-Does Islam tolerate other beliefs?
chunks.answer:
The Qur’an says:
Allah does not forbid you with regards to those who
do not fight you for [your] faith nor drive you out of
your homes, from dealing kindly and justly with
them; for Allah loves those who are just.
(Qur’an, 60:8)
There is no compulsion in religion. (2:214)
It is one of the functions of Islamic law to protect the
privileged status of minorities, and this is why non-
8
Muslim places of worship have flourished all over the
Islamic world. History provides many examples of
Muslim tolerance towards other faiths. For example,
when the caliph Omar entered Jerusalem in the year
634, he granted amnesty to all and sanctioned
freedom of worship to all religious communities in
the city. Another example is Muslims who ruled the
Spain had such tolerance of other beliefs that the
Golden Age of Jewish Civilization flourished under
the Muslim rule.
Not only that, Islamic law permits non-Muslim
minorities to set up their own courts thus allowing
them the autonomy to be judged according to their
family law.
14-Do Islam and Christianity have different

chunks.question: origins?
chunks.answer:
Together with Judaism, they go back to the prophet
and patriarch Abraham, and their three prophets are
directly descended from his sons-Muhammad (peace
be upon him) from the eldest, Ishmael, and Moses
and Jesus, from Isaac. Abraham established the
settlement, which today is the city of Makkah, and
built the Kabah towards which all Muslims turn when
they pray.
15. What do Muslims think of Jesus? (Peace be
upon him)
Muslims think highly of Jesus (peace be upon him)
and his worthy mother, Mary. The Quran tells us that
Jesus was born of a miraculous birth without a
father. "Lo! The likeness of Jesus with Allah is the
9
likeness of Adam. He created him of dust, and then
He said unto him: Be and he is" (Quran 3.59). He
was given many miracles as a prophet. These
include speaking soon after his birth in defense of his
mother's piety. God's other gifts to him included
healing the blind and the sick, reviving the dead,
making a bird out of clay and most importantly, the
message he was carrying. These miracles were given
to him by God to establish him as a prophet.
According to the Quran, he was not crucified but was
raised into Heaven. (Quran, Chapter Maryam)
16-"How can you believe in God, when you
can't see, hear, touch, smell, taste or even
imagine what He is?"
We know from the teachings of Muhammad, peace
be upon him, that no one has ever actually seen God
- at least not in this lifetime. Nor are we able to use
our senses to make some kind of contact with Him.
However, we are encouraged in Islam to use our
senses and our common sense to recognize that all
of this universe could not possibly come into
existence on its own. Something had to design it all
and then put it into motion. That is beyond our
ability to do, yet it is something that we can
understand.
We don't have to see an artist to recognize a
painting, correct? So, if we see paintings without
seeing artists painting them, in the same way, we
can believe that Allah created everything without
having to see Him (or touch, or hear, etc.).(1)
10

chunks.question: 17- What are the pillars of Islam?
chunks.answer:
There are five major pillars of Islam which are the
articles of faith. These pillars are 1) the belief (Iman)
in one God and that Muhammad (P) is His
messenger, 2) prayer (Salat) which are prescribed
five times a day, 3) fasting (Siyam) which is required
in the month of Ramadan, 4) charity (Zakat) which
is the poor-due on the wealth of the rich and 5) hajj
which is the pilgrimage to Mecca once in a lifetime if
one can afford it physically and financially. All the
pillars should be of equal height and strength in a
building in order to give the building its due shape
and proportions. It is not possible that one would do
hajj without observing fasting or without practicing
regular prayers. Now think of a building which has
pillars only. It would not be called a building. In
order to make it a building, it has to have a roof, it
has to have walls, it has to have doors and windows.
These things in Islam are the moral codes of Islam
such as honesty, truthfulness, steadfastness and
many other human moral qualities. Thus in order to
be a Muslim, one should not only be practicing the
pillars of Islam but should also have the highest
possible attribute for being a good human being.
Only then the building is completed and looks
beautiful.

chunks.question: 18- What is the purpose of worship in Islam?
chunks.answer:
The purpose of worship in Islam is to be God
conscious. Thus the worship, whether it is prayer,
fasting, or charity, is a means to achieve God
consciousness so that when one becomes conscious
of God, in thought and in action, he is in a better
11
position to receive His bounties both in this world
and the hereafter.

chunks.question: 19- Do Muslims believe in the hereafter?
chunks.answer:
God is Just and manifest His justice, He established
the system of accountability. Those who do good will
be rewarded and those who do wrong will be
punished accordingly. Thus, He created Heaven and
Hell and there are admission criteria for both.
Muslims believe that the present life is a temporary
one. It is a test and if we pass the test, we will be
given a life of permanent pleasure in the company of
good people in Heaven.
20- Will the good actions of the non-believers

chunks.question: be wasted?
chunks.answer:
No. The Quran clearly says that, "anyone who has an
atom's worth of goodness will see it and anyone who
has done an atom's worth of evil will also see it"
(Quran 99:7- 8).
By that it is meant that those who are non- believers
but have done good will be rewarded in this world
for their good deed. On the other hand, those who
do good if they are Muslims, they will be rewarded
not only in this world but also in the world hereafter.
However, the final Judgment is up to God himself.
(Quran 2:62)
